In this episode, Tanner seeks the African American vote.

Title: HEIFETZ MASTER CLASS SERIES: Volume 1
Description: Directed by Nathan Kroll • 1962 • United States /  / In this renowned series of rare television appearances, the legendary Jascha Heifetz—often referred to as the greatest violinist of the 20th century—leads a historic master class at the University of Southern California, in 1962. Through their mixture of brilliance and informality, these classes offer a glimpse into the technique, process, and personality of a classical virtuoso.

Title: Cours du soir
Description: Directed by Nicolas Ribowski • 1967 • France /  / Made while Jacques Tati was in production on PlayTime, and shot on the sets built for that film, the twentyty-seven minute Cours du soir was directed by Tati assistant Nicolas Ribowski and stars Tati as an acting instructor.

Title: Split Screen: S8-E6 Projections: Walter Bernstein
Description: Of all Projections interviews, Walter Bernstein’s tales are the stuff of a grand movie adventure. From WW2 hero/correspondent to Hollywood Blacklist in five years, both his script for THE FRONT and memoir INSIDE OUT illuminate that era, while FAIL SAFE captures the nail-biting fear of nuclear annihilation. Original airdate: 11/13/2000

Title: Split Screen: S1-E6 Projections: Harmony Korine
Description: In this installment of Projections, a series of interviews about filmmaking in New York, John speaks one-on-one with Harmony Korine. Original airdate 10/23/2000

Title: Split Screen: S7-E6 Projections: Ted Hope and James Schamus
Description: Origin story of odd-couple producers Ted Hope and James Schamus, who nurtured many key directors, especially Ang Lee, whose blockbuster CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON opened the week this interview aired. Yet their company Good Machine made squat. Undaunted, Schamus went on to run Focus for a decade and Hope heads film at Amazon Studios. Original air date: 12/11/2000

Title: Constance Towers on THE NAKED KISS
Description: The following video interview with star Constance Towers was conducted in 2011 by film historian and filmmaker Charles Dennis.

Title: HEIFETZ MASTER CLASS SERIES: Volume 5
Description: Directed by Nathan Kroll • 1962 • United States /  / In this renowned series of rare television appearances, the legendary Jascha Heifetz—often referred to as the greatest violinist of the 20th century—leads a historic master class at the University of Southern California, in 1962. Through their mixture of brilliance and informality, these classes offer a glimpse into the technique, process, and personality of a classical virtuoso.

Title: Olivier Assayas on SUMMER HOURS
Description: This interview with director Olivier Assayas was conducted in Paris in January 2010.

Title: Ako
Description: Depicting one night in the life of a young girl and her rowdy friends, Hiroshi Teshigahara’s AKO—also known as WHITE MORNING—was part of an omnibus film titled LA FLEUR DE L’ÂGE OU LES ADOLESCENTES, commissioned by the National Film Board of Canada.

Title: HEIFETZ MASTER CLASS SERIES: Volume 2
Description: Directed by Nathan Kroll • 1962 • United States /  / In this renowned series of rare television appearances, the legendary Jascha Heifetz—often referred to as the greatest violinist of the 20th century—leads a historic master class at the University of Southern California, in 1962. Through their mixture of brilliance and informality, these classes offer a glimpse into the technique, process, and personality of a classical virtuoso.

Title: Split Screen: S3-E6 Projections: David Picker
Description: Woody, Leone, Bertolucci, Schlesinger, Lester and 007. David Picker enabled them all, and many more, as production head in United Artists’ golden era. In this installment of PROJECTIONS a series of interviews about filmmaking in New York, John speaks one on one with his top choice for All Star auteur executive. Original airdate 10/09/2000

Title: Split Screen: S6-E6 Projections: Jonas Mekas
Description: Celebrating Jonas Mekas, a true underground hero who tirelessly championed experimental filmmakers and their “essential cinema” for half a century. A man of many hats, he directed, wrote about and showcased avant garde films, eventually giving them a home at Anthology Film Archives, playing a key role in the 1960s. Original air date 11/06/00

Title: Constance Towers on SHOCK CORRIDOR
Description: The following interview with SHOCK CORRIDOR actor Constance Towers was conducted by film historian and filmmaker Charles Dennis in 2011.

Title: Flunky, Work Hard
Description: Directed by Mikio Naruse • 1931 • Japan /  / Mikio Naruse's earliest available film, Flunky, Work Hard is the rare work by the director not to center around female characters. It is a charming, breezy short concerning an impoverished insurance salesman and his scrappy son, whose fisticuffs with the other boys of their village put his father's livelihood in jeopardy.

Title: Split Screen: S10-E6 Focus Group From Hell
Description: “Video on Vinyl: Then and Now”: P. H. O’Brien and Doug Stone go from NYC to London in search of the legacy of the mysterious inventor John Logie Baird; “Focus Group From Hell”: movie market research as conducted by the hilarious team of Keythe Farley and Brian Flemming. Original airdate 9/25/2000

Title: Split Screen: S7-E2 Reverse Speech
Description: Remember “Paul Is Dead”? David John Oates insists that reverse speech is the key to the truth; Producing Schlock: Tim Steffen talks to producer Sam Sherman who, with Al Adamson, made drive-in classics like SATAN’S SADISTS; From Porn Houses to Art Houses: Mike LaHaie and Howard Gertler explore NYC’s Times Square theaters. Original air date 04/12/1999

Title: Split Screen: S10-E7 Projections: Buck Henry
Description: In a two-year span early in his storied career, Buck Henry cocreated GET SMART and wrote THE GRADUATE, instantly showing the range of his genius. In the final PROJECTIONS, Buck’s observations on the independent model (TO DIE FOR) and cultural appropriation are prescient. Fashionistas should avert their eyes. Original airdate 12/04/2000

Title: Black Panthers
Description: Directed by Agnès Varda • 1968 • United States /  /  /  / Agnès Varda turns her camera on an Oakland demonstration against the imprisonment of activist and Black Panthers cofounder Huey P. Newton. In addition to evincing Varda’s fascination with her adopted surroundings and her empathy, this perceptive short is also a powerful political statement. /  /  /  / Restored by the Cineteca di Bologna at L’Immagine Ritrovata in association with Ciné-Tamaris and The Film Foundation. Restoration funding provided by the Annenberg Foundation, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA) and The Film Foundation.

Title: Split Screen: S6-E4 Guy Maddin Mystifies
Description: Manitoba Tonight: Guy Maddin; How’d You Do That: Archival FX; ’MISSION: IMPOSSIBLE Meets IRONSIDE”: Muscular Dystrophy poster-girl now turned indie action flick director Jenni Gold; Tanya Hamilton looks at several decades of Jamaican film culture. Original air date 10/19/98

Title: Masterclass: Kirsten Johnson
Description: Two fearless documentarians talk candidly at the 2016 Traverse City Film Festival. Michael Moore (FAHRENHEIT 9/11, BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE) and Kirsten Johnson (CAMERAPERSON) consider the moral and emotional challenges of filmmaking.

Title: Michael Haneke on CODE UNKNOWN
Description: This interview with director Michael Haneke was conducted in Windigsteig, Austria, in August 2015.

Title: Split Screen: S5-E2 Todd Haynes’s Goldmine
Description: Haynes and his longtime producer Christine Vachon cuddle up in Cannes; NEA public funding at the local level; an unusual outdoor screening on a hillside; a film festival sponsored by Dockers®. Original airdate 08/31/1998

Title: Making STILL WALKING
Description: In the following 2010 documentary, director Hirokazu Kore-eda and his actors and crew work to create STILL WALKING’s all-encompassing realism—whether by attending to the costumes and lighting or making sure the cooking is just like that of Kore-eda’s mother.

Title: États d’armes
Description: This is an excerpt from “États d’armes,” the third part of Patrick Rotman’s 2002 documentary L’ENNEMI INTIME, which focuses on the tragedies of the French-Algerian War. Here, Rotman combines new interviews with members of the French military involved in the conflict and archival footage to explore the tactics used during the seven-year war.

Title: Split Screen: S5-E3 Animal Talent
Description: The Sweet Sunshine animal Talent Agency; RAT WOMEN: an excerpt from filmmaker Minkie Spiro’s short; what happens to the puppies and dogs left too long at the pound; a visit to Wall Street to try to raise some indie cash. Original airdate 09/07/1998

Title: "Who Is Harry Lime?": Episode 1
Description: At the time of the filming of MR. ARKADIN, Orson Welles was perhaps most well known for his portrayal of Harry Lime in his radio series “The Lives of Harry Lime,” which aired from 1951 to 1952. Taken from Carol Reed’s THE THIRD MAN (1949), Lime became a popular antihero. Elements of MR. ARKADIN can be found in the following program from the series.

Title: Split Screen: S4-E2 The Real Dude Abides
Description: The RV crew hangs with Barry Tubb, an ex rodeo rider, Hollywood actor in Synder, TX; meet “Big” Joe La Creta: actor, wrestler, and sandwich master in Wilmington, MA; is there a “Real” Dude? Producer’s rep Jeff Dowd claims there is. Marina Zenovich talks to the Coen Brothers and the cast. Original airdate 05/18/1998

Title: Split Screen: S1-E2 Linklater and Bogosian in NYC, Duct Town
Description: Richard Linklater and Eric Bogosian at the New York Film Festival with their film SUBURBIA; Linklater’s first film, IT’S IMPOSSIBLE TO LEARN TO PLOW BY READING BOOKS; and a trip to North Reading, MA—Duct Town. Original airdate 03/10/1997

Title: Split Screen: S3-E2 John Wayne’s Hairpiece
Description: SPLIT SCREEN hits the road! Making a film vs. running the NYC Marathon; visiting IFFCON to talk indie film financing; John Wayne’s Hairpiece and other cinema treasures at the Smithsonian Institution in D.C.; filmmakers Doug Stone and P.H. O’Brien and Dan “Grizzly Adams” Haggerty go looking for the America of EASY RIDER. Original airdate 04/13/1998

Title: Peter Cowie on SENSO
Description: In this 2011 visual essay, film scholar Peter Cowie looks at the various themes—pictorial, musical, and political—that director Luchino Visconti wove together to create SENSO.

Title: Split Screen: S5-E4 Lars Von Trier is Dogmatic
Description: Adam and Jo’s stuffed animal take on THE ENGLISH PATIENT; a rare visit with brilliant and phobic director Lars von Trier; Amy Elliott and Lizzy Donius visit volcanologists in Hawaii who film lava; Northwestern Airlines indie movie channel. Original airdate 09/14/1998

Title: Split Screen: S4-E1 Keep Austin Weird
Description: Student activists and local film illuminati protest the shutting down of the UT Union Film program; a profile of the inimitable character actor Lawrence Tierney; shooting Super 8 films at the Austin Cinemaker Co-op; “Documation” - Bob Sabiston and Tommy Pallotta discuss their hybrid of animation and documentary. Original airdate 05/11/1998

Title: Split Screen: S4-E5 Mr. Moviefone’s Message
Description: A visit with Russ Leatherman, Mr. Moviefone himself; meet Al Milgrom the Minneapolis “czar of cinema”; witness Dan Cleveland and his heavy metal band Dark Horse on their ascent up their basement stairs; “Cosmic Society” Amy Elliot and Lizzie Dornius introduce you to a company whose business is filming what can’t be seen by the human eye. Original airdate 06/08/1998

Title: “La mitad invisible”: THE EXECUTIONER
Description: This 2012 episode of the television program “La mitad invisible” explores why THE EXECUTIONER is one of the most beloved films in Spanish cinema.

Title: Split Screen: S5-E6 Projections: Christine Vachon
Description: Quintessential NY producer Christine Vachon has been on the cutting edge with her company Killer Films for over 25 years, supporting numerous breakout first timers and her mainstay Todd Haynes. This edition of Projections was shot not long after BOYS DON’T CRY won Hilary Swank an Oscar. Original airdate 10/16/2000

Title: Split Screen: S8-E1 THE SIMPSONS in Korea
Description: Meet Al Kaplon, umpire turned filmmaker on the set of an X-FILES baseball episode; lady fetish wrestler Deena Zarra shows off some moves and discusses wrestling, and beating, Andy Kaufman; did you know THE SIMPSONS was animated in Seoul, Korea? Come along as Doug Stone and PH O’Brien pay the animators a visit. Original airdate 05/10/1999

Title: Marion Bailey and Amy Raphael on MEANTIME
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2017, writer Amy Raphael interviews actor Marion Bailey about creating the character of Auntie Barbara for MEANTIME.

Title: Dušan Makavejev on Danish Television
Description: Though it toured the European festival circuit, WR: MYSTERIES OF THE ORGANISM was particularly well-received in Scandinavia. In this interview, conducted for Danish television in 1972, filmmaker Christian Braad Thomsen questions director Dušan Makavejev about revolutionary cinema and radical liberation.

Title: Split Screen: S2-E2 Errol Rocks, Gators Chomp
Description: SWINGBLADE: SLING BLADE meets SWINGERS; Pierson travels to Orlando FL, the home of the Florida Film Festival and proposes an “indieworld” theme park; a visit with a self distributing filmmaker from Vermont; filmmaker Errol Morris, accompanied by his bulldog, talks about films, life and art from his Vermont front porch. Original airdate 08/15/1997

Title: Natalia Akerman
Description: In this 2007 interview, an off-camera Chantal Akerman interviews her mother about her films. The producers of the interview originally intended to edit out Akerman’s questions but ultimately decided to keep them in to preserve the candor of the mother-daughter rapport.

Title: Split Screen: S7-E3 Mr. Kinski/Miranda July and Big Miss Moviola
Description: Big Miss Moviola: Miranda July, filmmaker, performance artist, and creator of an inspired distribution concept called Big Miss Moviola; Director David Schmoeller lives to tell the tale of working with Klaus Kinski; A Fangoria Weekend of Horror with Keith Bearden, Doug Stone and P. H. O’Brien. Original air date 04/19/1999

Title: Masterclass: Kelly Reichardt
Description: Over the course of six features, Kelly Reichardt has established herself as one of American cinema’s sharpest observers of place and character. Beautifully attuned to the in-between moments of everyday life, her films such as OLD JOY, WENDY AND LUCY, and MEEK’S CUTOFF portray the journeys and struggles of outsiders and dreamers with an eloquent minimalism in which stillness speaks volumes. Reichardt sat down with critic April Wolfe for this conversation, in which she discusses her working relationship with frequent collaborator Michelle Williams, the challenges and rewards of shooting on location, and how her films achieve a delicate balance of the personal and political.

Title: Split Screen: S6-E2 Billy Wilder’s Shoes
Description: Making Films, Selling Shoes: director Steven Proto enlists the help of Billy Wilder; How’d You Do That?, on working with a deaf actress; Brian Flemming and Keythe Farley ride along with LA’s most famous nonworking actor; an encounter with Seymore Butts: Filmmaker. Original air date 10/05/98

Title: Untied!: Reflections on TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN!
Description: Produced in 2014, this documentary about the making of TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN! features interviews with director Pedro Almodóvar; actors Antonio Banderas, Victoria Abril, Loles León, and Rossy de Palma; producer Agustín Almodóvar; production manager Esther García; and cinematographer José Luis Alcaine.

Title: In the Ring
Description: In this 2013 visual essay, Jacques Tati scholar Stéphane Goudet discusses how the filmmaker’s appreciation for the circus, clowns, and mime humor is reflected in PARADE, and analyzes the film’s various comedic acts.

Title: Troell Behind the Camera
Description: The following short documentary, made in 2007, during the production of EVERLASTING MOMENTS, features interviews with director Jan Troell, cast and crew, and relatives of the real Maria Larsson.

Title: Split Screen: S8-E3 The Fabulous Stains
Description: Hanging out with a hard-core unit of Civil War reenactors down South; the story behind the cult masterpiece LADIES AND GENTLEMEN, THE FABULOUS STAINS; “How to Read a Movie Poster,” the hidden truth revealed! Original airdate 05/24/1999

Title: Dana Polan on THE NAKED CITY
Description: In this 2007 interview, New York University film studies professor Dana Polan, author of “Power and Paranoia: History, Narrative and the American Cinema, 1940–1950,” talks about THE NAKED CITY’s groundbreaking social portrait.

Title: François Truffaut and Claude-Jean Philippe
Description: On several occasions between 1976 and 1982, Claude-Jean Philippe, host of the French radio series “Le cinéma des cinéastes,” invited François Truffaut to talk about his films. In the following segment, first broadcast on June 29, 1980, Truffaut discusses JULES AND JIM almost twenty years after it was made.

Title: François Truffaut on JULES AND JIM
Description: The following interviews with director François Truffaut were conducted at various points throughout his career. In them, he discusses his working methods and the landmark JULES AND JIM.

Title: Split Screen: S2-E1 Lurie Fishes, Gilliam Monkeys
Description: John Lurie on his new series, FISHING WITH JOHN the musical ISLE OF LESBOS; Cyberhostage: two filmmaking cyberterrorists try to get our attention; The Hamster Factor: Terry Gilliams’s first market research screening for TWELVE MONKEYS. Original airdate 06/09/1997

Title: Andrzej Wajda on KANAL
Description: This interview was recorded in December 2003 at Andrzej Wajda’s School of Directing, in Warsaw. In it, Wajda is accompanied by his colleague Janusz “Kuba” Morgenstern and film critic Jerzy Płażewski.

Title: Nestor Almendros on Working with François Truffaut
Description: The following rare interview with cinematographer Nestor Almendros was conducted in Paris in April 1986. It was excerpted in Rainer Gansera’s 1986 documentary ARBEITEN MIT FRANÇOIS TRUFFAUT, produced by WDR, but for this edit, Truffaut expert Robert Fischer constructed the interview in full from the only surviving elements.

Title: Alexander Horwath
Description: The following interview with film historian Alexander Horwath was recorded in Vienna in December 2018.

Title: Introducing Simone Signoret
Description: The following archival programs from 1957, 1970, and 1982 present a multifaceted look at actor Simone Signoret’s life and work, featuring in-depth interviews with the French-cinema icon that touch on her approach to acting, her political engagements, and her career choices.

Title: RED DESERT Dailies 1
Description: These uncut and unfinished dailies from RED DESERT show the precision of Antonioni’s framing and direction of actors. Recent acquisitions of the Cineteca di Bologna, they are presented here as discovered—in both black and white and color, and without audio.

Title: Split Screen: S5-E1 Damon and Norton Play Poker
Description: Matt Damon and Ed Norton head to the World Series of Poker; self-taught stuntman crashing cars from a junkyard; Cronenberg’s CRASH acted by stuffed animals; a screening of RED RIVER for cows at the Fairlee Drive-In and Motel in Vermont. Original airdate 08/24/1998

Title: Split Screen: S3-E3 Grizzly Walks, Orson Talks
Description: “The Illusion and Reality” episode: Dan Myrick visits musician/filmmaker Billy Yeager in a Purple Haze in Hollywood, FL; movie VHS bootleggers in NYC; building a grizzly bear proof suit—Doug Stone and PH O’Brien visit Canadian director Peter Lynch; War of the Words—an infamous Orson Welles commercial recording. Original airdate 04/20/1998

Title: "Who Is Harry Lime?": Episode 2
Description: At the time of the filming of MR. ARKADIN, Orson Welles was perhaps most well known for his portrayal of Harry Lime in his radio series “The Lives of Harry Lime,” which aired from 1951 to 1952. Taken from Carol Reed’s THE THIRD MAN (1949), Lime became a popular antihero. Elements of MR. ARKADIN can be found in the following program from the series.

Title: LA JETÉE Alternate French Audio
Description: Chris Marker created unique English and French narration tracks for LA JETÉE and prefers that the film be experienced in the language the viewer is more familiar with. The different tracks are not direct translations of each other or synched to the images in exactly the same way. The french audio is presented here.

Title: MERRY CHRISTMAS MR. LAWRENCE: On the Screenplay
Description: In this video piece, recorded in London in 2010, screenwriter Paul Mayersberg discusses the development and screenplay of MERRY CHRISTMAS MR. LAWRENCE and the work of director Nagisa Oshima.

Title: Split Screen: S1-E1 Spike Lee, the Real Fargo, Waters Shocks
Description: Spike Lee’s first decade; John and Bob the Mailman; HANG YOUR DOG IN THE WIND (movie about making movies); the real Fargo—Brainerd, MN; and the Gruesome Twosome: an encounter with John Waters and Herschell Gordon Lewis. Original airdate 03/10/1997

Title: Split Screen: S9-E5 Cinemaniac
Description: If you’ve got a building to implode, call Controlled Demolition: Amy Elliott takes us there; Cinemaniac: Stephen Kijak profiles Jack Angstreich, a true film buff, who saw 1,000 films in eight months; Fight School: which comes first, the acting or the action? P. H. O’Brien finds the answer in his own backyard. Original airdate 10/11/99

Title: Trade Secrets: Nicolas Roeg and Jeremy Thomas
Description: Director Nicolas Roeg and producer Jeremy Thomas discuss the making of BAD TIMING in this rare on-camera interview, conducted in London, in 2004.

Title: Dudley Andrew on THE LIFE OF OHARU: Commentary
Description: Recorded in 2013, this commentary by film scholar Dudley Andrew plays over the first 28 minutes of THE LIFE OF OHARU.

Title: Split Screen: S10-E2 Field of Feuds
Description: Meet the feuding fields where FIELD OF DREAMS was shot; Janet Pierson profiles the Moth, the lively monthly gathering for storytelling; “Ocularis”: Randi Barros and Kerry Reardon take us to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where the residents understand that independence is also important in showing work, not just making it. Original airdate 10/25/1999

Title: La Jetée
Description: Directed by Chris Marker • 1963 • France /  / Chris Marker, filmmaker, poet, novelist, photographer, editor, and now videographer and digital multimedia artist, has been challenging moviegoers, philosophers, and himself for years with his complex queries about time, memory, and the rapid advancement of life on this planet. Marker's LA JETÉE is one of the most influential, radical science-fiction films ever made, a tale of time travel told in still images.

Title: Split Screen: S1-E5 Breakthrough Screenwriting
Description: Brian Flemming and Keythe Farley take a weekend “blockbuster” screenwriting course and make a film; Mary Harron and Katherine Dieckmann, both nine months pregnant, discuss their altered state with Guinevere Turner. Original airdate 06/02/1997

Title: Forza Bastia
Description: Directed by Jacques Tati and Sophie Tatischeff • 1978 • France /  / Jacques Tati directed this twenty-seven minute short, documenting a Dutch-French soccer match, in 1978. He never finished editing it, but his daughter Sophie Tatischeff discovered the footage and completed the film for release in 2000.

Title: Jan Nowak-Jeziorański
Description: During World War II, Jan Nowak-Jeziorański was a courier for Poland’s underground Home Army. Afterward, he served as director of the Polish-American Congress and consultant to the U.S. National Security Council. Director Andrzej Wajda conducted this, the last recorded interview with Nowak-Jeziorański, in 2004, the year before his death.

Title: Split Screen: S6-E3 Kuchar Kuts Loose
Description: George Kuchar, beloved innovator, underground filmmaker, and San Francisco film teacher; KIDS: promiscuous stuffed animals in NYC; 15 budding auteurs in Austin produce one feature together; Indie Dogs with Marina Zenovich; Artmark—activism, film, and videotape. Original airdate 10/12/98

Title: An Eastern Westerner
Description: Directed by Hal Roach • 1920 • United States /  / In this two-reeler from 1920, a fast and furious parody of western films, Harold Lloyd stars as an East Coast boy shipped off to a ranch; Mildred Davis, who would later become Lloyd's wife, costars. It is presented here with a new score composed and conducted by Carl Davis.

Title: Production History: Olivier Curchod
Description: Film scholar Olivier Curchod delves into the complicated production history of THE RULES OF THE GAME, in this 2003 piece by N. T. Binh.

Title: Split Screen: S4-E4 Selective Service in Aspen
Description: The Aspen Shortsfest; SELECTIVE SERVICE SYSTEM, a brilliant short, made when the draft was mandatory and anti-war protests were in full force; follow four ebullient NYC teens, who just happen to be working actresses and indie film stars on the rise; meet Todd Thaler, one of independent film’s busiest casting directors. Original airdate 06/01/1998

Title: The Beatles: The Road to A Hard Day's Night
I AM CURIOUS—BLUE: Director’s Diary
Description: In February of 2002, director Vilgot Sjoman recorded comments on selected scenes from I AM CURIOUS—BLUE. His commentary is based on his book “I Was Curious: Diary of the Making of a Film,” published by Grove Press in 1968.

Title: Split Screen: S10-E5 Woodworking with Bill
Description: “Multiplex II—The Manager”: welcome back to the Museum Place Cinemas; woodworking with William H. Macy in New York City; “Bikers R People 2”: Amy Elliott turns the camera on biker-chick documentarian Barbara Bustillos-Cogswell; behind the curtain of a documentary about a migrant worker’s wedding, LA BODA. Original airdate 9/18/2000

Title: Split Screen: S1-E3 Kevin and CRUMB at the Quick Stop
Description: Kevin Smith and John cohost from New Jersey; a visit with CRUMB director Terry Zwigoff at home; the found video DIRECTION MAN; Chris Smith and MAKING NORTHWESTERN with Mark Borchardt. Original airdate 3/17/1997

Title: Split Screen: S2-E4 Meet the Skolnicks, Sisters
Description: Cinemoids: a portrait of the film obsessed family at Long Island’s Cinema Arts Centre; Donnie Bosnia: the life story of two adventurers in eastern Europe; Sisters in Cinema: special preview of Yvonne Welborn feature documentary on black women in film, with Julie Dash and Darnell Martin. Original airdate 08/15/1997

Title: Olympic Spirit
Description: Directed by Drummond Challis and Tony Maylam • 1980 • United Kingdom /  / For their short film on the XIII Olympic Winter Games Lake Placid 1980, directors Drummond Challis and Tony Maylam assumed the challenge of making a documentary without any offscreen commentary, relying on music to sustain the flow of images.

Title: Split Screen: S2-E6 Projections: Wes Anderson
Description: In this installment of Projections, a series of interviews about filmmaking in New York, John speaks one-on-one with director Wes Anderson. Original airdate 10/02/2000

Title: Split Screen: S4-E6 Projections: David O. Russell
Description: If these Projections interviews focus on New York filmmaking, why is David O. Russell sitting poolside in LA? After a quintessential indie debut, SPANKING THE MONKEY, and a bigger Miramax follow-up, FLIRTING WITH DISASTER, he’d just made a provocative third feature THREE KINGS for a Hollywood studio. Which way would he go? Original airdate 11/20/2000

Title: Abbas Kiarostami Interview
Description: In this 2009 video interview, shot in Marrakech while Abbas Kiarostami was president of the Marrakech Film Festival jury, the director discusses CLOSE-UP and the impact it had on his career.

Title: Filming Haneke
Description: This documentary from 2000 details the production of CODE UNKNOWN and features interviews with cast and crew, including director Michael Haneke, producer Marin Karmitz, and actor Juliette Binoche.

Title: Chaplin Today: MODERN TIMES
Description: This documentary, produced by Philippe Truffault in 2003, places MODERN TIMES in historical context and includes the personal observations of filmmakers Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne.

Title: Split Screen: S7-E4 Thanksgiving Is Not for Turkeys
Description: Young Turkeys: see what it takes to bring that big bird to a table near you; Hair Today, Film Tomorrow: Mike LaHaie visits the world-renowned Ann Arbor Film Festival; Amy Elliott and Elizabeth Donius bring us the secrets of stunt and film swordsmanship from theatrical combat organization Ring of Steel. Original air date 04/26/1999

Title: Rüdiger Vogler, Yella Rottländer, and Lisa Kreuzer on ALICE IN THE CITIES
Description: This 2016 program features interviews with actors Rüdiger Vogler, Yella Rottländer, and Lisa Kreuzer.

Title: “Marcel Pagnol: Morceaux choisis”: Episode 4
Description: “Marcel Pagnol: Morceaux choisis” is a six-part documentary series on the life and work of the writer and filmmaker that was produced for French television in 1973 and features interview footage of Pagnol. Presented here is a 30-minute excerpt from episode 4, which relates directly to THE MARSEILLE TRILOGY.

Title: Pigeons in the Square
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1982 • France /  /  /  / An enthusiastic man sits on a park bench and explains the behaviors and rituals of pigeons.

Title: High and Dizzy
Description: Directed by Hal Roach • 1920 • United States /  / In this silent film, a young man gets drunk by accident then winds up on a narrow ledge high above the street.

Title: Split Screen: S3-E4 Carl Franklin Breaks it Down
Description: Self-distributing a documentary about talking to elementary school kids about gay issues; Filming in Charleston, SC, from Civil War pictures to slavery era epics; a visit with director Carl Franklin (ONE FALSE MOVE); Jacob Young’s ongoing project about broken down cars on the side of the road in the Deep South. Original airdate 04/27/1998

Title: Bruno Ganz on THE AMERICAN FRIEND
Description: The following interview with actor Bruno Ganz was conducted in Zurich in September 2015.

Title: Alekan la Lumière
Description: In these excerpts from the 1985 documentary ALEKAN LA LUMIÈRE, legendary director of photography Henri Alekan discusses his cinematographic techniques with director Wim Wenders. The documentary first aired on French television on August 4, 1988, and was directed by Michel Dumoulin.

Title: Split Screen: S10-E1 Jesus Is in the Mailbox/Atom Egoyan
Description: “Manitoba Tonight” with the brilliant filmmaker Atom Egoyan; “Jesus Video Project”: In 1998, Dr. Bob Cosby sent out 1.8 million copies of a video called “Jesus” to every resident in Alabama; Amy Elliott drives deep into the delta to explore authentic moving images of the Deep South’s historical past. Original airdate 10/11/1999

Title: Picturewise
Description: This piece was written and produced by critic and filmmaker David Cairns in 2014. Narrated by actor Rita Tushingham, it looks at the influences on and impact of the early work of director Richard Lester.

Title: Malle’s Fire Within
Description: In these interviews, conducted in 2008, actor Alexandra Stewart and filmmakers Philippe Collin and Volker Schlöndorff discuss the making of THE FIRE WITHIN.

Title: Richard Reeves on the Kennedy Administration
Description: Often looked back on through rose-tinted glasses, the Kennedy administration was in fact a tumultuous time, full of missteps and crises. In this December 2015 interview, historian Richard Reeves, author of “President Kennedy: Profile of Power,” discusses John F. Kennedy’s primary campaign and the inner workings of his White House.

Title: Serialized Success
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2013, Asian-film critic Tony Rayns offers his thoughts on the popularity of the ZATOICHI series, its main character, and some of the key talents involved in making it.

Title: Seijun Suzuki, Takeo Kimura, and Tadao Sato
Description: Director Seijun Suzuki, production designer Takeo Kimura, and film critic Tadao Sato share their lasting impressions of STORY OF A PROSTITUTE in this video presentation, filmed in 2005.

Title: “Cinéastes de notre temps”: CASQUE D’OR
Description: The following excerpts from a 1967 episode of “Cinéastes de notre temps” feature interviews with many of director Jacques Becker’s collaborators and admirers, including Simone Signoret, Claude Dauphin, François Truffaut, and Marguerite Renoir. In the first clip, we learn about Becker’s beginnings as an actor and filmmaker. In the second, the actors recall the shooting of CASQUE D’OR.

Title: François Thomas on MURIEL, OR THE TIME OF RETURN
Description: This interview with film scholar François Thomas was conducted in Paris in April 2016.

Title: Outtakes
Description: The following outtakes from CARNIVAL OF SOULS are presented with composer Gene Moore’s original organ score.

Title: BREATHLESS: Archival Interviews
Description: Presented here are excerpts from interviews with director Jean-Luc Godard, actors Jean-Paul Belmondo and Jean Seberg, and filmmaker Jean-Pierre Melville, recorded for French television between 1960 and 1964.

Title: Screen Director’s Playhouse
Description: This radio adaptation of STAGECOACH, originally broadcast on January 9, 1949, stars John Wayne and Claire Trevor, reprising their film roles.

Title: Chaplin Today: MONSIEUR VERDOUX
Description: This documentary, directed by Bernard Eisenschitz in 2003, looks at the political and personal turmoil in Charlie Chaplin’s life at the time of MONSIEUR VERDOUX, along with his bold direction of the film, and features observations by filmmaker Claude Chabrol and actor Norman Lloyd.

Title: Gold Town Documentary by Lisle Herbert
Description: Before it became Alaska’s capital, Juneau was the world’s biggest gold town. This documentary by filmmaker and Gold Town Nickelodeon founder Lisle Hebert explores the history of Juneau through dramatic reenactments and visuals of the city’s lush landscapes.

Title: Jean-Pierre Gorin, 2004
Description: The following interview with filmmaker Jean-Pierre Gorin regarding his work in film was recorded in New York City in 2004.

Title: Theodor Pištěk on MARKETA LAZAROVÁ
Description: The following interview with MARKETA LAZAROVÁ’s costume designer, Theodor Pištěk, was conducted in Prague in 2013.

Title: David Forgacs and Karen Pinkus on LE AMICHE
Description: In this interview, recorded in New York in 2016, scholars David Forgacs and Karen Pinkus discuss LE AMICHE’s themes, visual style, and adaptation from Cesare Pavese’s novel “Tra donne sole.”

Title: Split Screen: S9-E4 Hangin’ with HOW’S YOUR NEWS?
Description: Inside the Eye of SCORPIO RISING: Jon Ausbrooks and Lee Daniel make a mind-blowing, information-packed homage to the master Kenneth Anger; Hangin’ With HOW’S YOUR NEWS?: P. H. O’Brien and Doug Stone paid a visit to Camp Jabberwocky to meet with the correspondents and the man behind the team, filmmaker Arthur Bradford. Original airdate 09/27/99

Title: Split Screen: S2-E3 Buscemi and Turturro on the Block
Description: Mr. Pink and Barton Fink: Steve Buscemi and John Turturro on a stoop in Brooklyn; Irwin Young shows us how things work at his venerable film lab DuArt; Taranteenties: PH O’Brien and Doug Stone scope out the Andover Youth Services Homegrown Film Festival introducing us to the next generation. Original airdate 08/15/1997

Title: Split Screen: S7-E5 Tommy Lee Meets Bolexbrothers
Description: Bolexbrothers is an animation studio in Bristol, England, who’ve created a series of indescribably amazing films; Bill Judkins meets SYRACUSE NEW TIMES film critic Bill DeLapp; Seth Sells: the man who brought us the Pam Anderson and Tommy Lee sex tape; “Hamster,” a wonderful, hilarious romp inspired by a new camera. Original air date 05/03/1999

Title: THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK: Scott Smith Interview
Description: During preproduction on THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK, director Robert Epstein recorded draft interviews with more than forty people before deciding on the eight subjects seen in the film. Presented here are excerpts from an interview with Milk’s longtime boyfriend Scott Smith, which was not included in the film.

Title: Chaplin Today: THE GOLD RUSH
Description: This documentary, directed by Serge Le Péron in 2002, offers a thorough account of the making of THE GOLD RUSH and features interviews with actor Georgia Hale and Hollywood legend Mary Pickford, as well as personal observations by filmmaker Idrissa Ouédraogo.

Title: BURROUGHS: THE MOVIE New York Film Festival Premiere
Description: The following excerpts are from a Q&A that followed the premiere of BURROUGHS: THE MOVIE at the New York Film Festival in 2014.

Title: Screening at the Majestic
Description: This program features interviews with several members of BEAUTY AND THE BEAST’s cast and crew at a special screening of the film’s 1995 restoration.

Title: Split Screen: S6-E1 From Homicide to Ho Chi Minh
Description: Movie Saves Town: an indie effort revitalizes Holland, MI; Doug Stone visits Tony Bui, director of THREE SEASONS, and his Vietnamese cast; Homicide is Good: the indie film landscape in Baltimore; SE7EN: suspense, murder, stuffed animals! Original air date 09/29/98

Title: Olivier Assayas on L’AVVENTURA
Description: The following piece, produced by Éditions Montparnasse in 2004 and reedited by Criterion, features an analysis in three parts by filmmaker Olivier Assayas.

Title: Split Screen: S1-E4 Sundance on the Hudson
Description: Bob the Mailman in L.A.; insights from filmmakers at the Cold Spring Film Workshop; Marina Zenovich explores the January film alternatives in Park City, UT, home of the Sun-, Slam-, and Slumdance Festivals. Original airdate 3/24/1997

Title: Sydney Chaplin’s Footage from THE GREAT DICTATOR
Description: While Charlie Chaplin was directing and acting in THE GREAT DICTATOR, his half-brother, Sydney, was on set documenting the production in full color. His silent footage, shot on 16 mm Kodachrome film, is presented here in its entirety.

Title: Chaplin Today: LIMELIGHT
Description: This program from 2002, directed by Edgardo Cozarinsky, features interviews with filmmaker Bernardo Bertolucci and two of LIMELIGHT’s actors, Claire Bloom and Sydney Chaplin, Charlie Chaplin’s son.

Title: Adriano Aprà and Carlo di Carlo on LA NOTTE
Description: In this 2012 interview program, film critic Adriano Aprà and film historian Carlo di Carlo situate LA NOTTE within director Michelangelo Antonioni’s oeuvre and examine the film’s visual style.

Title: Chaplin Today: CITY LIGHTS
Description: This 27-minute documentary from 2003, directed by Serge Bromberg, examines CITY LIGHTS as a high point of Charlie Chaplin’s artistry and features observations by film producer and Aardman Animations cofounder Peter Lord.

Title: Gary Farmer on DEAD MAN
Description: The following is a 2017 interview with DEAD MAN actor Gary Farmer.

Title: John Nathan and Donald Richie on Yukio Mishima
Description: Translator John Nathan and critic Donald Richie knew Yukio Mishima. Nathan worked closely with him on the translation of “The Sailor Who Fell from Grace with the Sea” and later wrote a biography of him. Richie met Mishima on the writer’s first visit to New York in 1952. In this 2008 piece, they discuss the man and his work.

Title: Denitza Bantcheva on PURPLE NOON
Description: This interview with film historian and author Denitza Bantcheva was conducted at the Chez Justine Café in Paris in August 2012.

Title: Joseph McBride on CHIMES AT MIDNIGHT
Description: In this May 2016 interview, Joseph McBride, author of “What Ever Happened to Orson Welles?,” discusses Welles’s late career and approach to adapting Shakespeare.

Title: Split Screen: S8-E4 Waiting for STAR WARS
Description: Meet Robert Cartagena, a.k.a. Red Leader, for a look at the serious business of waiting in line for the new STAR WARS; experts weigh in on the realism of FBI procedures in the movies; bull rider Barry Tubb heads out west to the Taos Talking Pictures Fest where first prize is a $5,000 land grant. Original airdate 05/31/1999

Title: “Ciné regards”: Jacques Tati, 1978
Description: In this 1978 episode of the French television show “Ciné regards,” Jacques Tati watches clips from his Monsieur Hulot films and talks about his role as both filmmaker and performer.

Title: Polanski and Skolimowski on KNIFE IN THE WATER
Drew Associates at the Museum of Tolerance
Description: In October 1998, at New York’s Museum of Tolerance, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences premiered restorations of Drew Associates’ Kennedy films. In attendance from Drew Associates were Robert Drew, Richard Leacock, D. A. Pennebaker, and Albert Maysles. This 2016 documentary was drawn from footage of the event.

Title: Children of the Fields
Description: Robert M. Young's documentary short CHILDREN OF THE FIELDS, produced for the Xerox Corporation's television series Come Over to My House in 1973, became a key source of research for his first feature film, ¡ALAMBRISTA!.

Title: Harrod Blank and Leon Russell, 2015
Description: Director Les Blank’s son Harrod Blank was instrumental in helping A POEM IS A NAKED PERSON see the light of day, after it had gone largely unseen for decades. In this conversation, Blank sits down with the film’s subject, musician Leon Russell, in Nashville to talk about POEM’s long journey, from its production in the early 1970s to its release in 2015.

Title: The Voice Thief
Description: Directed by Adan Jodorowsky • 2013 • United States, France, Chile /  / A man goes on a surreal odyssey through Miami's psychedelic underworld in search of his wife's missing voice.

Title: Making FESTIVAL
Description: The following program features interviews with director Murray Lerner, associate editor Alan Heim, and assistant editor Gordon Quinn. It was produced in 2017.

Title: The Autopsy
Description: This program was made in 2004 and features director Brian De Palma, producer Edward R. Pressman, editor Paul Hirsch, and actors Charles Durning and Bill Finley.

Title: A Girl's Own Story
Description: Directed by Jane Campion • 1986 • Australia /  / This early short from director Jane Campion concerns a group of teenage girls in the 1960s.

Title: Painting with Light
Description: This piece about renowned cinematographer Jack Cardiff’s Oscar-winning work on Black Narcissus was made in 2000 by Craig McCall.

Title: PRIMARY: The Richard Leacock Version
Description: The hour-long PRIMARY was ahead of its time, and no broadcaster would touch it. After the possibility of the film’s being aired at a shorter length was raised, Robert Drew Associates team member Richard Leacock edited it down to a half hour overnight. Leacock and Drew were pleased with this new cut; nevertheless, it was not broadcast.

Title: Alfred Hitchcock and François Truffaut
Description: In these audio excerpts from a 1962 interview, director Alfred Hitchcock reflects on THE LODGER and British cinema in general with filmmaker François Truffaut. Helen G. Scott is the translator.

Title: The Stickleback's Egg
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1925 • France /  / Jean Painlevé made numerous research films, strictly with the scientific and university communities in mind. THE STICKLEBACK'S EGG, an educational short about fish egg fertilization, is presented here in its original silent version.

Title: David Schwartz and Michael Fassbender on FISH TANK
Description: The following is audio from a conversation between David Schwartz, chief curator at Museum of the Moving Image, and actor Michael Fassbender, which took place in Queens on January 6, 2010, as part of the museum's Pinewood Dialogues series.

Title: Women in Love
Description: DESERT HEARTS depended on the connection between its two lead actors, Patricia Charbonneau and Helen Shaver, and on their trust in director Donna Deitch. In the following program, made in New York in 2017, the actors and the director discuss the making of the film, the close bond they formed, and the ways it changed their lives.

Title: Three Examples of Myself as a Queen
Description: Directed by Anna Biller • 1994 • United States /  /  /  / Anna Biller casts herself as a melancholic Arabian ruler, a queen bee presiding over a cotton-candy pink hive, and a 1960s teenybopper princess in this retro-fantastic feminist anthem.

Title: François Thomas on HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR
Description: The following interview with film scholar François Thomas, author of “L’atelier d’Alain Resnais,” was conducted in Paris in March 2015.

Title: Split Screen: S9-E3 Scorsese, Imperioli, and Ventimiglia
Description: Waiting for Marty: Scorsese accepts an award at the Wexner Center in Ohio; catching up with Michael Imperioli and John Ventimiglia during a break from THE SOPRANOS; CASABLANCA: New and Improved: Brian Flemming and marketing wizard Keythe Farley market test CASABLANCA. Original airdate 09/20/99

Title: Split Screen: S3-E5 THE TIN DRUM: Banned in OK
Description: Reason to Believe” booking a film on college campuses with secret agent: Tedd Stuart; a visit with Bart Weiss, director of the Dallas Video Festival; surveillance video turned into experimental films; THE TIN DRUM— Tim DePaepe investigates how this Academy Award winning film was banned in Oklahoma City, OK. Original airdate 05/04/1998

Title: Jill Drew and D. A. Pennebaker
Description: The following conversation between Drew Associates general manager Jill Drew and famed documentarian D. A. Pennebaker was recorded at Pennebaker’s offices in New York in December 2015. The two discuss the early days of Direct Cinema, working for Robert Drew, and the joys and challenges of filming the president of the United States.

Title: Christopher Nolan on FOLLOWING
Description: This interview with writer-director Christopher Nolan was conducted in Los Angeles in December 2010.

Title: Pedro Almodóvar and Antonio Banderas
Description: This conversation between TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN! director Pedro Almodóvar and actor Antonio Banderas was recorded in 2003.

Title: Everything Begins and Ends
Description: This documentary, produced in 2014, features interviews with PICNIC AT HANGING ROCK producers Hal and Jim McElroy, executive producer Patricia Lovell, cinematographer Russell Boyd, and actors Helen Morse and Anne Louise Lambert. The interviews were conducted in 2003.

Title: Laloux sauvage
Description: This 2009 documentary by Florence Dauman of Argos Films features an extensive interview with FANTASTIC PLANET director René Laloux.

Title: The Life of Sayat-Nova
Description: Aired March 6, 1977, on the TF1 program “Foi et traditions des chrétiens orientaux,” and directed by Carlos de los Llanos, this program details the life of Armenian poet Sayat-Nova, the inspiration for the film THE COLOR OF POMEGRANATES.

Title: Sharon Malone and Eric Holder
Description: Not just a big moment in JFK’s presidency, the University of Alabama’s integration was a landmark in the U.S. civil rights struggle. In this January 2016 conversation, Sharon Malone—sister of Vivian Malone, one of the two students in CRISIS—and her husband, former attorney general Eric Holder, discuss the film and Vivian’s place in history.

Title: Christo’s Valley Curtain
Director: Albert Maysles, David Maysles, and Ellen Giffard
Description: Directed by Albert Maysles, David Maysles, and Ellen Giffard • 1974 • United States /  / Nominated for an Academy Award, CHRISTO'S VALLEY CURTAIN celebrates the Bulgarian-born artist's dramatic hanging of a huge orange curtain between two Colorado mountains. Since the late 1950's, Christo's large-scale temporary works of art have helped change our perception of art and society.

Title: A Visit from the Incubus
Description: Directed by Anna Biller • 2001 • United States /  /  /  / Lucy (Anna Biller), a young Victorian woman in the Old West, is being tormented by nightly visits from an incubus (a horrible demon who has sexual intercourse with sleeping women). Her friend Madeleine (Natalia Schroeder) tries to console her, but is unable to help. A fallen woman, Lucy gets a job singing at the local saloon. However, the incubus (Jared Sanford) has followed her there; and things take an unexpected turn as Lucy and the incubus, amid the rowdy cowboys and saucy can-can girls, have their final showdown. With beautiful period costumes and sets by director Anna Biller that emulate 1950s Technicolor films, plus big hairdos, weird musical numbers, and plenty of great character actors, this horror-western-musical has all of the elements of a cult classic.

Title: Outtakes: William Westmoreland
Description: William Westmoreland became the commander of United States forces in Vietnam in 1964. Named “Time” magazine’s Man of the Year in 1965, he came to be seen as the symbol for an unpopular war. In these excerpts from his HEARTS AND MINDS interview, he discusses civilian casualties in war, military strategy and performance, and the 1968 My Lai massacre.

Title: Jan Němec
Description: In the following segment from a 2009 interview, director Jan Němec discusses attending Famu Film School in Prague and making DIAMONDS OF THE NIGHT.

Title: Chieko Schrader on MISHIMA: A LIFE IN FOUR CHAPTERS
Description: Working closely with her husband, Leonard Schrader, and her brother-in-law Paul Schrader, Chieko Schrader wrote the Japanese-language screenplay for MISHIMA: A LIFE IN FOUR CHAPTERS. She was also an essential on-set link, translating instructions to actors and crew. This audio interview was recorded in Los Angeles in 2008 by David Weisman.

Title: ERASERHEAD Crew Interviews
Description: These interviews with ERASERHEAD director's assistant Catherine Coulson, actors Charlotte Stewart and Judith Anna Roberts, and cinematographer Frederick Elmes were conducted in 2014.

Title: Eric Rentschler on THE MERCHANT OF FOUR SEASONS
Description: The following interview with Eric Rentschler, a film historian and the Arthur Kingsley Porter Professor of Germanic Languages and Literature at Harvard University, was conducted in Cambridge, Massachusetts, in February 2015.

Title: Du côté de la côte
Description: Directed by Agnès Varda • 1958 • France /  /  /  / As if you need any more reasons to visit the beautiful south of France, Agnès Varda celebrates the splendor of this area in a short documentary funded by the French Tourism Office. In this cheeky little film, Varda highlights the importance of tourism to the region with shots of sunbathers soaking in rays and the attractions that will occupy visitors of all ages.

Title: Tempo International: Tativille
Description: In this 1967 episode of the British television program “Tempo International,” filmmaker Mike Hodges interviews director Jacques Tati on the set of PLAYTIME.

Title: The Making of SUMMER HOURS
Description: This half-hour 2008 documentary features interviews with director Olivier Assayas and actors Charles Berling and Juliette Binoche, and shows the cast and crew at work on SUMMER HOURS.

Title: Saltair: Return of the Salt Queen
Description: Veteran broadcaster Ed Yeates made a documentary about the Saltair resort for Salt Lake City’s KCPX-TV in 1966, adapting it from a radio version he’d made while a college student. The excerpts shown here feature the dilapidated resort around the time CARNIVAL OF SOULS was shot there. Note that the picture and sound quality are the best available.

Title: James Sanders on THE NAKED CITY
Description: Architect James Sanders is the author of “Celluloid Skyline” and cowriter of Ric Burns’s PBS documentary series “New York.” In this 2007 program he discusses THE NAKED CITY’s depiction of New York in the 1940s.

Title: DONT LOOK BACK: Snapshots from the Tour
Description: The following 25 minutes of never-before-seen outtakes from DONT LOOK BACK offer further glimpses into Bob Dylan’s historic 1965 tour.

Title: Wasp
Description: Directed by Andrea Arnold • 2003 • United Kingdom /  / Andrea Arnold's Oscar winning short film details the struggles of a young mother who feels that her children are preventing her from rekindling an old relationship.

Title: Split Screen: S10-E4 Animating WAKING LIFE
Description: Hanging out with Richard Linklater and Tommy Pallotta while making the uniquely animated feature WAKING LIFE; The Alloy Orchestra at the Maui Film Festival; “Multiplex 1—The Projectionist”: Welcome to the Museum Place Cinemas, where movies are $1 at all times. Original airdate 09/11/2000

Title: Jean-Pierre Berthomé and Jacquline Moreau
Description: In this conversation, recorded in 2013, film scholar Jean-Pierre Berthomé talks to THE YOUNG GIRLS OF ROCHEFORT costume designer Jacqueline Moreau, the wife of production designer Bernard Evein, about her and her husband’s decades-long collaboration with director Jacques Demy.

Title: Table Scraps
Description: In this 2013 video essay on BABETTE’S FEAST, filmmaker Michael Almereyda charts the path from Isak Dinesen’s story to Gabriel Axel’s film, taking detours along the way into art history, philosophy, and the author’s life in Africa. Actor Lori Singer narrates.

Title: William J. Clinton Foundation Panel, 2011
Description: In 2011, the William J. Clinton Foundation hosted a discussion in Arkansas to mark the twentieth anniversary of Clinton’s candidacy for president. In the following excerpts from that event, veterans of the campaign discuss the trials of New Hampshire, and an unexpected audience member—President Clinton—takes the mike to share his memories.

Title: Sound, Image and EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF
Description: In the following 2015 video essay, film historian Colin MacCabe explores the way filmmaker Jean-Luc Godard plays with sound and image in EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF.

Title: Archival Interviews
Description: The following are excerpted from French television programs. “Provence actualités” (February 26, 1966) features a short newsreel taken on the set of LE DEUXIÈME SOUFFLE. “Cinéma” (July 30, 1966) features interviews by François Chalais with director Jean-Pierre Melville and actor Lino Ventura.

Title: Guillermo del Toro in Conversation
Description: The Oscar-winning director of THE SHAPE OF WATER on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: HEIFETZ MASTER CLASS SERIES: Volume 7
Description: Directed by Nathan Kroll • 1962 • United States /  / In this renowned series of rare television appearances, the legendary Jascha Heifetz—often referred to as the greatest violinist of the 20th century—leads a historic master class at the University of Southern California, in 1962. Through their mixture of brilliance and informality, these classes offer a glimpse into the technique, process, and personality of a classical virtuoso.

Title: Christian Petzold and Nina Hoss on PHOENIX
Description: One of the greatest director-actor pairs in contemporary cinema, Christian Petzold and his leading lady, Nina Hoss, have work on six films together since 2001. In this conversation, recorded in Berlin in 2016, the two delve into their working process, the evolution of their collaboration, and the themes of their films together.

Title: NIGHT ON EARTH Commentary: Helsinki
Description: Recorded in 2007, this audio commentary features director of photography Frederick Elmes and location sound mixer Drew Kunin.

Title: Human Voice
Description: Directed by Edoardo Ponti • 2014 • Italy /  / This short film from 2014 stars Sophia Loren and was inspired by Jean Cocteau's 1930 play La voix humaine. It was directed by Edoardo Ponti, the son of Loren and producer Carlo Ponti.

Title: Bumping into Broadway
Description: Directed by Hal Roach • 1919 • United States /  / This 1919 short is the only Harold Lloyd title other than Speedy set in New York City, although it was filmed entirely in Los Angeles. BUMPING INTO BROADWAY was also the first two-reeler to star Lloyd's "Glasses Character." This newly restored master features a 2004 score by Robert Israel.

Title: Adam Gopnik in Conversation
Description: The author of “At the Strangers’ Gate” on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: David Brendel on Screenwriter Ben Hecht
Description: Writer Ben Hecht’s art made extensive use of his life, and the work he did in Hollywood drew on his experiences growing up in Al Capone–era Chicago and working in newsrooms to capture the worlds of gangsters, reporters, and spies. In this 2016 program, Hecht expert David Brendel explores the life and impact of one of cinema's most important voices.

Title: Art in Action
Description: In this 2018 program, Grady Hendrix, author and cofounder of the New York Asian Film Festival, discusses director King Hu’s aesthetic sensibility via analysis of a scene from DRAGON INN.

Title: The Screen Guild Theater: To Be or Not to Be
Description: This condensed adaptation of TO BE OR NOT TO BE, originally broadcast on “The Screen Guild Theater” on January 18, 1943, stars real-life husband and wife William Powell and Diana Lewis as Joseph and Maria Tura. German actor Sig Ruman reprises his role as Colonel Ehrhardt from the film.

Title: Commedia all'italiana: Germi Style
Description: Screenwriters Luciano Vincenzoni and Furio Scarpelli and film scholar Mario Sesti recall SEDUCED AND ABANDONED director Pietro Germi and the great tradition of commedia all’italiana in this compilation of interviews, recorded in Rome in 2006.

Title: Ophuls’s Collaborators: Alain Jessua
Description: This interview with THE EARRINGS OF MADAME DE . . . assistant director Alain Jessua was conducted by Robert Fischer in Paris in 2005.

Title: Critical Mass
Description: Directed by Hollis Frampton • 1971 • United States /  / This film was Hollis Frampton's first attempt at both working with actors and using sync sound. The performers, two students from the State University of New York at Binghamton, were given an outline of a situation from which to improvise.

Title: DEAD MAN: Neil Young
Description: Presented here is footage shot by director Jim Jarmusch that shows Neil Young composing the score for DEAD MAN.

Title: And You Act Like One Too
Description: Directed by Susan Seidelman • 1976 • United States /  /  /  / This short was made by SMITHEREENS director Susan Seidelman when she was a film student at New York University in 1976.

Title: Number, Please?
Description: Directed by Hal Roach and Fred Newmeyer • 1920 • United States /  / A young, heartbroken man goes to the amusement park, only to see the girl he lost with a new man.

Title: The Frontier Experience
Description: In 1975, Barbara Loden directed and starred in this half-hour educational film about a pioneer woman struggling to survive with her family on the Kansas Prairie.

Title: David Bordwell and Kristin Thompson on THE ONLY SON
Description: This interview with film scholars David Bordwell and Kristin Thompson was conducted exclusively in March 2010 in Madison, Wisconsin.

Title: Lagniappe
Description: The following short film features twenty-five minutes of additional footage shot during the filming of ALWAYS FOR PLEASURE and was compiled by Les Blank and Maureen Gosling.

Title: Christopher Faulkner on LA CHIENNE
Description: In this new interview, Jean Renoir scholar Christopher Faulkner discusses the filmmaker’s transition from silent films to talkies, his stylistic evolution, and the importance of LA CHIENNE within his career. It was recorded in Ottawa in February 2016.

Title: James Quandt Video Essay
Description: The following video essay about THE FACE OF ANOTHER, by James Quandt of the Cinematheque Ontario, was recorded in 2007.

Title: Hollywood Propaganda and World War II
Description: FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT was released a year before the U.S. entered World War II. The ending of the film was added at the last minute to bolster anti-isolationist sentiment among American viewers. In this 2013 piece, writer Mark Harris discusses the important role this and other Hollywood propaganda films played during the war.

Title: Barry Jenkins in Conversation
Description: The director of MOONLIGHT on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: On demande une brute
Description: Directed by Charles Barrois • 1934 • France /  / In this twenty-three-minute slapstick film, directed by Charles Barrois and written by Jacques Tati and René Clément, a shy, out-of-work actor (Tati) unwittingly enters a professional wrestling match. On demande une brute also stars Enrico Sprocani, a famous circus clown known as Rhum.

Title: Allison Anders on PARIS, TEXAS
Description: Filmmaker Allison Anders was a production assistant on PARIS, TEXAS. In this October 2009 interview, she reads from the diary she kept during the film’s production.

Title: François Thomas
Description: In this interview, shot in April 2016, Orson Welles scholar François Thomas discusses the production of THE IMMORTAL STORY, as well as Welles’s love for author Karen Blixen, who wrote under the pen name Isak Dinesen, on whose story the film is based.

Title: A Physical History of M
Description: This documentary traces the “physical history” of Fritz Lang’s M, from its production and original distribution to the digital restoration used as the basis for this edition. It includes a look at the French-language version of M but was produced before the discovery of the English-language version.

Title: Michael Haneke
Description: The following interview with director Michael Haneke was recorded in Vienna in May 2017.

Title: A Study in Undercranking
Description: In the following program, produced in 2015, silent-film specialist Ben Model looks at how Charlie Chaplin used the difference between filming and projecting speeds to create unique gags that could only exist in silent cinema.

Title: Rossellini and the City
Description: Mark Shiel is the author of “Italian Neorealism: Rebuilding the Cinematic City.” In this 2009 video essay, he discusses Roberto Rossellini’s depiction of the urban settings in ROME OPEN CITY, PAISAN, and GERMANY YEAR ZERO.

Title: FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT: Radio Adaptation
Description: On July 24, 1946, “Academy Award Theater” broadcast this radio adaptation of FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT.

Title: Hirokazu Kore-eda on STILL WALKING
Description: The following interview with STILL WALKING director Hirokazu Kore-eda was shot in August 2010 at the International House of Japan in Tokyo, with cinematographer Yutaka Yamazaki acting as cameraman.

Title: Kurosawa and the Censors
Description: Between 1945 and 1952, during the American occupation of Japan, censorship agencies reviewed all films proposed for production. In this 2007 video essay, film scholar Lars-Martin Sorensen sheds light on the challenges Akira Kurosawa faced from the censors in making DRUNKEN ANGEL.

Title: Miles Goes Modal
Description: In 2006, jazz trumpeter Jon Faddis and critic Gary Giddins discuss the iconic Miles Davis and the critical time in his career when the score for ELEVATOR TO THE GALLOWS was recorded.

Title: Gillian Armstrong on MY BRILLIANT CAREER
Description: In this interview, recorded in Los Angeles in 2018, director Gillian Armstrong talks about the way the success of MY BRILLIANT CAREER shaped her own career in film.

Title: Meheli Sen on THE HERO
Description: In this interview, produced in 2017, Meheli Sen, associate professor of cinema studies at Rutgers University, shares her observations about Satyajit Ray’s THE HERO; its lead actor, Uttam Kumar; and its unique setting, storytelling style, and peripheral characters.

Title: Brigitte Mira on ALI: FEAR EATS THE SOUL
Description: Brigitte Mira’s acting career spanned more than six decades and included such films as Werner Herzog’s THE ENIGMA OF KASPAR HAUSER and Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s SATAN’S BREW and ALI: FEAR EATS THE SOUL. This interview with her was conducted in Berlin in 2003.

Title: Freddy Buache and Dominique Païni
Description: In this 2004 conversation, film scholars Freddy Buache and Dominique Païni discuss the impact and insight of MASCULIN FÉMININ, Jean-Luc Godard’s playfully subversive film. Buache, founder of the Cinémathèque suisse, was the “recipient” of Godard’s 1981 short film LETTRE À FREDDY BUACHE. Païni was a director of the Cinémathèque française, in Paris.

Title: Deleted Scenes
Description: Director Andrei Tarkovsky cut SOLARIS significantly before the film went to Cannes in 1972. Long thought to be lost, the original version was, in fact, in the Russian film archive Gosfilmofond. Presented here is a sequence from the original version that differs from Tarkovsky’s final cut.

Title: Peter Weir on PICNIC AT HANGING ROCK.
Description: In this 2003 interview, director Peter Weir discusses the production and enduring mystery of PICNIC AT HANGING ROCK.

Title: Love Letters
Description: This 2014 program features interviews with THE HONEYMOON KILLERS actors Tony Lo Bianco and Marilyn Chris and editor Stan Warnow.

Title: Split Screen: S2-E5 Enter BLAIR WITCH, HANDS ON A HARDBODY
Description: Sunflower City: Lawrence, KS, the home of the family owned Sunflower Cable system, and CARNIVAL OF SOULS; HANDS ON A HARDBODY: an excerpt from Robb Bindler’s incredible documentary; The Blair Witch Project: a three-crew documentary team disappears deep in the woods of Maryland. Original airdate 08/15/1997

Title: Music by Charles Chaplin
Description: Charlie Chaplin composed most of his own scores, beginning with CITY LIGHTS in 1931. He also returned to his earlier silent films and composed new scores for their rereleases. In this 2012 interview, composer and conductor Timothy Brock discusses Chaplin’s musical achievements, as well as his own work reconstructing and conducting Chaplin’s scores.

Title: Gus Van Sant on MALA NOCHE
Description: The following interview with writer-director Gus Van Sant was recorded in January 2007.

Title: Charlie Chaplin and the American Press
Description: In this 2012 program, Kate Guyonvarch, director of the Chaplin company Roy Export, and Charles Maland, author of “Chaplin and American Culture,” review the coverage of Charlie Chaplin in the American press over some sixty years, and discuss how the timing of MONSIEUR VERDOUX represented a particular challenge to the artist’s public persona.

Title: Men of Mystery
Description: In this video interview, recorded in London in January 2008, Orson Welles biographer Simon Callow (“Orson Welles: The Road to Xanadu,” 1995) discusses late actor Robert Arden, producer Louis Dolivet, and the cameo by Michael Redgrave in MR. ARKADIN.

Title: Withnail & Us
Description: The following is a 1999 documentary on the film WITHNAIL AND I.

Title: Megan Abbott in Conversation
Description: The best-selling author of “You Will Know Me” on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Richard Neupert on PARIS BELONGS TO US
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2015, Richard Neupert, professor of film studies at the University of Georgia and author of “A History of the French New Wave Cinema,” discusses the themes and legacy of Jacques Rivette’s debut feature, PARIS BELONGS TO US.

Title: THE DEVIL AND DANIEL WEBSTER and HERE IS A MAN
Description: THE DEVIL AND DANIEL WEBSTER was first previewed as HERE IS A MAN on July 12, 1941. Although its overall content is similar, some stylistic flourishes and edits differ between that earlier print and the subsequent cut, titled ALL THAT MONEY CAN BUY. Those differences are presented here, with each “final” excerpt followed by the preview version.

Title: Liv Ullmann and Erland Josephson
Description: Actors Liv Ullmann and Erland Josephson have each had prolific careers working with Ingmar Bergman and other directors and have also gone on to direct projects of their own. The success of SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE catapulted them to international celebrity. Both were interviewed in 2003: Liv Ullmann in New York City and Erland Josephson in Stockholm.

Title: THE BATTLE OF ALGIERS: A Case Study
Description: In 2004, ABC News’ Christopher Isham discusses the contemporary political relevance of THE BATTLE OF ALGIERS with Richard A. Clarke, former national coordinator for security and counterterrorism and the author of “Against All Enemies: Inside America’s War on Terror,” and Michael A. Sheehan, former State Department counterterrorism coordinator.

Title: Masahiro Shinoda on THE HUMAN CONDITION
Description: In this video appreciation, created in 2009, we present filmmaker Masahiro Shinoda’s observations on THE HUMAN CONDITION and director Masaki Kobayashi.

Title: Christopher Faulkner on A DAY IN THE COUNTRY
Description: Originally shot in 1936, A DAY IN THE COUNRTY was not released until ten years later, in a 40-minute, unfinished version. In the following interview, conducted in October 2014, Jean Renoir scholar Christopher Faulkner discusses the film’s complicated production history and where it fits in the director’s oeuvre.

Title: Jean Renoir parle de son art: Part 3
Description: In the following 1961 interview, Jean Renoir discusses with French New Wave director Jacques Rivette his design of the “seventh art” and art in general, demolishing certain generally accepted ideas, and evoking memories from his own filmmaking career.

Title: Claude Miller on WEEKEND
Description: Assistant director Claude Miller recalls working with director Jean-Luc Godard on WEEKEND.

Title: Peter Cowie and Harriet Andersson
Description: In January 2012, film critic and Bergman scholar Peter Cowie sat down with actress Harriet Andersson in Stockholm for this conversation about SUMMER WITH MONIKA.

Title: “Ciné regards”: Judy Davis
Description: In this April 10, 1980, episode of the French television series “Ciné regards,” actor Judy Davis shares her thoughts about self-expression through acting and the limits of the cinematic medium.

Title: Revolutions Per Second
Description: The following video essay on Jean-Luc Godard’s WEEKEND, by writer and filmmaker Kent Jones, was produced in 2012.

Title: Walter Lassally on TOM JONES
Description: Cinematographer Walter Lassally (1926–2017) worked with director Tony Richardson on three films in three years: A TASTE OF HONEY, THE LONELINESS OF THE LONG DISTANCE RUNNER, and TOM JONES. In this piece, including footage from conversations with the cinematographer from 2004 and 2017, Lassally discusses TOM JONES and collaborating with Richardson.

Title: Lee Chang-dong on SECRET SUNSHINE
Description: The following interview with director Lee Chang-dong was conducted in April 2011 in Seoul, South Korea, by film critic Kim Young-jin.

Title: The Making of EL SUR
Description: The following program includes interviews with members of EL SUR’s cast and crew, including cinematographer José Luis Alcaine; actors Omero Antonutti, Sonsoles Aranguren, and Icíar Bollaín; and camera operator Alfredo Mayo. These interviews were originally shot for “El Mundo” in 2012 and have been reedited for this release.

Title: Cooking up RAOUL
Description: In this 2012 documentary, actors Mary Woronov, Robert Beltran, and Edie McClurg reflect on the making of EATING RAOUL.

Title: THREE COLORS: BLUE Selected-Scene Commentary
Description: In this audio commentary from 2004, actor Juliette Binoche revisits selected scenes from Blue.

Title: Stéphane Audran on BABETTE'S FEAST
Description: Before BABETTE’S FEAST, Stéphane Audran was probably best known for her performances in films by her former husband Claude Chabrol and her role in Luis Buñuel’s THE DISCREET CHARM OF THE BOURGEOISIE. In this 2012 interview, she discusses taking the part of Babette and the challenges of working in an unfamiliar language.

Title: Sławomir Idziak on THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE
Description: Cinematographer Sławomir Idziak first worked with Krzysztof Kieślowski on the director’s early film PEDESTRIAN SUBWAY (1973). Idziak went on to shoot several more films with Kieślowski, including THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE and BLUE (1993), and has more than fifty feature films to his name. This interview was conducted in London in 2006.

Title: The Lineup
Description: Director Jean-Pierre Melville and actors Alain Delon, Nathalie Delon, Cathy Rosier, and François Périer discuss the filmmaker’s style, acting, and LE SAMOURAÏ, in this collection of archival interviews. These clips, from the Institut national de l’audiovisuel, Paris, were originally broadcast on French television between 1967 and 1982.

Title: Alain Mimoun
Description: Directed by Louis Gueguen • 1959 • France /  / ALAIN MIMOUN, a short film made about the titular long-distance runner, is a jewel of a documentary, enhanced by a wonderfully laid-back jazz score by Alain Goraguer.

Title: Jay Weissberg on 4 MONTHS, 3 WEEKS AND 2 DAYS
Description: In this interview, film critic Jay Weissberg talks about Cristian Mungiu's film 4 MONTHS, 3 WEEKS AND 2 DAYS and its place within the New Romanian Cinema. It was recorded in 2016.

Title: Claire Denis on WHITE MATERIAL
Description: This interview with director Claire Denis was recorded in 2010.

Title: J.M. Mondésir
Description: Directed by Alice Colomer-Kang • 2012 • France /  / A housing project that seems more like an amphitheater, bears witness to a sacrifice. In 2002, Georges Mondesir dies after an encounter with the police. He's crazy, or just simple-minded. When face to face with the police, Mondesir is the Other. It's the underlying ancestral struggle between this duo that interests Alice Colomer-Kang. It never becomes a documentary about death. It's a ballet from which only the camera is free to escape. Slow motion defies realism, several perspectives intertwine - these bring about the impression that something had happened.

Title: Outtakes
Description: The following outtakes were assembled by Jay Rabinowitz, apprentice editor on DOWN BY LAW, who went on to edit many of Jim Jarmusch’s subsequent films.

Title: Freshwater Assassins
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1947 • France /  / The academic and the fantastic merge in Jean Painlevé's educational film about the food chain in a freshwater pond.

Title: Carl Davis: Scoring for Harold
Description: In the following 2013 interview, composer and conductor Carl Davis talks about his music for SAFETY LAST! and other Harold Lloyd titles, as well as his career scoring both silent and sound films.

Title: Jennifer Salt on SISTERS
Description: The following interview with actor Jennifer Salt was recorded in 2018.

Title: Tokyo 1958
Description: Hiroshi Teshigahara created TOKYO 1958 with the collaboration of eight other filmmakers: Susumu Hani, Zenzo Matsuyama, Yoshiro Kawazu, Kyushiro Kusakabe, Kanzaburo Mushanokoji, Sadamu Maruo, Ryuichiro Sakisaka, and Masahiro Ogi.

Title: Washingtonia
Description: Directed by Konstantina Kotzamani • 2014 • Greece /  / Washingtonia starts when the giraffes heart can no longer be heard. Washingtonia is an alternative name for Athens, a place where people, like animals, fall into summertime sadness because of the heat. Washingtonia is the only palm tree that its heart is not devoured by the red beetle. Because it's heart is small and dry and no one likes small and dry hearts.

Title: NIGHT ON EARTH Commentary: Rome
Description: Recorded in 2007, this audio commentary features director of photography Frederick Elmes and location sound mixer Drew Kunin.

Title: Everything Is Beautiful: Lines, Signs, Designs
Description: This first segment in a three-part program from 2005, produced by Les Films de Mon Oncle, focuses on the architecture of MON ONCLE.

Title: Restoring THE FRONT PAGE
Description: This 2016 piece details the work of the Academy Film Archive and The Film Foundation in bringing this version of THE FRONT PAGE to life. It highlights the differences between this restoration, in which certain scenes reflect director Lewis Milestone’s preferred presentation for domestic distribution, and previously available versions of the film.

Title: Mira Nair in Conversation
Description: The director of MONSOON WEDDING on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: The Borders of the Possible
Description: In this 2012 video essay, film historian Leonard Leff discusses Alfred Hitchcock’s adaptation of John Buchan’s novel “The Thirty-Nine Steps” and the hallmarks of Hitchcock’s style.

Title: Tadao Sato on SANSHO THE BAILIFF
Description: Recorded in 2007, this appreciation of SANSHO THE BAILIFF features film critic and historian Tadao Sato illuminating the film’s themes, discussing its technical excellence, and celebrating its director, Kenji Mizoguchi.

Title: Peter Jelavich
Description: Peter Jelavich, professor of history at Johns Hopkins University, is the author of “Berlin Alexanderplatz”: Radio, Film, and the Death of Weimar Culture. In this 2007 interview, he discusses the multiple ways in which Alfred Döblin’s novel has been adapted and how these disparate forms reflect the history of Weimar Germany.

Title: Roger Corman in Conversation
Description: The trailblazing filmmaker on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Template for the Troubles: John Hill on ODD MAN OUT
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2014, cinema scholar John Hill, author of “Cinema and Northern Ireland: Film, Culture and Politics,” delves into ODD MAN OUT and its depiction of Northern Ireland.

Title: On IN THE MOOD FOR LOVE
Description: In this 2012 interview, critic Tony Rayns offers his perspective on the style and content of IN THE MOOD FOR LOVE and his evaluation of the film’s place in director Wong Kar-wai’s career.

Title: Outtakes: David Brinkley
Description: From 1956 to 1970, journalist David Brinkley cohosted “The Huntley-Brinkley Report,” NBC’s nightly news show, with Chet Huntley. He later moved to ABC as a political commentator and retired in 1997. Highly critical of U.S. policy in Vietnam, Brinkley here discusses his personal feelings about the war and the role of the American press.

Title: Howard Brookner on BURROUGHS: THE MOVIE
Description: The following audio excerpts are from a July 1985 interview with director Howard Brookner about the making of BURROUGHS: THE MOVIE. The interview was conducted by William S. Burroughs biographer Ted Morgan.

Title: Roy Grundmann on CODE UNKNOWN
Description: The following interview with film scholar Roy Grundmann, editor of “A Companion to Michael Haneke,” was conducted in Boston in August 2015.

Title: A Canterbury Tale - Trailer
Description: Directed by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger • 1944 • United Kingdom /  / Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger's beloved classic A CANTERBURY TALE is a profoundly personal journey to Powell's bucolic birthplace of Kent, England. Set amid the tumult of the Second World War, yet with a rhythm as delicate as a lullaby, the film follows three modern-day incarnations of Chaucer's pilgrims, a melancholy "landgirl," a plainspoken American GI, and a resourceful British sergeant, who are waylaid in the English countryside en route to the mythical town and forced to solve a bizarre village crime. Building to a majestic climax that ranks as one of the filmmaking duo's finest achievements, the dazzling A CANTERBURY TALE has acquired a following of devotees passionate enough to qualify as pilgrims themselves.

Title: Adapting Tagore
Description: In this interview program, produced in 2013, Indian film scholar Moinak Biswas and Bengali cultural historian Supriya Chaudhuri discuss director Satyajit Ray’s controversial adaptation of Rabindranath Tagore’s novella “The Broken Nest.”

Title: Return to Glennascaul
