Description: Directed by Hilton Edwards • 1953 • United Kingdom /  / Orson Welles, playing himself, picks up a hitchhiker who recounts a strange story. Actors Micheál MacLiammóir and Hilton Edwards made this short film during a hiatus from shooting Othello (1952).

Title: Jean-Pierre Gorin on LA JETÉE
Description: In 2005, filmmaker, writer, and educator Jean-Pierre Gorin spoke with the Criterion Collection about LA JETÉE and the work of director Chris Marker. His observations are presented here.

Title: Shohei Imamura on INTENTIONS  OF MURDER
Description: This twenty-four minute interview with Shohei Imamura was conducted by film critic Tadao Sato.

Title: Julie Taymor’s Adventures in Moviegoing
Description: The award-winning stage and film director on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Light in the Darkness
Description: Made in 2017, this program features filmmakers Frank Darabont, Guillermo del Toro, and Robert Rodriguez discussing the cinematic importance of NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD.

Title: À PROPOS DE NICE Commentary
Description: Recorded in 2011, this commentary features Michael Temple, author of "Jean Vigo".

Title: Andrés Di Tella on LA CIÉNAGA
Description: In this interview, conducted in April 2014, director, writer, and Buenos Aires International Festival of Independent Cinema founder Andrés Di Tella examines the cultural context from which filmmaker Lucrecia Martel emerged, and analyzes her groundbreaking first feature.

Title: À propos de Nice
Description: Directed by Jean Vigo and Boris Kaufman • 1930 • France /  / Jean Vigo was twenty-five when he made this, his debut film, a silent cinematic poem that reveals, through a thrilling and ironic use of montage, the economic reality hidden behind the facade of the Mediterranean resort town of Nice. The first of Vigo's several collaborations with cinematographer Boris Kaufman (Dziga Vertov's brother and a future Oscar winner), À PROPOS DE NICE is both a scathing and invigorating look at 1930 French culture.

Title: Robert E. Fulton III Edit of BURROUGHS: THE MOVIE
Description: After two years of filming, director Howard Brookner brought inventor and photographer Robert E. Fulton III a trunkful of William S. Burroughs footage to see if Fulton could edit his film. The result was a decidedly experimental 23-minute cut. The director was looking for a more narrative approach, so Fulton’s edit, presented here, was never used.

Title: PARIS, TEXAS Deleted Scenes and Super 8 with Commentary
Regards from Nowhere
Description: This video essay on CARNIVAL OF SOULS by critic and filmmaker David Cairns was produced in 2016.

Title: “Cinéastes de notre temps”: Samuel Fuller, 1967
Description: This interview with director Samuel Fuller was excerpted from a 1967 episode of the French television series “Cinéastes de notre temps.”

Title: Jean Renoir parle de son art: Part 1
Description: In the following 1961 interview, Jean Renoir discusses with French New Wave director Jacques Rivette his design of the “seventh art” and art in general, demolishing certain generally accepted ideas, and evoking some memories from his own career.

Title: Dreyer Radio Broadcast
Description: Cinema scholar Gideon Bachmann broadcast this recording of director Carl Dreyer reading an essay on film during a 1958 episode of “The Film Art,” Bachmann’s radio program on New York’s WBAI.

Title: Behind the Scenes of RED
Description: The following piece juxtaposes footage of Krzysztof Kieślowski directing RED with the corresponding scenes as they appear in the film.

Title: Marlon James in Conversation
Description: The Booker Prize–winning author of “A Brief History of Seven Killings” on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Carlo Lizzani on GERMANY YEAR ZERO
Description: Carlo Lizzani was the only Italian hired to work on Roberto Rossellini's international crew for GERMANY YEAR ZERO. In this podium discussion from the Tutto Rossellini conference in Pesaro, Italy, in June 1987, Lizzani discusses his role as assistant director on the film. He also reads excerpts from letters that he wrote about the production wile on set to his friend Antonello Trombadori, an art critic and influential member of the Italian Communist Party, who had helped get him the job.

Title: Eva Hart: Survivor
Description: This interview with Titanic survivor Eva Hart was conducted by Ray Johnson in 1990. She died on February 14, 1996.

Title: Mining the Archive
Description: In this 2007 piece, Imperial War Museum film archivists Roger Smither and Anne Fleming discuss Stuart Cooper’s use of archival war footage to tell the story of the buildup to D-day in OVERLORD. Also included is additional footage shot on D-day by service cameramen.

Title: Richard Brody and Carrie Rickey on MIKEY AND NICKY
Description: This program, created in 2018, features critic Richard Brody and Carrie Rickey discussing Elaine May's unique achievements in MIKEY AND NICKY and in her film-directing career as a whole.

Title: David Korda on Zoltán Korda
Description: This video interview with David Korda, the eldest son of THE FOUR FEATHERS director Zoltán Korda, was recorded in London in 2011. In it, Korda discusses his family and his father’s career.

Title: Ronald Neame on TUNES OF GLORY
Description: This interview with director Ronald Neame was taped in Los Angeles in October 2003.

Title: A Lecture
Description: This performance piece by filmmaker Hollis Frampton, recorded in 1968 in New York City, features the voice of artist Michael Snow. Frampton would place a tape deck at the front of a room, press play, and walk to the back to run a 16 mm projector. Presented here is the audio portion of the piece, with images designed to replicate Frampton’s visuals.

Title: The Bakery Girl of Monceau
Description: Directed by Eric Rohmer • 1963 • France /  / Simple, delicate, and jazzy, the first of the Moral Tales shows the stirrings of what would become the Eric Rohmer style: unfussy naturalistic shooting, ironic first-person voice-over, and the image of the "unknowable" woman. A law student (played by producer and future director Barbet Schroeder) with a roving eye and a large appetite stuffs himself full of sugar cookies and pastries daily in order to garner the attentions of the pretty brunette who works in a quaint Paris bakery. But is he truly interested, or is she just a sweet diversion?

Title: Jane Shattuc on THE BITTER TEARS OF PETRA VON KANT
Description: This interview with Jane Shattuc, professor of visual and media arts at Emerson College and author of “Television, Tabloids, and Tears: Fassbinder and Popular Culture,” was conducted in September 2014.

Title: Melville-Delon: D’honneur et de nuit
Description: The following short documentary, directed by Olivier Bohler in 2011, explores the close friendship between director Jean-Pierre Melville and actor Alain Delon, and their iconic collaboration LE SAMOURAÏ. It features interviews with Melville's nephews Laurent Grousset and Rémy Grumbach, critic Rui Nogueira, and filmmaker Volker Schlöndorff.

Title: MANILA . . . A Filipino Film
Description: Made by filmmaker and cinematographer Mike De Leon in 1975, this documentary about the making of MANILA IN THE CLAWS OF LIGHT features interviews with director Lino Brocka, actors Hilda Koronel and Rafael Roco Jr., and others.

Title: Hitchcock/Truffaut
Description: In 1962, filmmaker François Truffaut interviewed Alfred Hitchcock over the course of approximately fifty hours, with the help of translator Helen G. Scott, resulting in the landmark 1967 book “Hitchcock.” Presented here are excerpts from Truffaut’s audio recordings, in which Hitchcock discusses the original version of THE MAN WHO KNEW TOO MUCH.

Title: Hokusai
Description: In his first short film, Hiroshi Teshigahara explores the work of the wood-block artist Katsushika Hokusai (1760–1849).

Title: David Bordwell and Kristin Thompson
Description: The following discussion about THERE WAS A FATHER with film scholars David Bordwell and Kristin Thompson was recorded in 2010.

Title: Harvey Milk: Two Films, One Legacy
Description: Director Robert Epstein and producer Richard Schmiechen’s THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK has carried the torch on behalf of Harvey Milk since its release in 1984. In 2008, Gus Van Sant’s MILK introduced his story to a new generation of viewers. In this 2011 program, Epstein, Van Sant, actor James Franco, and several of Milk’s friends discuss the films.

Title: Dear Martha . . .
Description: This video essay was written by Scott Christianson, author of “Condemned: Inside the Sing Sing Death House.” It includes rare photos, clippings, and documents from Martha Beck and Ray Fernandez’s trial and incarceration.

Title: Brad Bird in Conversation
Description: The director of RATATOUILLE on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: The Colour of His Hair
Description: Directed by Sam Ashby • 2017 • United Kingdom /  / Based on an unrealized film script written in 1964 for The Homosexual Law Reform Society, a British organization that campaigned for the decriminalization of homosexual relations between men, THE COLOUR OF HIS HAIR merges drama and documentary into an impressionistic meditation on queer life before and after the partial legalization of homosexuality in 1967.

Title: Christopher Frayling on the Design of THINGS TO COME
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2013, writer and cultural historian Christopher Frayling discusses the groundbreaking design of THINGS TO COME.

Title: Todd Haynes on Rainer Werner Fassbinder
Description: In this interview, conducted in Portland, Oregon, in 2003, director Todd Haynes discusses the influence of filmmaker Rainer Werner Fassbinder on his work, and the influence of director Douglas Sirk on them both.

Title: David Bordwell on MASTER OF THE HOUSE
Description: In the following program, film scholar David Bordwell examines the cinematic techniques Carl Theodor Dreyer was experimenting with when he made MASTER OF THE HOUSE.

Title: The Making of Y TU MAMÁ TAMBIÉN
Description: This documentary from 2001 features behind-the-scenes footage from the film’s production and is narrated by actor Daniel Giménez Cacho, the star of Alfonso Cuarón's debute feature, SÓLO CON TU PAREJA, and the narrator of Y TU MAMÁ TAMBIÉN.

Title: Babette Mangolte on JEANNE DIELMAN
Description: JEANNE DIELMAN cinematographer Babette Mangolte was a longtime collaborator of Chantal Akerman’s, and also shot her films HÔTEL MONTEREY and LA CHAMBRE. This interview, in which Mangolte discusses JEANNE DIELMAN, was conducted in April 2009.

Title: Working with De Sica
Description: This short documentary features interviews with film scholar Callisto Cosulich, BICYCLE THIEVES coscreenwriter Suso Cecchi d’Amico, and actor Enzo Staiola. The interviews were conducted in Italy in 2005.

Title: Rodney Hill on THE UMBRELLAS OF CHERBOURG
Description: In this 2014 interview, film scholar Rodney Hill talks about THE UMBRELLAS OF CHERBOURG and how it embodies characteristics of both the French New Wave and the “tradition of quality” style of French filmmaking.

Title: Matteo Garrone on GOMORRAH
Description: This interview with GOMORRAH director Matteo Garrone was shot in July 2009 in Rome.

Title: Gregor Dorfmeister on THE BRIDGE
Description: THE BRIDGE was adapted from Gregor Dorfmeister’s first novel, published in 1958. In this March 2015 interview, Dorfmeister discusses the autobiographical nature of the story and the enduring impact of both the novel and the film.

Title: Final Destination
Description: In this 2016 piece, writer and comedian Dana Gould discusses CARNIVAL OF SOULS.

Title: Making SWEETIE
Description: This conversation between SWEETIE stars Genevieve Lemon and Karen Colston was recorded in 2006.

Title: Robby Müller on DOWN BY LAW
Description: This interview with DOWN BY LAW cinematographer Robby Müller was recorded at the Hortus Botanical Garden in Amsterdam in 2002.

Title: Rebecca Miller in Conversation
Description: The author and filmmaker on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Living and Departed
Description: This visual essay, written, produced, and narrated by critic Tag Gallagher, the author of “The Adventures of Roberto Rossellini: His Life and Films,” examines JOURNEY TO ITALY in relation to Rossellini’s earlier collaborations with actor Ingrid Bergman.

Title: Susanne Bier on AFTER THE WEDDING
Description: Director Susanne Bier discusses her filmmaking process and artistic preoccupations in this conversation with Danish film critic Morten Piil, recorded in 2006. /  /

Title: Neil Brand on THE LODGER
Description: In this 2017 interview, composer Neil Brand discusses the process of creating a new score for THE LODGER.

Title: John Sweet: A Pilgrim’s Return
Description: In 2001, Nick Burton and Eddie McMillan produced the following short documentary on John Sweet's first visit back to Canterbury since the making of A CANTERBURY TALE, in 1943. Sweet and his costar Sheila Sim were attending the Kent International Film Festival and its annual Michael Powell celebrations. In the piece, Sweet talks about making the film, its enduring popularity, and its effect on his life since.

Title: Hôtel des invalides
Description: In this documentary from 1952, Georges Franju turns his camera on the seventeenth-century Paris military complex of the title, which includes a hospital turned museum and a burial site. It is narrated by actor Michel Simon and a museum tour guide and features music by Maurice Jarre and images by Marcel Fradetal, both of whom also worked on JUDEX.

Title: PÉPÉ LE MOKO and ALGIERS
Description: This 2002 piece compares PÉPÉ LE MOKO with its 1938 U.S. remake, ALGIERS.

Title: Takashi Murakami on JELLYFISH EYES
Description: In this interview, conducted in July 2015 at the Kaikai Kiki studio in New York, director Takashi Murakami talks about the genesis of JELLYFISH EYES, how the film was informed by the television of his childhood, and the evolution of his approach to making art.

Title: Paul Dano in Conversation
Description: The actor and director of WILDLIFE on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Coutard and Rissient on BREATHLESS
Description: In this 2007 interview, Raoul Coutard, who shot fourteen films for Jean-Luc Godard, and Pierre Rissient, the assistant director on BREATHLESS, recall the production of Godard’s first feature film.

Title: Thea Eymèsz on Rainer Werner Fassbinder
Description: ALI: FEAR EATS THE SOUL editor Thea Eymèsz worked with director Rainer Werner Fassbinder on sixteen of his films, beginning with 1969’s GODS OF THE PLAGUE and ending with 1976’s SATAN’S BREW. In the following interview, conducted in her Munich apartment in 2003, Eymèsz talks for the first time on camera about their collaboration.

Title: Michel Romanoff on THE WAGES OF FEAR
Description: Assistant director Michel Romanoff worked with directors such as Marcel Carné, Julien Duvivier, Jacques Demy, Agnès Varda, and Henri-Georges Clouzot, whose second he was on DIABOLIQUE, THE SPIES, and THE WAGES OF FEAR. In this 2005 interview in Paris, Romanoff discusses his work on the two-year shoot of THE WAGES OF FEAR in the southern France.

Title: “Cinéastes de notre temps”: François Truffaut, 1965
Description: In this television excerpt from December 2, 1965, François Truffaut discusses his youth, writing for “Cahiers du cinéma,” and the character Antoine Doinel. Actors Jean-Pierre Léaud and Albert Rémy and Truffaut’s collaborator Claude de Givray also appear.

Title: Suranjan Ganguly on Satyajit Ray
Description: In the following interview, conducted in 2013, Satyajit Ray scholar and author Suranjan Ganguly discusses how Ray presents women faced with the challenges of modernity in THE BIG CITY, CHARULATA, and THE COWARD.

Title: Eugenia Paulicelli on LE AMICHE
Description: Recorded in New York in 2016, this interview features scholar Eugenia Paulicelli talking about the significance of fashion in the films of Michelangelo Antonioni.

Title: Pay Day
Description: Directed by Charles Chaplin • 1922 • United States /  / Chaplin plays a productive bricklayer who lives by the adage, "Work hard, play hard." With a stack of money burning a hole in his pocket, he bickers with his wife on the best way to allocate the payday funds.

Title: Hitchcock-Truffaut: THE 39 STEPS
Description: In 1962, François Truffaut interviewed Alfred Hitchcock for approximately fifty hours, with the help of his collaborator and translator Helen G. Scott. Those interviews would form the basis of Truffaut’s landmark 1967 book “Hitchcock.” Presented here are excerpts from Truffaut’s original audio recordings, in which Hitchcock discusses THE 39 STEPS.

Title: The Tobis v. Chaplin Affair
Description: In this audio essay, recorded in London in March 2002, film historian David Robinson, author of “Chaplin: His Life and Art,” delves into the sordid history of the plagiarism lawsuit brought by Tobis Films, producers of À NOUS LA LIBERTÉ, against Charlie Chaplin and his film MODERN TIMES.

Title: The Perfect Bowl
Description: This program on TAMPOPO’s influence on food culture in Japan and abroad features interviews with ramen expert Hiroshi Oosaki and ramen chefs Ivan Orkin, Jerry Jaksich, Sam White, and Rayneil De Guzman. It was produced in 2016.

Title: The Influence of TOM JONES
Description: In the following interview, recorded in York, England, in October 2017, film scholar Duncan Petrie explains how TOM JONES’s production, cinematic style, and enormous financial success changed the landscape of British filmmaking.

Title: John's Gone
Description: Directed by Josh Safdie and Benny Safdie • 2010 • United States /  / JOHN'S GONE is a fever dream comedy. John sells things online, cheats off dollar stores, needs friends but settles for strangers, has roaches.

Title: Sheryl Lee on TWIN PEAKS: FIRE WALK WITH ME
Description: The following is a 2017 interview with actor Sheryl Lee.

Title: Wong Kar-wai on IN THE MOOD FOR LOVE
Description: Presented here is an interview with director Wong Kar-wai, conducted by film critic Michel Ciment and filmmaker Hubert Niogret.

Title: The Look of CHILDREN OF PARADISE
Description: The following video essay by Paul Ryan looks at the design of CHILDREN OF PARADISE and features sketches by its screenwriter Jacques Prévert, production designer Alexandre Trauner, art director Léon Barsacq, and costume designer Mayo.

Title: Blood of the Beasts
Description: Directed by Georges Franju ‰Û¢ 1949 ‰Û¢ France /  /   /  /  This 1949 documentary by Georges Franju looks at the brutal reality of ParisÕs abattoirs, while employing a disarmingly beautiful visual style.

Title: On Pascal
Description: Eric Rohmer directed several episodes of the French television series “En profil dans le texte.” In this episode from 1965, he interviews authors and philosophers Brice Parain and Dominique Dubarle on the topic of Pascal’s wager.

Title: His Royal Slyness
Description: Directed by Hal Roach • 1920 •  /  / Harold Lloyd plays a tireless American bookseller traveling abroad in the kingdom of Thermosa, where he is mistaken for a prince. When the true prince returns to stake his claim to the throne, the country is thrown into turmoil.

Title: From the Ruins
Description: Made for in 2005, this video interview features director Seijun Suzuki and production designer Takeo Kimura. These longtime collaborators discuss the making of GATE OF FLESH.

Title: Elements of Landscape
Description: In the following piece, Italian film critic and scholar Adriano Aprà and longtime Michelangelo Antonioni friend and collaborator Carlo di Carlo discuss the director and his vision for L’ECLISSE. The interviews were conducted in Rome in 2004.

Title: On RED
Description: The following 2011 video essay about Krzysztof Kieślowski’s RED was written and narrated by film writer Dennis Lim.

Title: Walter Matthau and Dick Cavett
Description: Walter Matthau visited “The Dick Cavett Show” on April 21, 1980, to promote his film LITTLE MISS MARKER. In this excerpt from that appearance, the actor shares anecdotes from his career in theater and film.

Title: Several Friends
Description: Directed by Charles Burnett • 1969 • United States /  /  /  / Charles Burnett’s first film already displays the director’s neorealist, poetry-of-the-everyday style as it follows a group of friends over the course of an aimless day in Los Angeles. /  /  /  / Limited engagement ends September 30

Title: Producing MISHIMA
Description: In this piece, producers Tom Luddy and Mata Yamamoto recount the challenges of producing MISHIMA: A LIFE IN FOUR CHAPTERS. Their interviews were recorded in 2007 and 2008.

Title: Duane Jones on NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD
Description: Conducted by journalist Tim Ferrante on December 13, 1987, this audio interview with actor Duane Jones, edited by Ferrante and including content not heard in previous presentations, is illustrated with stills and clips.

Title: Faire face: La prostitution
Description: These excerpts from “La prostitution,” an episode of the television series “Faire face” that first aired on February 24, 1961, feature interviews with Max Fernet, Paris’s director of police, and Marcel Sacotte, a magistrate and the author of the 1959 book “Où en est: La prostitution,” from which Jean-Luc Godard took inspiration for VIVRE SA VIE.

Title: Antonythasan Jesuthasan on DHEEPAN
Description: This interview with novelist and actor Antonythasan Jesuthasan was conducted in Paris in February 2017.

Title: Luca Barattoni on Antonio Pietrangeli
Description: In this interview, conducted in November 2015, film scholar Luca Barattoni examines the career of director Antonio Pietrangeli, from his beginnings as a critic to his emergence as a leading voice in Italian film, and especially his innovative portrayal of women in the rapidly changing Italy of the 1960s.

Title: Philip Baker Hall on SECRET HONOR
Description: In 1983, Philip Baker Hall took to the stage in the role of President Richard M. Nixon in the play “Secret Honor.” Within that same year, he was asked by Robert Altman to bring his performance to the screen. In this interview recorded in 2004, Hall discusses this milestone role in his prolific career.

Title: Rüdiger Vogler and Lisa Kreuzer on WRONG MOVE
Description: This 2016 program features interviews with actors Rüdiger Vogler and Lisa Kreuzer.

Title: Dreaming of Jeanie
Description: This 2010 video essay by writer Tag Gallagher (“John Ford: The Man and His Films”) analyzes the visual style Ford employs in STAGECOACH, and explains how his technique allows us to both deeply empathize with and remain objective toward the film’s many characters.

Title: Ronald Neame and Brian Garfield on HOPSCOTCH
Festival Talks: Traverse City Film Festival
Description: In 2016, director Kirsten Johnson traveled with CAMERAPERSON to two film festival that had unique connections to the content of her documentary. Both screenings were followed by in-depth conversations with Johnson. An edited program from the live event at Traverse City, hosted by filmmaker Michael Moore, is presented here.

Title: On WHITE
Description: The following 2011 video essay about Krzysztof Kieślowski’s WHITE was written and narrated by film critic and festival curator Tony Rayns.

Title: Eduard Artemyev on SOLARIS
Description: One of SOLARIS’s most distinctive features is its innovative combination of musical styles. Eduard Artemyev’s score contrasts Earth’s culture and family relations with the impersonal, abstract Solaris Ocean. In this 2011 piece, Artemyev discusses his working relationship with director Andrei Tarkovsky and demonstrates his unusual artistic methods.

Title: Gai dimanche
Description: Directed by Jacques Berr • 1935 • France /  / Jacques Tati and Enrico Sprocani, a famous clown who went by the name Rhum, cowrote and costar in this twenty-one minute short. Directed by Jacques Berr, it tells the story of a couple of city tramps who hatch a clever moneymaking scheme.

Title: The Poet and Singer
Description: Directed by Bi Gan • 2012 • China /  /  /  / Water and lightning. Music and poetry. Life and death. An incantatory, visually sublime river journey that anticipates the cosmic mystery of KAILI BLUES.

Title: HIS ROYAL SLYNESS Commentary
Description: This commentary features director and Harold Lloyd archivist Richard Correll and film writer John Bengtson.

Title: The Making of HARLAN COUNTY USA
Description: This documentary features new interviews with producer-director Barbara Kopple, cinematographers Hart Perry and Kevin Keating, associate director Anne Lewis, and three people featured in HARLAN COUNTY USA: United Mine Workers organizer Houston Elmore, miner Jerry Johnson, and strike activist Bessie Parker.

Title: Alternate Edit of À PROPOS DE NICE
Description: An earlier, slightly longer version of À PROPOS DE NICE was found in the archives of the filmmaker Jean Painlevé. In a letter to Painlevé, director Jean Vigo wrote, “When I was working on it, I forgot that a film should be entertaining, so it is a little long or repetitive in places, as you noticed.” Presented here are the longer sequences.

Title: Five Influences on 'Diamonds'
Description: In the following video essay, created in 2018, film scholar James Quandt examines the style of DIAMONDS OF THE NIGHT.

Title: Kiyoshi Ogasawara on KWAIDAN
Description: In this interview, shot in 2015, KWAIDAN assistant director Kiyoshi Ogasawara discusses working with director Masaki Kobayashi and the original, 183-minute version of the film.

Title: Paul Feig in Conversation
Description: The director of BRIDESMAIDS on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Manthia Diawara on BLACK GIRL
Description: Conducted in 2016, this interview with filmmaker and cultural theorist Manthia Diawara (“African Cinema: Politics and Culture”) analyzes Ousmane Sembène's 1966 film.

Title: In the Web of Time
Description: In the following short documentary from 1989, directed by cinematographer František Uldrich, František Vláčil shares his thoughts on his filmmaking process.

Title: Zbigniew Preisner on Krzysztof Kieślowski
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2011, composer Zbigniew Preisner recalls his harmonious collaboration with director Krzysztof Kieślowski on the THREE COLORS trilogy, NO END, DEKALOG, and THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE.

Title: Remaking British Theater
Description: Shelagh Delaney’s play “A Taste of Honey” was first produced by Joan Littlewood’s Theatre Workshop in London in 1958. In this interview, recorded in London in May 2016, theater scholar Kate Dorney discusses the groundbreaking production and its enduring influence.

Title: Norio Osada on LADY SNOWBLOOD
Description: This piece, produced in 2015, features screenwriter Norio Osada discussing his adaptation of the “Lady Snowblood” manga into two feature films.

Title: "Invent Nothing, Deny Nothing" Five Guys from Mamet's Homicide
Description: Here, five recurring actors from David Mamet's productions, Steven Goldstein, Ricky Jay, J.J. Johnston, Joe Mantegna, and Jack Wallace, discuss their work with Mamet and the film HOMICIDE.

Title: Víctor Erice on EL SUR
Description: Midway through the filming of EL SUR, originally planned as a longer movie, production was halted, and the intended ending was never shot. In this interview, which originally aired on Spanish television on September 20, 2003, director Víctor Erice recalls the obstacles he faced and discusses how he feels about the film he was unable to complete.

Title: Hospital
Description: Directed by Krzysztof Kieślowski • 1976 • Poland /  /  /  / Krzysztof Kieślowski began his career making documentaries. Presented here is HOSPITAL, one of his nonfiction shorts.

Title: Krzysztof Piesiewicz on Krzysztof Kieślowski
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2011, Krzysztof Piesiewicz, cowriter of the THREE COLORS trilogy as well as a defense attorney and politician, discusses his long friendship and collaboration with director Krzysztof Kieślowski.

Title: Deleted Scenes and Outtakes
Description: The following is twenty minutes of outtakes and on-set footage from the shooting of KINGS OF THE ROAD. It is silent but presented here with music from Axel Linstädt’s score for the film.

Title: Phillip Lopate on THE STORY OF THE LAST CHRYSANTHEMUM
Description: In this interview, recorded in New York in June 2016, critic Phillip Lopate discusses the evolution of Kenji Mizoguchi’s style and why THE STORY OF THE LAST CHRYSANTHEMUM was a turning point in the filmmaker’s career.

Title: Paul Bartel and Mary Woronov on EATING RAOUL
Description: The following interview with director Paul Bartel and actor Mary Woronov was shot in New York in 1982.

Title: Ártún
Description: Directed by Guðmundur Arnar Guðmundsson • 2014 • Denmark /  / A young boy wants to have his first kiss but has no luck in the small village he lives in. His best friends tell him about girls in the city that get high and easy to make out with when they smoke cigarettes. He questions their story but still decides to join them to the city and find out for himself.

Title: Zbigniew Preisner on THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE
Description: Zbigniew Preisner, Poland’s leading film composer, enjoyed a long collaboration with director Krzysztof Kieślowski, scoring every one of his films beginning with 1985’s NO END. In 1998, he released “Requiem for My Friend,” an album dedicated to the director. This exclusive interview was conducted at the composer’s home in Kraków in July 2006.

Title: Eduard Artemyev on STALKER
Description: A pioneer in the field of electronic music, Eduard Artemyev composed scores for three of Andrei Tarkovsky’s films (SOLARIS and THE MIRROR, in addition to STALKER). In this 2000 interview, Artemyev recalls the process of composing for STALKER.

Title: Rebound
Description: CARNIVAL OF SOULS director Herk Harvey and screenwriter John Clifford were employed for over thirty years by the Lawrence, Kansas–based industrial film giant the Centron Corporation. Between them, Harvey and Clifford made over four hundred films for Centron, from which the following segment has been selected.

Title: Jacques Audiard on DHEEPAN
Description: This interview with DHEEPAN director Jacques Audiard was conducted in Paris in February 2017.

Title: Ettore Scola on A SPECIAL DAY
Description: In this interview with director Ettore Scola, conducted in Rome in May 2015, he discusses the arc of his career and why he wanted to create the character of Gabriele in A SPECIAL DAY.

Title: Chaplin’s LIMELIGHT
Description: In the following program, produced in 2015, Charlie Chaplin biographer David Robinson explores the evolution and personal nature of LIMELIGHT.

Title: Noah Isenberg on DETOUR
Description: The following interview with Noah Isenberg, author of the British Film Institute’s monograph on DETOUR and “Edgar G. Ulmer: A Filmmaker in the Margins,” was recorded in New York in November 2018.

Title: Kaneto Shindo on ONIBABA
Description: This 2003 video interview with Kaneto Shindo shows the acclaimed writer/director discussing the genesis and filming of ONIBABA, as well as reflecting on his diverse and prolific career within the Japanese film industry.

Title: Ludovic Cortade on THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN
Description: In this 2010 interview, French film scholar Ludovic Cortade, author of “Le cinéma de l’immobilité,” discusses the themes and style of THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN.

Title: Geraldine Chaplin on CRÍA CUERVOS . . .
Description: The following interview with actor Geraldine Chaplin was recorded in 2007.

Title: Alfred Hitchcock and Peter Bogdanovich: 1972
Description: In this audio excerpt from an interview conducted in 1972, Alfred Hitchcock talks to filmmaker Peter Bogdanovich about his early years as a director.

Title: Oliver Reed on “The Merv Griffin Show”
Description: This episode of “The Merv Griffin Show” from April 25, 1980, features actor Oliver Reed, along with filmmaker Orson Welles and entertainer Charo. Reed shares various anecdotes as well as his thoughts on film acting.

Title: Masahiro Shinoda on PALE FLOWER
Description: In the following interview, recorded in 2010, writer-director Masahiro Shinoda discusses the production of PALE FLOWER.

Title: Liv Ullmann
Description: This interview with actor Liv Ullmann was produced in 2018.

Title: The Making of PHOENIX
Description: This 2014 documentary features interviews with PHOENIX director Christian Petzold; actors Nina Hoss, Nina Kunzendorf, and Ronald Zehrfeld; and production designer K. D. Gruber.

Title: Robert Altman on THE PLAYER
Description: This interview, in which director Robert Altman discusses THE PLAYER and the Hollywood film industry, was recorded in New York in December 1992.

Title: Star 34
Description: CARNIVAL OF SOULS director Herk Harvey and screenwriter John Clifford were employed for over thirty years by the Lawrence, Kansas–based industrial film giant the Centron Corporation. Between them, Harvey and Clifford made over four hundred films for Centron, from which the following segment has been selected.

Title: Michael Cera in Conversation
Description: The star of SUPERBAD and JUNO on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: A German Movie
Description: Conducted in 2004, this interview with Volker Schlöndorff features the writer-director discussing the making of YOUNG TÖRLESS and reflecting on its impact.

Title: Erik Skjoldbjærg and Stellan Skarsgård on INSOMNIA
Description: In this twenty-minute conversation, recorded in Oslo in January 2014, director Erik Skjoldbjærg and actor Stellan Skarsgård discuss the making of INSOMNIA, including the development of the script, the creation of the lead character of Engstrom, and their interest in inverting the genre norms of film noir.

Title: Making of AND EVERYTHING IS GOING FINE
Description: In this interview piece, produced in March 2012, director Steven Soderbergh, producer Kathleen Russo, and editor Susan Littenberg talk about the evolution of AND EVERYTHING IS GOING FINE.

Title: Shohei Imamura on THE INSECT WOMAN
Description: This twenty-one minute interview with Shohei Imamura was conducted by film critic Tadao Sato.

Title: The Clown Turns Prophet
Description: In this visual essay, Charlie Chaplin biographer Jeffrey Vance draws from film stills and historical imagery to discuss the making of THE GREAT DICTATOR, the anticipation surrounding Chaplin’s first all-talkie production, and the enduring influence of his bold satire.

Title: Adriano Aprà on Marco Ferreri and DILLINGER IS DEAD
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2009, Italian film historian Adriano Aprà discusses the career of Marco Ferreri and the singularity of DILLINGER IS DEAD.

Title: Luc Roeg on WALKABOUT
Description: Director Nicolas Roeg’s son Luc played the young boy in WALKABOUT (he is credited as Lucien John). Luc Roeg is now a London-based film producer whose credits include LET HIM HAVE IT, SPIDER, and Nicolas Roeg’s TWO DEATHS. In this video interview, recorded in 2010 in London, he discusses the shooting of WALKABOUT and his father’s work.

Title: Jean Gruault
Description: This interview with JULES AND JIM cowriter Jean Gruault was conducted in April 1986 at the Cinémathèque française in Paris for Rainer Gansera’s documentary WORKING WITH TRUFFAUT. Only a few minutes of it were used in that film, but the Criterion Collection was granted access to the footage and assembled this twenty-one-minute version.

Title: Needle
Description: Directed by Anahita Ghazvinizadeh • 2013 • United States /  /  /  / Lilly plans to get her ears pierced, until her parents’ incessant quarreling begins to cause problems. This skillful look at shifting family dynamics insightfully explores the stages children go through when processing change. Anahita Ghazvinizadeh’s subtle approach leads to a powerful payoff. The short film was the winner of the Cinéfondation award at the 2013 Cannes Film Festival.

Title: On BLUE
Description: The following 2011 video essay was written and narrated by film studies professor Annette Insdorf, author of “Double Lives, Second Chances: The Cinema of Krzysztof Kieślowski.”

Title: Louis Malle on THE FIRE WITHIN
Description: In September 1994 Louis Malle was interviewed for German television, by journalist Angelika Wittlich, about his career in cinema. The interview, which took place in his office in Paris, would be one of his last—he passed away on November 23, 1995. Presented here is an excerpt concerning THE FIRE WITHIN.

Title: The Black Balloon
Description: Directed by Josh Safdie and Benny Safdie • 2012 • United States /  / The black balloon, an alien in a crowded land, searches for some semblance of companionship after losing all of its friends.

Title: Ramona
Description: Directed by Andrei Cretulescu • 2015 • Romania /  / One girl. One car. One night. No coincidence.

Title: Reviving Harry Lime
Description: The following is a 2006 interview with Harry Alan Towers. Born in 1920, in London, Towers started as an actor and radio writer, before establishing a production company, Towers of London, in 1946. In the early 1950s, he produced two radio series starring and written by Orson Welles: “The Lives of Harry Lime” and “The Black Museum.”

Title: Collaborative Composition
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2014, film music scholar Jeff Smith, author of “The Sounds of Commerce,” analyzes William Alwyn’s unusual score for ODD MAN OUT.

Title: Tati Story
Description: This 2002 film by Jacques Tati scholar Stéphane Goudet traces Tati's life and work through clips from his films and rare photos and archival material.

Title: Tati Story
Description: This 2002 film by Jacques Tati scholar Stéphane Goudet traces Tati's life and work through clips from his films and rare photos and archival material.

Title: Locations and Effects
Description: In this short 2013 documentary, film writer John Bengtson and visual-effects expert Craig Barron discuss Harold Lloyd’s innovative use of stunts, locations, and effects in his “thrill pictures.”

Title: On Camera
Description: For his film FOR ALL MANKIND, director Al Reinert chose to record audio-only interviews with the Apollo astronauts. Here, Reinert presents a compilation of on-camera interviews with fifteen astronauts, excerpted from a few of his favorite films about the Apollo missions and from two events for the fortieth anniversaries of Apollo 7 and Apollo 8.

Title: Anecdotes from EUROPA
Description: This short 2005 documentary about EUROPA’s production features interviews with film historian Peter Schepelern, actor Jean-Marc Barr, producer Peter Aalbaek Jensen, assistant director Tomas Gislason, cowriter Niels Vorsel, and prop master Peter Grant.

Title: Gunnel Lindblom and Birgitta Pettersson
Description: In these interviews, conducted in Stockholm in August 2005, actors Gunnel Lindblom and Birgitta Pettersson reflect on working with director Ingmar Bergman and their experiences making THE VIRGIN SPRING.

Title: On the Comprehensive Version of MR. ARKADIN
Description: In the following documentary, produced in 2006, film historians and archivists Stefan Drössler and Claude Bertemes discuss the principles behind the creation of a new, unique version of MR. ARKADIN. Director and Orson Welles confidant Peter Bogdanovich shares his understanding of Welles’s intentions and style to address the differences in the edit.

Title: Ichikawa and Curtis on FIRES ON THE PLAIN
Description: The following interviews with director Kon Ichikawa and actor Mickey Curtis were recorded in 2005 and 2006. The two reminisce about their experiences making FIRES ON THE PLAIN.

Title: Werner Herzog Eats His Shoe
Description: Directed by Les Blank • 1980 • United States /  / As a result of a lost bet with his assistant, Errol Morris, director Werner Herzog must eat his own shoe.

Title: Christopher Hobbs on THE LONG DAY CLOSES
Description: In this interview, production designer Christopher Hobbs describes building sets for THE LONG DAY CLOSES, creating the special effects, and the unique process of reconstructing director Terence Davies’s childhood memories. The interview was conducted at Hobbs’s home in France in September 2013.

Title: Claire Denis on PARIS, TEXAS
Description: Filmmaker Claire Denis served as first assistant director on PARIS, TEXAS. She appears here in conversation with critic Kent Jones in October 2009.

Title: Robert Altman and Garry Trudeau on TANNER ’88
Description: In this video discussion recorded in June 2004, director Robert Altman and writer Garry Trudeau reminisce about their shared political interests and successful collaboration on the groundbreaking series TANNER ’88.

Title: Michael Fitzgerald on WISE BLOOD
Description: Presented here is a 2009 interview with Michael Fitzgerald, whose production credits include THE PLEDGE, COLOR ME KUBRICK, and THE THREE BURIALS OF MELQUIADES ESTRADA. WISE BLOOD was his first film, and he worked with John Huston again on 1984’s UNDER THE VOLCANO.

Title: God Respects Us When We Work, but Loves Us When We Dance
Description: Directed by Les Blank • 1968 • United States /  / Hippies and flower children dance and create rituals at the historic Los Angeles "Love-In" of Easter Sunday, 1967.

Title: Shooting the OPEC Sequence of CARLOS
Description: This documentary shows how director Olivier Assayas and his crew re-created the historic events of December 21, 1975, when Carlos the Jackal and his team raided OPEC headquarters in Vienna during a meeting of the group’s ministers. It was shot on the set of CARLOS and directed by Arnaud Giocomini, for Film en Stock.

Title: Seijun Suzuki, 1997
Description: The following interview with director Seijun Suzuki was recorded during a retrospective of his work by the Japan Foundation and Los Angeles Filmforum at the Nuart Theatre in Los Angeles in March 1997.

Title: Scénario de SAUVE QUI PEUT (LA VIE)
Description: In 1979, director Jean-Luc Godard submitted the following 20-minute video to the Centre national du cinéma, in place of a screenplay, to secure financing for his new film, EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF.

Title: Chantal Akerman: On JEANNE DIELMAN
Description: This interview with director Chantal Akerman was conducted in Paris in April 2009.

Title: René Clair on I MARRIED A WITCH
Description: In this audio interview from the late fifties, director René Clair discusses the differences between working in commercial and experimental cinema, as well as the overall state of the art of film. The interview was conducted in New York by film historian Gideon Bachmann, for his radio program “The Film Art.”

Title: Borom sarret
Description: Directed by Ousmane Sembène • 1963 • Senegal /  /  /  / This groundbreaking short film, which won first prize at the 1963 Touris Film Festival in France, was the directorial debut of Ousmane Sembène. /  /  /  / Restored in 2013 by the Cineteca di Bologna/L’Immagine Ritrovata laboratory and Éclair, in association with The Film Foundation’s World Cinema Project; INA, Institut National de l’Audiovisuel; and the Sembène Estate.  Restoration funded by Doha Film Institute.

Title: PERSONA’s Prologue: A Poem in Images
Description: The following visual essay by Ingmar Bergman scholar Peter Cowie, produced in 2013, focuses on the first seven minutes of PERSONA.

Title: Angelo Badalamenti on TWIN PEAKS: FIRE WALK WITH ME
Description: The following is a 2017 interview with composer Angelo Badalamenti.

Title: Tokuzo Tanaka on UGETSU
Description: The first assistant director on UGETSU, Tokuzo Tanaka would later go on to direct several episodes of the famous ZATOICHI film series, starring Shintaro Katsu. He was interviewed in Tokyo, in May 2005, about his work with director Kenji Mizoguchi.

Title: Hollis Frampton
Description: In 1978, filmmaker Hollis Frampton was interviewed by filmmaker Adele Friedman for the Video Data Bank at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. Presented here are excerpts from that conversation.

Title: Double Obsession: Seki, Sada, and Oshima
Description: Nagisa Oshima’s EMPIRE OF PASSION is often paired with this preceding film, the sexually explicit IN THE REALM OF THE SENSES (1976). In this 2009 video essay, Catherine Russell, author and professor of film studies at Concordia University in Montreal, looks at the two films side by side.

Title: Timothy Corrigan on THE TIN DRUM
Description: In this 2012 interview, film scholar Timothy Corrigan (“New German Cinema: The Displaced Image”) discusses the themes and style of THE TIN DRUM and its place in the history of German cinema.

Title: Dino Risi on IL SORPASSO
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2004 by film critic Jean A. Gili, director Dino Risi discusses the true stories that inspired IL SORPASSO, why Vittorio Gassman was an unexpected choice for the leading role, and the film’s lasting influence on Italian cinema.

Title: Everything Is Beautiful: Fashion
Description: This second segment in a three-part program from 2005, produced by Les Films de Mon Oncle, focuses on the costumes of MON ONCLE.

Title: Sheila Sim on A CANTERBURY TALE
Description: The following video interview with actress Sheila Sim (Lady Attenborough) was taped in London in February 2006.

Title: Jenny Agutter on WALKABOUT
Description: The following interview with actor Jenny Agutter was conducted in 2008 for Potemkine Productions in France. In it, she discusses how she came to be cast in WALKABOUT and what it was like to work with director Nicolas Roeg and actor David Gulpilil.

Title: A Bucket of Water and a Glass Matte
Description: In this 2010 program, Craig Barron and Ben Burtt, leading experts in the fields of visual and sound effects, respectively, discuss the techniques used and choices made by Charlie Chaplin and his crew on MODERN TIMES.

Title: Otar Iosseliana on Jean Vigo
Description: In this 2001 interview, Georgian-French filmmaker Otar Iosseliani (CHASING BUTTERFLIES; FAREWELL, HOME SWEET HOME) talks about the influence that Jean Vigo has had on his own work.

Title: The Wurlitzer: Nathan Barr and Mark Herman
Description: Presented here are two rarely seen Harold Lloyd shorts: Over the Fence (1917), the first "Glasses Character" film, and That's Him (1918). Lloyd lost many of his early films in a fire, and these have been restored from the best existing elements-a 9.5 mm print and a 28 mm print, respectively-and are accompanied by new scores performmed by Mark Herman on a historic Wurlitzer theater pipe organ owned by film and television composer Nathan Barr. Also included are a discussion about these early film formats by Dino Everett, archivist at the University of Souther California's Hugh M. Hefner Moving Image Archive, and a video tour of the Wurlitzer organ lead by Barr and Herman.

Title: Harriet Andersson on CRIES AND WHISPERS
Description: In this conversation, recorded in Stockholm in January 2012, film historian Peter Cowie and actor Harriet Andersson talk about her work in CRIES AND WHISPERS.

Title: Renato Berta and William Lubtchansky, 1981
Description: In this 1981 German television program, “Godards Kameramänner,” directed by Michael Klier and part of the series “Kino 81,” cinematographers Renato Berta and William Lubtchansky discuss their collaborative effort on EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF.

Title: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar in Conversation
Description: The athlete and author on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Remembering Reno
Description: In the following conversation, filmed in Los Angeles in August 2017, director Donna Deitch, cinematographer Robert Elswit, and production designed Jeannine Oppewall discuss their collaboration in creating the look of DESERT HEARTS.

Title: Jean-Pierre Berthomé on LE PLAISIR
Description: Max Ophuls adapted three short stories by Guy de Maupassant for his film LE PLAISIR. In this piece, created in 2008, film scholar Jean-Pierre Berthomé discusses Ophuls’s original script, in which a different short story, “Paul’s Mistress,” makes up the third episode in place of “The Model.” Berthomé examines how and why various changes were made to thte script and what effect these had on the finished film.

Title: Samba Gadjigo on Ousmane Sembène
Description: In this 2016 piece, filmmaker and professor of French Samba Gadjigo (SEMBENE!) characterizes what defines the work of Ousmane Sembène.

Title: Meet the Carveths
Description: In this 2013 interview, shot in Toronto, “Fangoria” editor in chief Chris Alexander talks to actors Art Hindle and Cindy Hinds about THE BROOD.

Title: NIGHT ON EARTH Commentary: Los Angeles
Description: Recorded in 2007, this audio commentary features director of photography Frederick Elmes and location sound mixer Drew Kunin.

Title: Functions of Film Sound
Description: This 2013 visual essay sets clips from A MAN ESCAPED to a reading of “Functions of Film Sound,” a chapter from David Bordwell and Kristin Thompson’s book “Film Art.” The chapter analyzes the sound design of A MAN ESCAPED as a means of discussing the use of sound in film. The text is read by actor Dan Stewart.

Title: Alfred Hitchcock and Peter Bogdanovich: 1963
Description: In this audio excerpt from an interview conducted in 1963, Alfred Hitchcock talks to filmmaker Peter Bogdanovich about his early years as a director.

Title: All the Boys Are Called Patrick
Description: Directed by Jean-Luc Godard • 1957 • France /  / A man makes dates with two women on the same day without realizing that they are best friends. Directed by Jean-Luc Godard.

Title: Jon Else on THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK
Description: In this 2011 program, filmmaker Jon Else, director of the UC Berkeley documentary program, takes a closer look at director Robert Epstein’s THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK.

Title: Louis Malle, 1994
Description: On September 22, 1994, just over a year before his death, THE LOVERS director Louis Malle was interviewed by journalist Angelika Wittlich at his office in Paris.

Title: Barbara Sukowa on LOLA
Description: Actor Barbara Sukowa began her career in the German theater. In this 2003 interview she discusses her move into film under the direction of Rainer Werner Fassbinder. In 1981, Sukowa starred in Fassbinder’s LOLA, as well as Margarethe von Trotta’s MARIANNE AND JULIANE. She has since worked with Lars von Trier, Michael Cimino, and David Cronenberg.

Title: Édgar Ramírez on CARLOS
Description: This interview with actor Édgar Ramírez was shot in Tenerife, Spain, in June 2011.

Title: It’s Intentional: Costa-Gavras on Z
Description: In this 2009 interview, director Costa-Gavras recalls Greece’s volatile post–World War II era, the making of Z, and the film’s timely release.

Title: Bibi Andersson, Ingmar Bergman, and Liv Ullmann
Description: In the following excerpt from an interview originally recorded for Swedish television in 1966, PERSONA’s director and lead actors discuss the evolution of the film and their individual interpretations of it.

Title: Bernard Tavernier
Description: This introduction to THE MARSEILLE TRILOGY by filmmaker Bertrand Tavernier was recorded in Paris in 2017.

Title: Mike Figgis on THE BROWNING VERSION
Description: New video interview with Mike Figgis, director of the 1994 remake.

Title: Interview with Gerard Feil
Description: In this interview, LORD OF THE FLIES cameraman and editor Gerald Feil examines specific scenes from the film and discusses some of the technical obstacles that arose during production.

Title: Sunday in Peking
Description: Directed by Chris Marker • 1956 • France /  / Chris Marker's documentary on Peking offers his thoughts on the people, culture and history of the city.

Title: Uncle Yanco
Description: Directed by Agnès Varda • 1967 • France /  /  /  / In her effervescent first California film, Agnès Varda delves into her own family history. The short documentary UNCLE YANCO features Varda tracking down a Greek emigrant relative she’s never met, discovering an artist and kindred soul leading a bohemian life in Sausalito. /  /  /  / Restored by the Cineteca di Bologna at L’Immagine Ritrovata in association with Ciné-Tamaris and The Film Foundation. Restoration funding provided by the Annenberg Foundation, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA) and The Film Foundation.

Title: Gaudí, Catalunya, 1959
Description: In 1959 Hiroshi Teshigahara shot the following 16 mm footage of he and his father’s first trip to Barcelona and the outlying Catalonian countryside, including a visit to the home of Salvador Dali in Port Lligat. The footage was recorded without sound.

Title: Outtakes: George Ball
Description: As undersecretary of state to President John F. Kennedy, George Ball was an early opponent of America’s military involvement in Vietnam. In Lyndon B. Johnson’s administration, he was one of the few advisers to argue against the U.S.’s escalation of the war. He resigned in 1966. In these excerpts, he discusses his roles in both administrations.

Title: Jane Shattuc on EIGHT HOURS DON’T MAKE A DAY
Description: The following interview with Jane Shattuc, professor of visual and media arts at Emerson College and author of “Television, Tabloids, and Tears: Fassbinder and Popular Culture,” was conducted in June 2018.

Title: Rodeo
Description: Directed by Carroll Ballard • 1969 • United States /  / This twenty-minute documentary from 1969 follows champion bull rider Larry Mahan as he competes in the 1968 National Rodeo Finals in Oklahoma City.

Title: James Quandt Video Essay
Description: The following video essay about PITFALL, by James Quandt of the TIFF Cinematheque, was recorded in 2007.

Title: David Allen Appreciation: THE MAGIC TREASURE
Description: EQUINOX’s effects animator, David Allen, was a revered figure within the effects and stop-motion animation community until his untimely death, in 1999. Presented here is piece of his best and rarest work: a puppet-animated fairy tale called THE MAGIC TREASURE.

Title: Tadao Sato on TWENTY-FOUR EYES
Description: This 2008 video interview with Tadao Sato (“Currents in Japanese Cinema”) features the renowned film historian’s insightful observations on the social and cinematic resonance of TWENTY-FOUR EYES.

Title: Captain Kidd’s Kids
Description: Directed by Hal Roach • 1919 •  /  / After a wild bachelor party, a boy finds himself aboard a sailing vessel where he encounters numerous adventures in this short film.

Title: Reflecting Reality
Description: Conducted in 2002, this interview features IL POSTO writer-director Ermanno Olmi reminiscing about the film and his career. Film critic (and occasional Olmi collaborator) Tullio Kezich also offers his thoughts.

Title: Emmanuelle Riva on HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR
Description: In the first of these two interviews, actor Emmanuelle Riva speaks with François Chalais on the occasion of the debut of HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR, in which she had her first starring role, at the 1959 Cannes Film Festival. In the second, shot in 2003, she sits down with the Criterion Collection to discuss the film.

Title: Errol Morris on GATES OF HEAVEN
Description: This interview with director Errol Morris was conducted in Cambridge, Massachusetts, in October 2014.

Title: Raoul Coutard on JULES AND JIM
Description: Cinematographer Raoul Coutard shot films for many of the French New Wave’s most celebrated directors, including Jean-Luc Godard and François Truffaut. In this 2003 interview in Paris, he recalls his work on JULES AND JIM.

Title: Howard Hughes Press Conference
Description: In F FOR FAKE, director Orson Welles uses excerpts from a 1972 press conference that Howard Hughes conducted, by telephone, in order to discredit the Clifford Irving “autobiography” of him. In the following piece, audio of Hughes’s answers is accompanied by text of the reporters’ questions.

Title: Theresa Russell
Description: BAD TIMING marked the first time Theresa Russell worked with director Nicolas Roeg, whom she later married. In this interview, recorded in Los Angeles, in January 2005, she discusses the film and its impact on her life.

Title: Chaplin’s Napoleon
Description: Charlie Chaplin long wanted to make a film about Napoleon Bonaparte, working and reworking his concept over a number of years—until ultimately it morphed into THE GREAT DICTATOR. The following visual essay by Cecilia Cenciarelli, archivist and head of the Cineteca di Bologna’s Progetto Chaplin, traces the trajectory of Chaplin’s Napoleon project.

Title: THE PIANO TEACHER Postsync Sessions
Description: The following nineteen minutes of footage offer a behind-the-scenes look at the audio postsync sessions for THE PIANO TEACHER and feature director Michael Haneke and actor Isabelle Huppert.

Title: Visual Effects in THE GOLD RUSH
Description: In this 2012 interview, visual effects expert Craig Barron looks at the techniques used to create some of the classic set pieces in THE GOLD RUSH.

Title: Jane Campion: The Film School Years
Description: This conversation between critic Peter Thompson and Jane Campion took place in 1989, following the success of Campion’s short films. It was produced for the Australian Television Radio and Film School, where she studied.

Title: The Art of Effects: THE GOLD RUSH
Description: This installment of our ongoing series on special effects focuses on the techniques used to create some of the classic set pieces in Charlie Chaplin’s groundbreaking 1925 film THE GOLD RUSH.

Title: NIGHT ON EARTH Commentary: Paris
Description: Recorded in 2007, this audio commentary features director of photography Frederick Elmes and location sound mixer Drew Kunin.

Title: Jackie Coogan: The First Child Star
Description: The following video essay by Charlie Chaplin scholar Lisa Haven, on THE KID actor Jackie Coogan, was produced in 2015.

Title: “Variances”: Patricia Highsmith, 1971
Description: This interview with PURPLE NOON writer Patricia Highsmith, conducted by Agnès Thierre and Pierre Lambert and directed by Lambert, first aired on the French television program “Variances” on August 3, 1971.

Title: Our Paul: Remembering Paul Robeson
Description: In this video program, produced in 2006, actors Ruby Dee and James Earl Jones and filmmaker William Greaves recall Paul Robeson, his impact on African-American culture, and the controversy that plagued his final years.

Title: SHAKE! OTIS AT MONTEREY Commentary 1
Description: The following commentary features music historian Peter Guralnick and was recorded in Boston in the winter of 2002. This commentary is a song-by-song reading of the film.

Title: SHAKE! OTIS AT MONTEREY Commentary 2
Description: The following commentary features music historian Peter Guralnick and was recorded in Boston in the winter of 2002. This commentary is a look at Otis’s career, pre- and post-Monterey.

Title: Tsutomu Yamazaki on HIGH AND LOW
Description: The following interview with award-winning actor Tsutomu Yamazaki, who plays the kidnapper, Takeuchi, in HIGH AND LOW, was recorded in Tokyo in 2008.

Title: Shake! Otis at Monterey
Director: D. A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus
Description: Directed by D. A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus • 1986 • United States /  / Redding, a venerable star of Memphis's Stax record label, seduced the "love crowd" in one of his best, and last, performances. Shake! Otis at Monterey, feature the entire set of this legendary musician, a performance that has entered rock-and-roll mythology.

Title: George Sluizer on THE VANISHING
Description: In this interview with George Sluizer, conducted at his home in France in May 2014, the director discusses the challenges of adapting THE VANISHING from its source novel, the psychology of its characters, and his approach to building suspense.

Title: Raoul Coutard on WEEKEND
Description: Cinematographer Raoul Coutard recalls working with director Jean-Luc Godard on WEEKEND.

Title: Challenging the Viewer
Description: In this 2018 program, critic, filmmaker, and festival programmer Tony Rayns discusses director Lino Brocka, MANILA IN THE CLAWS OF LIGHT, and the social context in which the film was made.

Title: Like Home
Description: In this 2013 visual essay, Jacques Tati scholar Stéphane Goudet explores the director’s stylistic choices in PLAYTIME.

Title: Mysteries of Life
Description: Conducted in 2002, this interview features I FIDANZATI writer/director Ermanno Olmi reminiscing about the film and his career. Film critic/historian (and occasional Olmi collaborator) Tullio Kezich also offers his thoughts.

Title: Donna Deitch and Jane Lynch on DESERT HEARTS
Description: Wanting to make a film about a lesbian relationship that didn’t end in tragedy, director Donna Deitch spent five years working on DESERT HEARTS. Its release in 1985 was a landmark moment in queer cinema. In this conversation, recorded in Los Angeles in 2017, Deitch and actor Jane Lynch discuss the making of the film and its significance for Lynch.

Title: Jean Seberg
Description: After a much-publicized but brief stint in Hollywood, Jean Seberg was selected by Jean-Luc Godard to star in BREATHLESS. It was to become the legendary actress’s best-remembered role. This 2007 video essay by Mark Rappaport, director of the 1995 film FROM THE JOURNALS OF JEAN SEBERG, reveals the true story behind her iconic face.

Title: Visual Effects in FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT
Description: In this 2013 interview, visual effects expert Craig Barron looks at the creation of some of FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT’s thrilling set pieces.

Title: Tadao Sato on THE ONLY SON
Description: This interview with Japanese film critic and scholar Tadao Sato was conducted in November 2003 in Tokyo.

Title: The Three Andreis
Description: This short 1966 documentary about the making of ANDREI RUBLEV is a project by Dina Musatova, who had studied at the film school VGIK with director Andrei Tarkovsky. This film is held by the Russian State Documentary Film & Photo Archive in Krasnogorsk.

Title: Abbas Kiarostami on TASTE OF CHERRY
Description: Dr. Jamsheed Akrami, professor of communication at William Paterson University, conducted this interview with director Abbas Kiarostami prior to the release of TASTE OF CHERRY, in 1997. It was recorded for Dr. Akrami’s 2000 documentary on Iranian cinema, FRIENDLY PERSUASION.

Title: B. Ruby Rich and José Antonio Évora
Description: This program features interview with film critics B. Ruby Rich and José Antonio Évora. They were recorded in San Francisco and Miami in 2018.

Title: Liv Ullmann on Ingmar Bergman
Description: The celebrated actor Liv Ullmann appeared in ten of Ingmar Bergman’s films. In this 2013 interview, conducted in New York, she discusses their work together.

Title: Chen Chang on A BRIGHTER SUMMER DAY
Description: Taiwanese actor Chen Chang was only a teenager when he got the lead role in A BRIGHTER SUMMER DAY. He would go on to become a major star, appearing in such films as HAPPY TOGETHER; CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON; and THE GRANDMASTER. In this 2014 interview, Chang discusses his breakthrough debut.

Title: Jhumpa Lahiri in Conversation
Description: The Pulitzer Prize–winning author on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Vive le Tour
Description: Directed by Louis Malle • 1962 • France /  / In his short documentary Vive le Tour, Louis Malle presents his energetic evocation of the Tour de France. This, Humain, trop humain, and Place de la République, Louis Malle's three French-set documentaries, reveal, in an eclectic array of ways, the director's eternal fascination with, and respect for, the everyday lives of everyday people.

Title: Self Portrait ’92
Description: Director Vilgot Sjoman made “Selft Portrait ’92” for Swedish television. Presented here are excerpts from this program, selected and edited for this release by the director.

Title: Dudley Andrew on THE LIFE OF OHARU
Description: This 2013 illustrated audio essay, written and narrated by film scholar Dudley Andrew, explores director Kenji Mizoguchi’s interest in the theater, art, and fiction of seventeenth- and eighteenth-century Japan, and locates the roots of his idea for the adaptation THE LIFE OF OHARU in his second postwar film, UTAMARO AND HIS FIVE WOMEN.

Title: Redefining Cinema
Description: This 2017 interview with film scholar James Steffen (“The Cinema of Sergei Parajanov”) addresses the making of THE COLOR OF POMEGRANATES.

Title: Mary Karr in Conversation
Description: The author of “Lit” and “The Liars’ Club” on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Witness to the Times
Description: Director Francesco Rosi and film critic Tullio Kezich, who chronicled the production of SALVATORE GIULIANO, discuss the filmmaker's start in cinema and his touchstone film, in this 2003 program.

Title: Heart of Lightness
Description: The following is a 2014 interview with RIDE IN THE WHIRLWIND director Monte Hellman and assistant director Gary Kurtz.

Title: Phil Walden on Otis Redding
Description: Phil Walden was Otis Redding’s manager from 1959 until Redding’s death in 1967. This interview was recorded in Atlanta in the spring of 2002.

Title: 24 Hours in the Life of a Clown
Description: Directed by Jean-Pierre Melville • 1946 • France /  / Jean-Pierre Melville's first directorial effort was this 1946 short film about a clown and his partner, who find inspiration one day in the streets for their performance in the circus that night.

Title: Ginette Vincendeau on LE SAMOURAÏ
Description: “Melville on Melville,” Rui Nogueira’s 1971 book of interviews with Jean-Pierre Melville, was for decades the only English-language work devoted to the director’s films. In 2003, cinema historian Ginette Vincendeau added “Jean-Pierre Melville, An American in Paris.” In this 2005 video interview, Vincendeau shares her thoughts on LE SAMOURAÏ.

Title: Art
Description: Directed by Adrian Sitaru • 2014 • Romania /  / After a casting session, two filmmakers found the perfect 14-year-old girl to star in their new movie. Now, they have to convince the reluctant mother to let her daughter play the role of a sexually abused child. What follows is a witty argumentation on proper parenting and on the abuses and sacrifices made in the name of great works of art.

Title: David Bordwell on GOOD MORNING
Description: In the following interview, conducted in February 2017, film scholar David Bordwell analyzes the evolution of director Yasujiro Ozu’s style by comparing the 1932 silent film I WAS BORN, BUT . . . with the filmmaker’s own 1959 reworking of the story, GOOD MORNING.

Title: Jonathan Lethem in Conversation
Description: The author of “The Feral Detective” on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: And the Whole Sky Fit in the Dead Cow's Eye
Description: Directed by Francisca Alegría • 2016 • Chile /  / Emeteria (85) is visited by the ghost of her patrón, Teodoro. She believes he has come to take her to the afterlife, but he has more devastating news.

Title: Murray Melvin on A TASTE OF HONEY
Description: Murray Melvin’s performance as Geoffrey in A TASTE OF HONEY brought him international acclaim, including the award for best actor at the 1962 Cannes Film Festival. In this interview, recorded in London in May 2016, Melvin (who also originated his role in the play) discusses the film’s production.

Title: Véronique and Her Dunce
Description: Directed by Eric Rohmer • 1958 • France /  / In this short film from director Eric Rohmer, Véronique tutors a perplexing young boy.

Title: Stig Björkman on INGRID BERGMAN: IN HER OWN WORDS
Description: Director Stig Björkman comments on the making of INGRID BERGMAN: IN HER OWN WORDS in this 2016 interview.

Title: Jérémie Renier and Olivier Gourmet on LA PROMESSE
Description: The following 2012 program features interviews with actors Jérémie Renier and Olivier Gourmet.

Title: A Day’s Pleasure
Description: Directed by Charles Chaplin • 1919 • United States /  / Charlie Chaplin stars in this comedy short about a middle class family man who encounters one difficulty after another while attempting to make a simple excursion by car and boat with his wife and kids.

Title: A Cajun Celebration
Description: This short documentary about DRY WOOD and HOT PEPPER, in 2014, features interviews with Maureen Gosling, Les Blank’s collaborator on the films; Blank’s son beau; and filmmaker Taylor Hackford.

Title: Lasse Hallström on MY LIFE AS A DOG
Description: This interview with director Lasse Hallström was recorded in the spring of 2002.

Title: Lucrecia Martel
Description: In this piece, produced in the fall of 2014, LA CIÉNAGA director Lucrecia Martel examines her inspirations and approach to cinema.

Title: Close Ties
Description: Directed by Zofia Kowalewska • 2016 • Poland /  /  /  / A Polish couple on the cusp of celebrating their forty-fifth anniversary confronts still-fresh emotional wounds in this tender documentary exploration of commitment, betrayal, and forgiveness.

Title: Jacqueline Bisset on UNDER THE VOLCANO
Description: The role of Yvonne in John Huston’s UNDER THE VOLCANO remains one of the high points in acclaimed actress Jacqueline Bisset’s career. The following video interview was recorded in June 2007 in Los Angeles.

Title: Adriano Aprà on EUROPE ’51
Description: In this 2011 interview, film critic Adriano Aprà discusses how, in EUROPE ’51, director Roberto Rossellini was working in a more didactic mode than in his earlier films, one that anticipated his later television work.

Title: Lois Sutcliffe Smith on Lindsay Anderson
Description: Lois Sutcliffe Smith, who gave THIS SPORTING LIFE director Lindsay Anderson his first opportunity in filmmaking with MEET THE PIONEERS, remained a close friend of Lindsay’s. This video interview with Smith was recorded in March 2007 in London.

Title: Les mistons
Description: Directed by François Truffaut • 1957 • France /  / The story takes place in provincial France, where a group of young boys ("mistons" roughly translates "brats") are infatuated with a beautiful young woman. Jealous of her passionate affair, they conspire to make mischief for the woman and her boyfriend.

Title: Truffaut and Rohmer on L’ATALANTE
Description: This conversation between New Wave directors François Truffaut and Eric Rohmer, titled “Postface à L’ATALANTE,” was presented following a 1968 French television broadcast of the film.

Title: Interpreting Reality
Description: In this 18-minute piece, produced in June 2013, cowriter-director Noah Baumbach, director of photography Sam Levy, and Pascal Dangin, who did the film’s color mastering, discuss digital filmmaking, the late cinematographer Harry Savides, and how they achieved the look of FRANCES HA.

Title: Five Miles Out
Description: Directed by Andrew Haigh • 2009 • United Kingdom /  / An adolescent girl meets a boy while on holiday with her cousins. This short film, created in 2009 by Andrew Haigh, provides some insight into the director’s evolving vision.

Title: LISTEN TO BRITAIN (Jennings)
Description: A portrait of England during World War II, this short propaganda film is considered a landmark in nonfiction filmmaking for its deft montage and visual poetry.

Title: Philip Kaufman in Conversation
Description: The director of THE UNBEARABLE LIGHTNESS OF BEING on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Rita Tushingham on A TASTE OF HONEY
Description: Rita Tushingham’s performance as Jo in A TASTE OF HONEY brought her international acclaim, including the award for best actress at the 1962 Cannes Film Festival. In this interview, recorded in London in May 2016, Tushingham discusses the film’s production.

Title: Senator Nixon’s Fund Crisis Speech
Description: The following program was broadcast nationally on September 23, 1952.

Title: Apichatpong Weerasethakul
Description: This program with MYSTERIOUS OBJECT AT NOON director Apichatpong Weerasethakul was produced in 2017.

Title: Alain Renoir
Description: The son of Jean Renoir and the grandson of Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Alain Renoir worked as an assistant cameraman on two of his father’s films—LA BÊTE HUMAINE and THE RULES OF THE GAME—before coming to the United States and embarking on a career as a professor of comparative literature. This interview took place at his home in California in 2003.

Title: Zbigniew Zamachowski and Julie Delpy on WHITE
Description: In this program, produced in 2011, Polish actor Zbigniew Zamachowski and French actor Julie Delpy share their memories about the making of WHITE and discuss their admiration for director Krzysztof Kieślowski.

Title: Mike Leigh on THE MIKADO
Description: Director Mike Leigh dramatized Gilbert and Sullivan’s creation of “The Mikado” in his award-winning 1999 film TOPSY-TURVY, which required extensive research on the duo and the opera. In this video interview, recorded in 2010, Leigh brings his unique perspective to the 1939 film version of the opera.

Title: Peter Cowie
Description: The following interview on THE MAGIC FLUTE with film scholar Peter Cowie, author of “Ingmar Bergman: A Critical Biography,” was produced in 2018.

Title: Bill Hader in Conversation
Description: The actor and comedian on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: Factory
Description: Directed by Krzysztof Kieślowski • 1970 • Poland /  /  /  / Krzysztof Kieślowski began his career making documentaries. Presented here is FACTORY, one of his nonfiction shorts.

Title: Willem Dafoe: Agent of Fantasy
Description: The following is a 2010 interview with actor Willem Dafoe.

Title: BLIND CHANCE Unshelved
Description: In the following interview, produced in 2015, Polish film critic Tadeusz Sobolewski considers the political context of Krzysztof Kieślowski’s BLIND CHANCE, the film’s censorship and delayed release, and its significance within Kieślowski’s body of work.

Title: A Day with the Boys
Description: Directed by Clu Gulager • 1969 • United States /  / Directed by character actor Clu Gulager and shot by cinematographer Laszlo Kovacs, this 1969 short film was an influence on David Gordon Green's GEORGE WASHINGTON.

Title: The Bergman Connection
Description: In this new visual essay, film scholar and Bergman biographer Peter Cowie traces the influence of Victor Sjöström and THE PHANTOM CARRIAGE on the films of Ingmar Bergman.

Title: Asparagus
Description: Directed by Suzan Pitt • 1979 • United States /  / Suzan Pitt's animated short throws open the doors of perception onto a shape-shifting vision of polymorphous sexuality. A landmark in the history of independent animation, ASPARAGUS is a mesmerizing exploration of the artist's inner world, and a viewing experience like no other.

Title: On-Set Footage
Description: The following 18 minutes of silent, black-and-white footage was shot during the production of PERSONA. It is presented here with audio commentary by Ingmar Bergman scholar Birgitta Steene.

Title: MERRY CHRISTMAS MR. LAWRENCE: On the Music
Description: In this interview, conducted in New York in 2010, actor and composer Ryuichi Sakamoto discusses the score for MERRY CHRISTMAS MR. LAWRENCE.

Title: That Obscure Source of Desire
Description: In this 2011 documentary, activist Susie Bright, author of “Big Sex, Little Death,” and UC Berkeley professor Linda Williams, author of “Screening Sex,” discuss BELLE DE JOUR’s representation of feminine sexuality and fantasy, and its themes of masochism, power, and desire, in terms of director Luis Buñuel’s surrealist aesthetic.

Title: Adriano Apra on THE FLOWERS OF ST. FRANCIS
Description: Filmed in Rome in 2004, this interview features film historian Adriano Apra.

Title: BLACK ORPHEUS and That Bossa Nova Sound!
Description: BLACK ORPHEUS introduced an international audience to the sights and sounds of Rio de Janeiro. In the following program, produced in 2010, jazz historian Gary Giddins and Brazilian author Ruy Castro recall the roots of the film’s score and the role it played in popularizing the bossa nova sound.

Title: Martin Scorsese
Description: The following introduction to TRANCES by filmmaker Martin Scorsese, founder of the World Cinema Project, was produced in 2013.

Title: Hou Hsiao-hsien and Edmond Wong on TAIPEI STORY
Description: This conversation between filmmakers Hou Hsiao-hsien (who plays the main character in TAIPEI STORY and cowrote the script) and Edmond Wong was produced in 2017.

Title: Dailies
Description: This silent 16 mm reel includes never-before-seen raw footage and alternate takes that were not used in NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD.

Title: Jeanne Moreau on ELEVATOR TO THE GALLOWS
Description: This interview with actor Jeanne Moreau was recorded at the Brasserie La Lorraine in Paris in 2005.

Title: In Their Own Voices
Description: This piece combines 1964 interviews with the Beatles with behind-the-scenes footage and photos.

Title: Renée Shafransky on Spalding Gray
Description: Renée Shafransky collaborated with Spalding Gray on a number of the latter’s monologues, including “Swimming to Cambodia,” “Monster in a Box,” and “Gray’s Anatomy.” In this interview, conducted in New York in March 2012, she discusses their process.

Title: Michael Cunningham in Conversation
Description: The author of “The Hours” on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title: John Nathan on ZATOICHI
Description: The following is a 2013 interview with filmmaker and Japanese-culture scholar John Nathan, who shares his memories of actor and filmmaker Shintaro Katsu, star of the ZATOICHI series.

Title: Arno Frisch
Description: The following interview with actor Arno Frisch was recorded in Berlin in December 2018.

Title: Alternate Opening
Description: This 18-minute opening sequence was included only in an early, 183-minute edit of FACES that was screened in Toronto in April 1968.

Title: Jean-Pierre Gorin on SANS SOLEIL
Description: Filmmaker, writer, and educator Jean-Pierre Gorin began his career as Jean-Luc Godard’s collaborator on the Dziga Vertov Group films, including TOUT VA BIEN. In this interview, recorded in 2005, he discusses his friend director Chris Marker and SANS SOLEIL.

Title: Jan-Christopher Horak on WESTFRONT 1918
Description: In this 2016 interview, Jan-Christopher Horak, director of the UCLA Film & Television Archive, discusses the importance of WESTFRONT 1918 to director G. W. Pabst’s career.

Title: Steve McQueen on HUNGER
Description: This interview with director Steve McQueen was conducted in 2009.

Title: Fritz Rasp on THE THREEPENNY OPERA
Description: Film historian Hans-Michael Bock filmed this interview with THE THREEPENNY OPERA star Fritz Rasp in 1972.

Title: Greil Marcus and D. A. Pennebaker on DONT LOOK BACK
Description: This conversation between music journalist and cultural critic Greil Marcus and director D. A. Pennebaker about DONT LOOK BACK was filmed in 2010.

Title: Home Movies
Description: Actor-director Harold Lloyd’s archive contains over a hundred hours of personal home movies. Here, his granddaughter Suzanne Lloyd narrates a selection of footage shot around the time that SPEEDY was made.

Title: Peter Hames on MARKETA LAZAROVÁ
Description: Film historian Peter Hames has written extensively on Central and Eastern European cinema. The following interview with him about MARKETA LAZAROVÁ was conducted in London in 2013.

Title: All at Sea
Description: ALL AT SEA is a home movie by Alistair Cooke featuring Chaplin and actress Paulette Goddard, presented with a score by Donald Sosin.

Title: The Bunting House
Description: In this video essay, created in 2017, art historian Steven Jacobs explores the roles that architecture, space, and setting play in THE LODGER.

Title: Guillermo del Toro on THE MAN WHO KNEW TOO MUCH
Description: This interview with filmmaker Guillermo del Toro, a dedicated fan of director Alfred Hitchcock and the author of the 1990 book “Alfred Hitchcock,” was conducted in 2012.

Title: Ronald Neame on THE HORSE’S MOUTH
In Search of Jazz
Description: In this interview with Jean Cocteau, taken from an episode of the French television series “In Search of Jazz,” the director talks about the music in his films. The program first aired on April 24, 1956.

Title: Tatsuya Nakadai on THE HUMAN CONDITION
