Description: In this new video interview with Tatsuya Nakadai, conducted in 2009, the screen legend discusses his landmark role as Kaji in THE HUMAN CONDITION.

Title: Todd Haynes on LE PLAISIR
Description: In this introduction, recorded in Hollywood in April 2005, director Todd Haynes reflects on the masterful filmmaking of LE PLAISIR. Please note: this interview contains remarks about the ending of the film.

Title: I Put A Spell On Me
Description: The following are excerpts from the 2001 documentary SCREAMIN’ JAY HAWKINS: I PUT A SPELL ON ME.

Title: Memphis Tour
Description: This 2010 documentary visits MYSTERY TRAIN’s locations and discusses the rich social and musical history of Memphis.

Title: For the Love of Music
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2011, Andrew Robinson, author of “Satyajit Ray: The Inner Eye,” discusses the making of THE MUSIC ROOM and the film’s cultural significance.

Title: Guillermo del Toro on CRONOS
Description: In this 2010 interview, director Guillermo del Toro offers his thoughts on CRONOS, including what the film means to him and its place in his diverse career.

Title: David Cairns on GOOD MORNING
Description: In this new video essay, David Cairns examines Yasujiro Ozu’s use of humor in his films.

Title: Diatoms
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1968 • France /  / Diatoms are explored through microscopic footage while their purpose and uses are explained.

Title: My Old Fiddle: A Visit with Tommy Jarrell in the Blue Ridge
Description: This seventeen-minute film, composed of footage shot during the making of SPROUT WINGS AND FLY, continues the story of Tommy Jarrell and reveals the origins of his famous fiddle.

Title: Manual of Arms
Description: Directed by Hollis Frampton • 1966 • United States /  / The film has the look of a New York loft, a certain overlay of gritty, claustrophobic funk that permeated that whole period. It's also a formalist's snapshot album. Those people were friends of mine during a fairly interesting time. We were all lepers, 'out-of-it,' or what have you, with the possible exception of Larry Poons.' , Hollis Frampton

Title: Shih Chun on A TOUCH OF ZEN
Description: In this new piece, actor Shih Chun addresses his longtime collaboration with director King Hu and his performance as Gu Sheng-zhai in A TOUCH OF ZEN.

Title: The Audacious Adventurer
Description: In this 2006 interview, filmmaker Bertrand Tavernier recalls his friend the director Michael Powell and Powell’s stories about the making of BLACK NARCISSUS.

Title: Eric Rentschler on BAAL
Description: The following interview with Eric Rentschler, a film historian and the Arthur Kingsley Porter Professor of Germanic languages and literature at Harvard University, was conducted in Cambridge, Massachusetts, in November 2017.

Title: Tag Gallagher Video Essay
Description: In this 2008 video essay, writer Tag Gallagher analyzes director Max Ophuls’s use of montage to create moments of passion and desire in his films, particularly THE EARRINGS OF MADAME DE . . .

Title: Suzanne Lloyd
Description: Suzanne Lloyd is the granddaughter of Harold Lloyd and was raised by him and his wife, Mildred Davis Lloyd, in Los Angeles. She is the president of Harold Lloyd Entertainment and has dedicated her career to preserving and promoting Harold’s film legacy. In this 2013 introduction, she discusses SAFETY LAST! and its place in his career.

Title: Kazuko Yoshiyuki and Tatsuya Fuji
Description: The following program, recorded in Tokyo in 2008, features interviews with EMPIRE OF PASSION actors Kazuko Yoshiyuki and Tatsuya Fuji, who play Seki and Toyoji.

Title: Jeff Smith on Georges Delerue
Description: Award-winning composer Georges Delerue wrote scores for more than 200 films—in addition to composing operas, ballets, chamber pieces, and more. He is perhaps best known for the eleven films he scored for François Truffaut. This audio essay, written by music historian Jeff Smith, explores Delerue’s music for SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER.

Title: Five Directors on THE BATTLE OF ALGIERS
Description: In this collection of interviews conducted in 2004, directors Spike Lee, Mira Nair, Julian Schnabel, Steven Soderbergh, and Oliver Stone discuss the influence, style, and importance of Gillo Pontecorvo’s film THE BATTLE OF ALGIERS.

Title: Swallowed
Description: Directed by Lily Baldwin • 2016 • United States /  /  /  / What if the ideal life you've meticulously constructed isn’t enough? Your swallowed truths, buried longings, become a parasite that lives off you, in you, with you. It’s a nagging reminder of the unrequited; a codependent affair. This breaking point is the film SWALLOWED. Sam, newly a mother, shops at a supermarket with her baby and husband Carlson. She throws a neighborhood shishkabob party in her den. Her family shares a Sunday breakfast. But through her smiles and picturesque tasks, there's a suppression. Sam’s grown something she can no longer contain. As she purges this parasite, we move inside her body and experience this wildness as a feverish dance.The parasite ejects us back into the kitchen of another woman, alone eating breakfast as she looks at a happy couple pictured on the back of her cereal box. It’s Sam and Carlson. What's beneath a picture? A dream within a dream. Horror meets dance, SWALLOWED suggests a complex truth to motherhood and domesticity.

Title: Tatsuya Fuji on IN THE REALM OF THE SENSES
Description: This interview with actor Tatsuya Fuji was conducted in 2009.

Title: Lafcadio Hearn
Description: In the nineteenth century, writer Lafcadio Hearn played a crucial role in popularizing Japanese folklore for Western audiences. Four of his stories provided the basis for Masaki Kobayashi’s KWAIDAN. In this piece, made in 2015, English literature scholar Christopher Benfey, editor of “Lafcadio Hearn: American Writings,” profiles Hearn.

Title: Sandrine Bonnaire on Maurice Pialat
Description: À NOS AMOURS was actor Sandrine Bonnaire’s feature debut. She went on to work with such filmmakers as Claude Chabrol and Jacques Rivette. In this interview, recorded in 2003, she describes her lasting on- and offscreen relationship with director Maurice Pialat.

Title: Madame Tutli-Putli
Description: Directed by Chris Lavis and Maciek Szczerbowski • 2007 • Canada /  / This stop-motion animated film takes viewers on an exhilarating existential journey into the fully imagined, tactile world of Madame Tutli-Putli. As she travels alone on the night train, weighed down with all her earthly possessions and the ghosts of her past, she faces both the kindness and menace of strangers. Finding herself caught up in a desperate metaphysical adventure, adrift between real and imagined worlds, Madame Tutli-Putli confronts her demons.

Title: Akira Mizuta Lippit on THE NAKED ISLAND
Description: The following interview with film scholar Akira Mizuta Lippit was conducted in Los Angeles in February 2016.

Title: Viva Maria!
Description: Directed by Agnieszka Smoczyńska • 2010 • Poland /  /  /  / This short documentary about opera singer Maria Fołtyn was directed by Agnieszka Smoczyńska in 2010, while she was a film student at the Wajda School in Warsaw.

Title: Emily Watson on BREAKING THE WAVES
Description: In the following interview, conducted in London in June 2013, Emily Watson discusses the challenges she faced in playing the complicated character Bess in BREAKING THE WAVES.

Title: The Short and Curlies
Description: Directed by Mike Leigh • 1987 • United Kingdom /  /  /  / David Thewlis and Alison Steadman star in this 1987 short comedy by Mike Leigh about a romance between a hairdresser’s daughter and a young man who communicates only through one-liners.

Title: Louis Malle, 1975
Description: During the production of his 1975 film BLACK MOON, Louis Malle was interviewed for Canadian television about his unusual start in filmmaking and his first feature, ELEVATOR TO THE GALLOWS.

Title: Ginette Vincendeau on LE SILENCE DE LA MER
Description: In this interview, conducted in November 2014, film professor Ginette Vincendeau, author of “Jean-Pierre Melville: An American in Paris,” discusses Melville’s remarkable film debut.

Title: Chantal Akerman: On Filmmaking
Description: The following footage is excerpted from “Chantal Akerman par Chantal Akerman,” a 1997 episode of the French television program “Cinéma, de notre temps.”

Title: David Lynch and Frederick Elmes on ERASERHEAD
Description: This interview with director David Lynch and cinematographer Frederick Elmes was shot in 1979 by filmmaker Tom Christie for his television production class at UCLA. It takes place at one of ERASERHEAD's locations in Los Angeles, where the Beverly Center shopping mall now stands.

Title: Anatomy of a Style
Description: A piece on Richard Lester's methods.

Title: The Last Cowboy
Description: The following is a 2014 interview with RIDE IN THE WHIRLWIND director Monte Hellman and chief wrangler Calvin Johnson.

Title: The Color of Armenian Land
Description: Directed by Mikhail Vartanov, this rarely screened impressionistic documentary from 1969 features footage of director Sergei Parajanov making THE COLOR OF POMEGRANATES.

Title: President Nixon’s Farewell to the White House Staff
Description: The following was broadcast live on August 9, 1974, from the East Room of the White House.

Title: An Artist of the Everyday
Description: In this interview, conducted in April 2013, sociology professor Priscilla Parkhurst Ferguson, the author of “Accounting for Taste: The Triumph of French Cuisine,” discusses the importance of cuisine to the French national identity, and its poignant evocation in BABETTE’S FEAST.

Title: Sarah Polley and Greta Gerwig on FRANCES HA
Description: The following conversation between actor and filmmaker Sarah Polley and the film’s cowriter and star, Greta Gerwig, was recorded in Toronto in July 2013.

Title: The Polish “Revolution”
Description: In this exclusive documentary, director Andrzej Wajda and longtime Polish film critic Jerzy Plazeski talk about the making of DANTON, the reaction of the French, and interpretations of the film as a statement on Polish politics and Solidarity movement.

Title: The Curve
Description: Directed by Edwige Shaki • 1999 • France /  / An artist falls for an art model who reminds him of a sculpture.

Title: Behind the Scenes of WILD STRAWBERRIES
Description: The following 16 minutes of silent footage was filmed by director Ingmar Bergman on the set of WILD STRAWBERRIES. It features voice-over by Jan Wengström, curator of archival film collections at the Swedish Film Institute.

Title: Tadao Sato on KURONEKO
Description: In this video interview, conducted in 2011, renowned Japanese-film critic Tadao Sato offers his insights on the cinematic accomplishments and cultural significance of KURONEKO

Title: Visconti’s Collaborators
Description: The following interviews, conducted in 2003, feature screenwriter Suso Cecchi d'Amico, film writers Laura Delli Colli and Lino Micciche, cinematographer Giuseppe Rotunno, and costume designer Piero Tosi discussing Luchino Visconti and the evolution of LE NOTTI BIANCHE’s production—from costume design to actor auditions.

Title: Adriano Aprà on PAISAN
Description: Film historian and teacher Adriano Aprà has devoted much of his career to Roberto Rossellini and his films, directing the 1992 film ROSSELLINI VISTO DA ROSSELLINI, editing the 1992 collection of Rossellini essays and interviews “My Method,” and writing the 2006 book “In viaggio con Rossellini.” In this 2009 interview, Aprà discusses PAISAN.

Title: Harry Baer on FOX AND HIS FRIENDS
Description: This interview with actor Harry Baer was conducted in Berlin in September 2016.

Title: Melvüt Akkaya on LAW OF THE BORDER
Description: This interview with filmmaker Melvüt Akkaya was produced in 2017.

Title: DONKEY SKIN and the Thinkers
Description: In this 2008 discussion, film critic Camille Taboulay, psychoanalysts Lucille Durrmeyer and Jean-Claude Polack, and seventeenth-century literature specialist Liliane Picciola talk about DONKEY SKIN’s themes of incest, love, and childhood fantasy.

Title: MODERN TIMES: A Closer Look
Description: In this 2010 visual essay, Chaplin historian Jeffrey Vance, author of “Chaplin: Genius of the Cinema,” draws from a wealth of production photography to discuss the making of MODERN TIMES.

Title: Peter Cowie and Jörn Donner
Description: In this conversation, recorded in Stockholm in 2003, film historian Peter Cowie and writer Jörn Donner discuss Ingmar Bergman’s 1955 return to Svensk Filmindustri and his subsequent breakthrough comedy success, SMILES OF A SUMMER NIGHT.

Title: Lars von Trier—Anecdotes
Description: This 2005 documentary about various collaborators’ experiences working with Lars von Trier features interviews with costume designer Manon Rasmussen, film school teacher Mogens Rukov, editor-director Tomas Gislason, producer Peter Aalbaek Jensen, art director Peter Grant, actor Michael Simpson, production manager Per Arman, and actor Ole Ernst.

Title: Madhabi Mukherjee and Soumitra Chatterjee on CHARULATA
Description: This interview program features actors Madhabi Mukherjee and Soumitra Chatterjee, who play Charulata and Amal in CHARULATA. The interviews were conducted in Kolkata in 2013.

Title: Nathalie Baye on EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF
Description: In this interview from 2010, actor Nathalie Baye describes Jean-Luc Godard’s directing style and the premiere of EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF at Cannes.

Title: Around Jean Cocteau
Description: Is LES ENFANTS TERRIBLES a film by Jean-Pierre Melville or Jean Cocteau? In this short 2003 piece, director Noël Simsolo poses that question to film scholar Dominique Païni and critic Jean Narboni while strolling through an exhibition of Cocteau’s work at the Centre Pompidou, in Paris.

Title: Mikhail Romadin on SOLARIS
Description: Although SOLARIS was occasionally marketed as the Soviet 2001, director Andrei Tarkovsky actually thought of his film as 2001’s polar opposite—it emphasized humanity and morality over special effects and science fiction. For the creation of SOLARIS’s distinctive look, Tarkovsky turned to art director Mikhail Romadin, interviewed here in 2011.

Title: Bad Night for the Blues
Description: Directed by Chris Shepherd • 2010 • United Kingdom /  / Blues rinses, portraits of the queen and stand up bingo. Chris Shepherd delves into his past and recalls the world of his Aunty Glad and her local Conservative Club. The hues of blue that make up the Tory heartland are more than just a party - they are a state of mind.

Title: Logorama
Director: François Alaux, Hervé de Crécy, and Ludovic Houplain
Description: Directed by François Alaux, Hervé de Crécy, and Ludovic Houplain • 2009 • France /  /  /  / Spectacular car chases, an intense hostage crisis, wild animals rampaging through the city, and even more in LOGORAMA!

Title: Jacques Tati at the 1972 San Francisco Film Festival
Description: In 1972, PLAYTIME made its U.S. debut at the San Francisco Film Festival. Director Jacques Tati attended the event and participated in a discussion about the film, moderated by program director Albert Johnson. The following are audio excerpts from that conversation.

Title: Irène Jacob on THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE
Description: Irène Jacob was virtually unknown when she starred in THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE, for which she won the best actress award at Cannes. She has since appeared in such films as OTHELLO and THE SECRET GARDEN, and collaborated again with Krzysztof Kieślowski on RED (1994). In this 2005 interview, she discusses working on THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE.

Title: Deleted Scenes
Description: The following deleted scenes reveal interesting details about the characters and the film's unique production design, costumes, and symbolism. Scenes 1-8 are presented with their original audio. Scenes 9-16 were missing their original audio and are therefore presented without sound.

Title: The Horse in Focus
Description: 1956 • Sweden /  / This short film covers the equestrian segment of the 1956 Summer Olympics.

Title: Masahiro Shinoda on SAMURAI SPY
Description: In this video interview with Masahiro Shinoda, recorded in Tokyo in 2005, the director discusses his beginnings in filmmaking, the influence of such directors as Yasujiro Ozu and Kenji Mizoguchi on his work, and the style he used in SAMURAI SPY.

Title: The Cage
Description: Directed by Adrian Sitaru • 2010 • Romania, Netherlands /  / When Mihaes's little boy brings home a sick dove this raises new conflicts between father and son, but also a possible 'reconciliation' that Mihaes does not want to lose.

Title: Bernardo Bertolucci on LA COMMARE SECCA
Description: The following interview with director Bernardo Bertolucci was recorded in Rome in 2003. In it, he discusses his relationship with his mentor, filmmaker Pier Paolo Pasolini, and traces the development of LA COMMARE SECCA from preproduction to its debut at the 1962 Venice Film Festival.

Title: Adriano Aprà
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2011, film critic Adriano Aprà examines both the themes of STROMBOLI and the media scandal that erupted during its production.

Title: Madhabi Mukherjee on THE BIG CITY
Description: The following interview with actor Madhabi Mukherjee, who plays Arati in THE BIG CITY, was conducted in Calcutta in 2013.

Title: THE EMPTY SPACE Excerpt
Description: The following 16-minute excerpt from Gerald Feil’s 1973 documentary THE EMPTY SPACE looks at some of Peter Brook’s methods as a theater director.

Title: Outtakes
Description: The following is sixteen minutes of outtakes and on-set footage from the shooting of ALICE IN THE CITIES. The material is silent but is presented here with music from CAN’s score for the film.

Title: The Edge of the World
Description: In 1937, director Michael Powell shot the feature THE EDGE OF THE WORLD on Scotland’s Isle of Foula. In 1978, Powell revisited the location for the documentary RETURN TO THE EDGE OF THE WORLD. This is a scene from THE EDGE OF THE WORLD, introduced by Powell himself in an excerpt from the documentary.

Title: Nelson Rodríguez on MEMORIES OF UNDERDEVELOPMENT
Shampa Srivastava on PATHER PANCHALI
Description: The following interview with Shampa Srivastava, who plays young Durga in PATHER PANCHALI (credited as Runki Banerjee), was conducted in 2015.

Title: Skunk
Description: Directed by Annie Silverstein • 2014 • United States /  / Raised by a single mother on an isolated subdivision in rural Texas, fourteen-year-old Leila's deepest connection is with her pack of rescued dogs. On a hot summer morning, she wakes to find that her beloved pit bull Bubba has eviscerated a skunk. Leila heads to a nearby swimming hole to bathe him and meets Marco, a neighborhood boy with a chip on his shoulder. Charmed by his attention, Leila lets Marco into her world. But after a tense sexual encounter things spin out of control and Leila is forced to protect what she loves most at the cost of her own innocence.

Title: Rade Serbedzija on BEFORE THE RAIN
Description: Rade Serbedzija was born in Croatia to an ethnic Derbian family and became one of the most popular Yugoslav actors of the 1970s and ’80s. In 1993, during the war in the former Yugoslavia, he fled to London, where Milcho Manchevski tracked him down to star in BEFORE THE RAIN. In this 2008 interview, he shares his thoughts about working on the film.

Title: Bruce Eder on the Score to THINGS TO COME
Description: In this visual essay, produced in 2013, film historian Bruce Eder discusses Arthur Bliss’s musical score for THINGS TO COME.

Title: ERASERHEAD Locations
Description: This footage shows director David Lynch, actors Jack Nance and Charlotte Stewart, and director's assistant Catherine Coulson revisiting the locations at the AFI in Los Angeles where they made ERASERHEAD over the course of four years. The interviews were conducted by Toby Keeler for his 1997 documentary PRETTY AS A PICTURE: THE ART OF DAVID LYNCH.

Title: Revisiting BLACK ORPHEUS
Description: The French-Brazilian-Italian coproduction BLACK ORPHEUS is often considered less a Brazilian film than one with a decidedly European perspective. In this 2010 interview, Brazilian film scholar Robert Stam discusses this criticism and BLACK ORPHEUS’s importance in film history.

Title: Harold Lloyd: Big Man on Campus
Description: This 2014 visual essay by John Bengtson, author of “Silent Visions: Discovering Early Hollywood and New York Through the Films of Harold Lloyd,” looks at the locations used for the college and football scenes in THE FRESHMAN and features rare behind-the-scenes stills from Lloyd’s archive.

Title: Irena Kovarova
Description: In the following interview, recorded in 2018 in New York, film programmer and Czechoslovak film expert Irena Kovarova discusses the importance of DIAMONDS OF THE NIGHT within the Czechoslovak New Wave.

Title: Harold Lloyd
Description: The following interview with Harold Lloyd was broadcast on December 14, 1962, on Dutch public television. In it, Lloyd gives a tour of his estate and discusses his work and the development of his "Glasses Character."

Title: Fauve
Description: Directed by Jérémy Comte • 2018 • Canada /  / Set in a surface mine, two boys sink into a seemingly innocent power game with Mother Nature as the sole observer.

Title: Irène Jacob on Krzysztof Kieślowski
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2011, actor Irène Jacob discusses her experiences working with director Krzysztof Kieślowski (she also appeared in his film THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE), and talks about her and costar Jean-Louis Trintignant’s tightly choreographed performances in RED.

Title: Jacques Demy at the Midnight Sun Film Festival
Description: In the following Q&A session from the 1987 Midnight Sun Film Festival in Sodankylä, Finland, director Jacques Demy sits down with moderator Peter von Bagh.

Title: School for Postmen
Description: Directed by Jacques Tati • 1947 • France /  / This fifteen minute short, about a clumsy rural postman named Francois, was the first film Jacques Tati directed on his own; he also wrote and stars in it. Tati would reprise the role of Francois in Jour de Fete a few years later.

Title: Swimming to the Macula
Description: The following is actual footage of Spalding Gray’s macular surgery in the early 1990s. It is presented as it was filmed, without sound.

Title: Kon Ichikawa on THE BURMESE HARP
Description: In the following interview, recorded in Japan in 2005, director Kon Ichikawa discusses the production of THE BURMESE HARP.

Title: Passion Project: Martin Rosen on WATERSHIP DOWN
Description: Conducted in 2014, this interview with WATERSHIP DOWN writer, producer, and director Martin Rosen chronicles the difficult process of bringing Richard Adams’s celebrated novel to cinematic life.

Title: Barry Day on BRIEF ENCOUNTER
Description: In the following interview, recorded in October 2011, Noël Coward expert Barry Day, author of “Coward on Film: The Cinema of Noël Coward,” discusses BRIEF ENCOUNTER.

Title: Renoir at Work
Description: The working methods of director Jean Renoir, who was thought to have often used improvisation, were illuminated in 1994 when the Cinémathèque Française released UN TOURNAGE À LA CAMPAGNE, composed of eighty-nine minutes of outtakes from the production of A DAY IN THE COUNTRY. The following video essay, written and narrated by Renoir scholar Christopher Faulkner, examines those outtakes.

Title: Ethan Hawke and Jonathan Marc Sherman on BAAL
Description: The following conversation between actor Ethan Hawke and playwright Jonathan Marc Sherman was recorded in New York in November 2017. Hawke and Sherman collaborated on the 2013 stage production “Clive,” an adaptation of Bertolt Brecht’s play “Baal.”

Title: Seven Women of Different Ages
Description: Directed by Krzysztof Kieślowski • 1978 • Poland /  /  /  / Krzysztof Kieślowski made more than twenty documentaries, including the following short. SEVEN WOMEN OF DIFFERENT AGES (1978) subtly portrays a range of ballet dancers, one each day of the week.

Title: L'opéra Mouffe
Description: Directed by Agnès Varda • 1958 • France /  /  /  / Pregnant with her first child, director Agnès Varda turned her camera to her immediate surroundings capturing day-to-day life along the Rue Mouffetard. Lacking synch sound and incorporating a number of unconventional techniques, this short work displays Varda's freestyle approach to filmmaking and its subject matter.

Title: Olivier Assayas on Sacha Guitry
Description: In this interview, filmmaker Olivier Assayas discusses his love for the films of Sacha Guitry and how pioneering and influential they have been in French cinema. The interview was conducted in New York in October 2016.

Title: Edward Woodward on BREAKER MORANT
Description: Actor Edward Woodward discusses playing Lieutenant Harry “Breaker” Morant in BREAKER MORANT in this 2004 interview.

Title: Mila Parély on THE RULES OF THE GAME
Description: Actor Mila Parély appeared in over forty films, including Jean Renoir’s THE RULES OF THE GAME, Jean Cocteau’s BEAUTY AND THE BEAST, and Max Ophuls’s LE PLAISIR. This 1995 interview with her was produced by Jacques Motte for his documentary HISTOIRE D’UN TOURNAGE EN SOLOGNE, about the making of THE RULES OF THE GAME, and was edited by Criterion.

Title: The Making of WHITE
Description: In the following behind-the-scenes program, director Krzysztof Kieślowski discusses some of the key narrative details in WHITE and the challenges and pleasures of shooting in Poland.

Title: NIGHT ON EARTH Commentary: New York
Description: Recorded in 2007, this audio commentary features director of photography Frederick Elmes and location sound mixer Drew Kunin.

Title: Chaplin Studios: Creative Freedom by Design
Description: In this piece, visual effects expert Craig Barron takes a look at the set designs created by Charlie Chaplin and his team of artists and technicians—designs whose ingenuity, efficiency, and humor flowed from the unique creative process employed at Chaplin Studios.

Title: Barry Day on IN WHICH WE SERVE
Description: In the following interview, recorded in October 2011, Noël Coward expert Barry Day, author of “Coward on Film: The Cinema of Noël Coward,” discusses IN WHICH WE SERVE.

Title: Introducing Columbia Noir
Description: Critics Imogen Sara Smith and Farran Smith Nehme explore the style and sensibility that Columbia Pictures brought to film noir.

Title: Sofia Coppola in Conversation
Description: Sofia Coppola discusses growing up in a household of legendary cinephiles, the works that opened her eyes to the possibilities of moviemaking, and the films she wants to share with her own children.

Title: Liv Ullmann on PERSONA
Description: In this 2013 interview, actor Liv Ullmann goes into detail about the making of PERSONA, her connection to the character of Elisabet Vogler, and what she took away from this life-changing experience.

Title: Premature
Description: Directed by Gunhild Enger • 2013 • Norway /  / PREMATURE tells the story of Norwegian Martin and his pregnant Spanish girlfriend, Lucia. We follow the pair during their first 15 minutes on Norwegian soil, observing Lucia's first encounter with this new culture and her in‚Äêlaws. The film depicts a car trip full of social tensions, expectations and misunderstandings.

Title: Masterclass: Damien Chazelle
Description: The director of LA LA LAND presents Jean Rouch and Edgar Morin’s revolutionary documentary in Madison, Wisconsin, and examines its pivotal place in the history of nonfiction film with professor Kelley Conway.

Title: Francesco Rosi, Raffaele La Capria, Michel Ciment
Description: In 2006, film critic Michel Ciment interviewed Francesco Rosi and writer Raffaele La Capria about their collaboration and concerns for their native city of Naples.

Title: Isabella Rossellini on THE FLOWERS OF ST. FRANCIS
Description: The following interview with Roberto Rossellini's daughter, actress Isabella Rossellini, was conducted in New York in 2004.

Title: Abbas Kiarostami on CERTIFIED COPY
Description: This interview with director Abbas Kiarostami was recorded in Paris in 2012.

Title: The Silence
Description: Directed by Ali Asgari and Farnoosh Samadi • 2016 • Italy, France /  / Fatma and her mother are Kurdish refugees in Italy. On their visit to the doctor, she has to translate what the doctor tells to her mother but she keeps silent.

Title: The South African War
Description: This 2015 piece features historian Stephen Miller, author of “Volunteers on the Veld,” discussing the Second Boer War and, in particular, the conflict depicted in BREAKER MORANT.

Title: Brett Halsey on THE ATOMIC SUBMARINE
Edmundo Desnoes on MEMORIES OF UNDERDEVELOPMENT
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2018, Edmundo Desnoes, author of “Inconsolable Memories,” talks about adapting his novel to the screen for MEMORIES OF UNDERDEVELOPMENT.

Title: GEORGE WASHINGTON Cast Reunion
Description: On September 15, 2001, the Criterion Collection organized a reunion of the cast members of GEORGE WASHINGTON in High Point, North Carolina. Director David Gordon Green conducted the interviews with the cast, in which they discussed the making of the film and life after GEORGE WASHINGTON.

Title: Claire Bloom on LIMELIGHT
Description: The following interview with LIMELIGHT actress Claire Bloom was conducted in 2015.

Title: Resurrecting the Avant-Garde
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2015, film historian Peter Hames, author of “Czech and Slovak Cinema,” unlocks the surreal charms of VALERIE AND HER WEEK OF WONDERS.

Title: Seiko Ogawa on TAMPOPO
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2016, food stylist Seiko Ogawa talks about her work on Tampopo.

Title: Paul Mason on BRUTE FORCE
Description: Paul Mason is a criminologist specializing in media representations of prison. He is the editor of “Captured by the Media: Prison Discourse in Popular Culture.” He also directs the Prison Media Monitoring Unit and is a founding member of the group No More Prisons. In this 2007 program, he discusses BRUTE FORCE’s relevance to prison reform.

Title: Pioneer
Description: Directed by David Lowery • 2011 • United States /  / Starring Will Oldham, Myles Brooks /  /  /  / A father tells his son the most epic bedtime story ever.

Title: Presenting THE GOLD RUSH
Description: In 1942, Charlie Chaplin released a sound version of THE GOLD RUSH, effectively abandoning his 1925 silent. In 1993, filmmakers David Gill and Kevin Brownlow reconstructed the original film, for which there were few surviving elements. In this program, Brownlow and Chaplin biographer Jeffrey Vance recount the journey of this comic masterpiece.

Title: Cinema Lesson by Wong Kar-wai
Description: Presented here is a “cinema lesson” given by director Wong Kar-wai at the 2001 Cannes Film Festival.

Title: "The Kid Brother": Close to Home
Description: In the following new video essay, location historian and author John Bengston discusses the Los Angeles locations used in the filming of THE KID BROTHER, employing historical research and geographic features to identify specific details.

Title: Andrew Rice on Idi Amin
Description: The following interview with Andrew Rice, author of “The Teeth May Smile but the Heart Does Not Forget: Murder and Memory in Uganda,” was conducted in New York City in August 2017.

Title: Soundtrack Selections
Description: These selections from the soundtrack for BEFORE THE RAIN feature the music of the Macedonian band Anastasia.

Title: David Raskin and the Score
Description: In this 1992 interview, film and television composer David Raksin, best remembered for his theme music for the film LAURA (1944), recalls the four months he spent with Charlie Chaplin arranging the music for MODERN TIMES. Also presented is a nine-minute piece of the original orchestral track, from the first factory sequence, without sound effects.

Title: Pickle
Description: Directed by Amy Nicholson • 2015 • United States /  / Let us reflect on the brief existence of Pickle the fish. Although he could not swim, he was lovingly cared for by a couple that kept him propped up in a sponge. Along with an obese chicken, a cat with a heart condition, and a paraplegic possum, his life is a celebration of man's eternal capacity to care for all creatures. He will be dearly missed.

Title: Eddie Axberg on HERE IS YOUR LIFE
Description: The following interview with actor Eddie Axberg was conducted in Stockholm in March 2015.

Title: Postwar Poetry
Description: Made in 2014 by White Dolphin Films, this documentary provides a look at ODD MAN OUT through archival material and interviews with filmmakers, director Carol Reed’s collaborators, and critics.

Title: Butter Lamp
Description: Directed by Hu Wei • 2013 • China /  /  /  / A young photographer and his assistant take pictures of Tibetan nomads. Against diverse and more or less exotic backgrounds, families appear to the photographer. Through these shots, the photographer will weave unique links with each of the various villagers.

Title: Kim Newman on DIABOLIQUE
Description: In this interview, shot in London in 2010, novelist and film critic Kim Newman discusses how the groundbreaking DIABOLIQUE has influenced countless horror films, including Alfred Hitchcock’s PSYCHO. Newman’s books include “The Hound of the d’Urbervilles: The Crime-Book of Professor Moriarty” and “Nightmare Movies: Forty Years of Fear.”

Title: Mira Nair on THE MUSIC ROOM
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2011, filmmaker Mira Nair (SALAAM BOMBAY!, MONSOON WEDDING) discusses her admiration for Satyajit Ray and THE MUSIC ROOM.

Title: Agnès Varda on LA POINTE COURTE
Description: This 2007 interview was shot at director Agnès Varda’s home office on the rue Daguerre in Paris.

Title: Rémi Fournier Lanzoni on IL SORPASSO
Description: Italy’s highest-grossing film of 1962, IL SORPASSO is among the most beloved movies of the golden age of commedia all’italiana, which lasted from the late 1950s to the 1970s. In this 2014 interview, scholar Rémi Fournier Lanzoni discussed the film’s resonance with Italian audiences, its social commentary, and how it embodies Dino Risi’s style.

Title: The Romanian Tour
Description: In this short documentary from 2007, Romanian audience members are asked for their responses after viewing 4 MONTHS, 3 WEEKS AND 2 DAYS.

Title: Maurice Pialat on L’ENFANCE NUE
Description: On February 12, 1973, right after L'ENFANCE NUE first aired on French television, Maurice Pialat was interviewed by Michel Martens for an episode of the program “Champ contre-champ,” directed by Maurice Frydland. In these excerpts, Pialat discusses L'ENFANCE NUE's subject matter, its commercial failure, and his intentions as a filmmaker.

Title: Jean-Pierre Gorin on MASCULIN FÉMININ
Description: Jean-Pierre Gorin and Jean-Luc Godard made seven films together as the Dziga-Vertov Group, including 1972’s TOUT VA BIEN. In this interview, Gorin discusses Godard's deepening narrative, historical, and cultural experimentation in MASCULIN FÉMININ. The Criterion Collection interviewed Gorin in New York, in March of 2005.

Title: Jean Renoir parle de son art: Part 2
Description: In the following 1961 interview, Jean Renoir discusses with French New Wave director Jacques Rivette his design of the “seventh art” and art in general, demolishing certain generally accepted ideas, and evoking some memories from his own career.

Title: Making F.R.I.E.N.D.S.
Description: In the following 2015 piece, director Takashi Murakami’s special effects crew and clay model makers bring to life the F.R.I.E.N.D.S. of JELLYFISH EYES.

Title: Howard and Uncle Bill
Description: This piece features a 2015 interview with filmmaker Aaron Brookner, BURROUGHS: THE MOVIE director Howard Brookner’s nephew.

Title: Magali Noël on AMARCORD
Description: Chosen at the last moment to play Gradisca in director Federico Fellini’s AMARCORD, Magali Noël threw herself into the role with typical verve and charm. She also appeared in Fellini’s LA DOLCE VITA and SATYRICON, in addition to such films as RIFIFI and Z.

Title: Mutations of Memory: Editing in HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR
Description: Professor David Bordwell traces the ways in which director Alain Resnais and screenwriter Marguerite Duras retooled cinematic language to evoke the texture of memory in their 1959 masterpiece.

Title: Kumar Shahani on A RIVER CALLED TITAS
Description: In this 2013 interview, filmmaker Kumar Shahani (KHAYAL GATHA), a former student of Ritwik Ghatak’s, shares his appreciation for Ghatak’s 1973 film A RIVER CALLED TITAS.

Title: Bruce Beresford on MISTER JOHNSON
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2015, director Bruce Beresford recounts his experiences making MISTER JOHNSON.

Title: The Making of ANTICHRIST: Visual Style
Description: Made in 2010 by Zentropa’s DVD production company, Electric Parc.

Title: President Nixon Resigns the Office of the Presidency
Description: The following was broadcast live nationwide on August 8, 1974.

Title: Joshua Oppenheimer on NIGHT AND FOG
Description: This interview with filmmaker Joshua Oppenheimer was conducted in Copenhagen in April 2016.

Title: Tony Rayns on PIGS AND BATTLESHIPS
Description: This interview with film critic Tony Rayns was conducted in December 2008.

Title: Casper Tybjerg on MASTER OF THE HOUSE
Description: In this interview, produced in 2014, Danish film historian Casper Tybjerg discusses how MASTER OF THE HOUSE went from being a popular stage play to a film, one that was a major stepping-stone in director Carl Theodor Dreyer’s career.

Title: More Than a Soundtrack: The Valerie Project
Description: In this piece, produced in 2015, Joseph A. Gervasi and Greg Weeks, cofounders of the Philadelphia-based psych-folk ensemble the Valerie Project, discuss VALERIE AND HER WEEK OF WONDERS and how it inspired them to create a unique alternate score.

Title: Suzanne Schiffman on SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER
Description: This rare interview with Suzanne Schiffman, François Truffaut’s closest collaborator, was conducted in April 1986, in Paris. The interview was originally intended for Rainer Gansera’s documentary WORKING WITH TRUFFAUT. The Criterion Collection gained access to the complete interview and edited a version exclusively for this DVD edition.

Title: Adrian Utley and Will Gregory
Description: Adrian Utley, of the band Portishead, and Goldfrapp’s Will Gregory composed their score for THE PASSION OF JOAN OF ARC in 2010. This conversation between the two was filmed at Utley’s home in Bristol, England, in 2017.

Title: Ingmar Bergman on Victor Sjöström
Description: In this 1981 interview with Ingmar Bergman, excerpted from Gösta Werner’s feature documentary VICTOR SJÖSTRÖM: A PORTRAIT, the filmmaker discusses his deep admiration for Sjöström—director of THE PHANTOM CARRIAGE—as well as the influence he had on his own career and their work together on WILD STRAWBERRIES.

Title: Musicians of THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN
Description: In this 2010 video portrait, the musicians from THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN discuss their integral role in the film.

Title: Peter Bogdanovich and Noah Baumbach on FRANCES HA
Description: The following conversation between filmmaker Peter Bogdanovich and Noah Baumbach was recorded in New York City in June 2013.

Title: Everyday Realities
Description: EVERYDAY REALITIES: TONY RAYNS ON NEW TAIWAN CINEMA AND EDWARD YANG features the noted Asian-cinema critic discussing the cinematic movement, its key players and characteristics, and the qualities that distinguish Edward Yang and his work from his contemporaries.

Title: Masaki Kobayashi and Masahiro Shinoda on KWAIDAN
Description: This conversation between director Masaki Kobayashi and filmmaker Masahiro Shinoda about the making of KWAIDAN was shot in 1993 for the Directors Guild of Japan.

Title: Ingmar Bergman on SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE
Description: In this 1986 interview for Swedish television, Ingmar Bergman reflects on the making of SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE, discussing the characters he created and the strong response they elicited from their audience.

Title: Robert Christides on LE PLAISIR
Description: Robert Christides was employed as set decorator on both LE PLAISIR and LOLA MONTES. He continued to work as a set decorator, art director, and production designer in a career that spanned thirty years. This 1989 interview was conducted in Paris by Martina Muller.

Title: “Close-Up”: Shelagh Delaney
Description: In this interview excerpt, playwright Shelagh Delaney discusses growing up in Salford, England, and writing her hit play “A Taste of Honey” at the age of eighteen. The interview aired in 1960 on the television series “Close-Up.”

Title: Restoring Time
Description: This short documentary from 2015 discusses the ongoing work by the Wim Wenders Foundation to restore the filmmaker’s early output.

Title: Behind the Scenes in Macedonia
Description: In this program, shot in 1993, during the filming of BEFORE THE RAIN, cast and crew share their thoughts about working together in Macedonia and the challenges they faced.

Title: Antoine Bourseiller on 2 OR 3 THINGS I KNOW ABOUT HER
Description: Theater director, actor, and author Antoine Bourseiller was a close friend of both Jean-Luc Godard and Anna Karina in the sixties (his children play Marina Vlady’s children in 2 OR 3 THINGS I KNOW ABOUT HER). In this interview, he recounts the “warlike friendship” he shared with Godard, until it was disrupted by the director’s turn to Maoism.

Title: The Martha Graham Technique
Description: In 1975 the Martha Graham Dance Company filmed a technique demonstration in three parts. Presented here are excerpts from that film, which Graham narrates.

Title: Kieślowski at Cannes, 1994
Description: This short documentary, shot at the time of RED’s world premiere at the Cannes Film Festival, includes interviews with director Krzysztof Kieślowski and actors Irène Jacob and Jean-Louis Trintignant, as well as footage of Kieślowski announcing his retirement from filmmaking.

Title: Chantal Goya on MASCULIN FÉMININ
Description: The following interview with Chantal Goya was recorded in Paris, in May 2005. In it, she looks back on her career as a singer and on the experience of working with Jean-Luc Godard on MASCULIN FÉMININ.

Title: The Making of BORDER RADIO
Description: This documentary, made in 2002, features interviews with filmmakers Allison Anders, Kurt Voss, and Dean Lent, and actors Chris D. and John Doe.

Title: Metin Erksan and Fatih Akin on DRY SUMMER
Description: This 2013 program features excerpts from a 2008 interview with the late director Metin Erksan and a new interview with filmmaker Fatih Akin (HEAD-ON), both of whom reflect on Erksan's 1964 film.

Title: Soumitra Chatterjee and Sharmila Tagore on APUR SANSAR
Description: In the following program, produced in 2015, Soumitra Chatterjee and Sharmila Tagore talk about what it was like acting for director Satyajit Ray and their experiences making APUR SANSAR, the debut film for each of them.

Title: Tony Lawson on INSIGNIFICANCE
Description: Before working with director Nicolas Roeg, INSIGNIFICANCE editor Tony Lawson had collaborated with such acclaimed filmmakers as Sam Peckinpah (on STRAW DOGS) and Stanley Kubrick (on BARRY LYNDON). The following interview with Lawson was conducted exclusively in London in December 2010.

Title: Silent Traces: MODERN TIMES
Description: In this 2010 visual essay, John Bengtson, author of “Silent Traces: Discovering Early Hollywood Through the Films of Charlie Chaplin,” tours the locations used in MODERN TIMES through photographs, vintage maps, and film clips, revealing what Chaplin’s camera captured of the backdrop to the silent era and how things have changed.

Title: Superbia
Description: Directed by Luca Tóth • 2016 • Czech Republic /  / In the land of Superbia strict rules devide the societies of women and men, maintained also physically by the Milk River originating from the Cow God. Different customs and manners estrange the sexes far apart, the strong and sturdy women on one side and the decent and delicate men on the other. The story follows three main characters. A man and a woman find their ways to each other against all odds. Their actions become the catalyst of change within the societies, sparking a cultural revolution. The third and most conflicted character is a nemesis female character who does not want or does not know how to adapt to a coming, unknown new era.

Title: Bronja Clair on René Clair
Description: Bronja Clair met her future husband in 1924, at the premiere of his film ENTR’ACTE, and became an active participant with him in the French art world. She remembers René Clair and his art in this 1998 interview.

Title: Magazine: An Homage to Jacques Tati
Description: In this 1982 episode of the French television show “Magazine,” artist and set designer Jacques Lagrange pays tribute to his friend Jacques Tati through anecdotes about his collaboration with the filmmaker.

Title: Bong Joon-ho on THE HOUSEMAID
Description: In this 2013 interview, filmmaker Bong Joon-ho (THE HOST) shares his appreciation for Kim Ki-young’s 1960 film THE HOUSEMAID.

Title: Olivier Assayas on COLD WATER
Description: This interview with director Olivier Assayas was conducted in New York in March 2018.

Title: Edmond Was a Donkey
Description: Directed by Franck Dion • 2012 • Canada /  / This animated short about social conformity tells the story of Edmond - a very 'different' sort of guy. When his co-workers jokingly crown him with a pair of donkey ears, Edmond suddenly discovers his true identity. And while he enjoys his newfound self, the ears create an ever-widening gap between himself and others.

Title: Krzysztof Kieślowski: The Early Years
Description: In this interview program from 2003, film critic Geoff Andrew, filmmaker Agnieszka Holland, cinematographer Sławomir Idziak, film studies professor Annette Insdorf, and actor Irène Jacob examine director Krzysztof Kieślowski’s formative years and the political and social circumstances that shaped his direction and philosophical choices in cinema.

Title: Sherwan Haji
Description: In this interview shot in 2017, actor Sherwan Haji discusses his move to Finland, working with director Aki Kaurismäki, and the ongoing plight of Syrian refugees.

Title: Tony Richardson on A TASTE OF HONEY
Description: This audio interview with screenwriter and director Tony Richardson is presented with film clips and behind-the-scenes images. The interview, conducted by critic Gideon Bachmann at the 1962 Cannes Film Festival, covers the state of British cinema, Richardson’s filmmaking methods, and what drew him to adapt “A Taste of Honey” for the screen.

Title: Thoughts on LE BONHEUR
Description: In 2006 Agnès Varda gathered four intellectuals from various professions and backgrounds—freelance writer-journalist Michèle Manceaux, producer and distributor Gérard Vaugeois, journalist and critic Frédéric Bonnaud, and Fadela Amara, president of the organization Ni putes ni soumises, which seeks to help women of Arab and North African descent assert their rights—to discuss their thoughts on LE BONHEUR as a film and happiness as a concept.

Title: Tokuzo Tanaka on SANSHO THE BAILIFF
Description: Tokuzo Tanaka was first assistant director on SANSHO THE BAILIFF, and in this 2007 interview, he offers a complex portrait of Kenji Mizoguchi, outlines the methods employed by the filmmaking team, and remembers the director’s surprising feelings about the film.

Title: Greenacres
Description: Harold Lloyd broke ground for his elaborate Los Angeles estate, Greenacres, during the filming of THE KID BROTHER. Presented here is a 2005 featurette in which Suzanne Lloyd provides a tour of the estate.

Title: MR. ARKADIN Outtakes and Rushes: Orson Welles Acting
Description: Found in the archives of the Cinémathèque municipale de Luxembourg, the footage shown here represents outtakes, work prints, and rushes Orson Welles used to construct MR. ARKADIN, at least as far as he was able. It is extremely rare, and some of the only material in existence showing Welles in the act of directing.

Title: Möbius
Description: Directed by Sam Kuhn • 2017 • United States, Canada /  / A tale of magic and mutation half remembered by a teen poet whose beloved has mysteriously disappeared.

Title: Jean Renoir: A Passage Through India
Description: This video essay by film writer Paul Ryan on Jean Renoir’s approach to filming Rumer Godden’s novel “The River” features rare behind-the-scenes stills and location-scouting footage.

Title: Willy Kurant on THE IMMORTAL STORY
Description: Director of photography Willy Kurant discusses shooting THE IMMORTAL STORY for Orson Welles, in this July 2004 interview.

Title: Arnošt Lustig Through the Eyes of Jan Němec
Description: In this fourteen-minute film from 1993, director Jan Němec pays tribute to author Arnošt Lustig, whose work he adapted for Loaf of Bread and DIAMONDS OF THE NIGHT.

Title: Deer Boy
Description: Directed by Katarzyna Gondek • 2017 • Poland, Belgium, Croatia /  / DEER BOY is a story about a hunter's son, who was born with antlers, and about how each man kills the thing he loves.

Title: Kitty
Description: Directed by Chloë Sevigny • 2016 • United States /  / Adapted from Paul Bowles' short story of the same name, KITTY displays Chloë Sevigny's inventive and singular aesthetic in a story about a little girl who dreams of becoming a kitten and finds herself transformed into one.

Title: Barry Day on THIS HAPPY BREED
Description: In the following interview, recorded in October 2011, Noël Coward expert Barry Day, author of “Coward on Film: The Cinema of Noël Coward,” discusses THIS HAPPY BREED.

Title: Peter Cowie on SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE
Description: SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE was originally filmed as a six-part television series and then edited by Ingmar Bergman into a feature film. In this program, filmed in 2004, renowned Bergman expert Peter Cowie talks about the making of the two versions and the choices made by the director in the editing process.

Title: Peter Cowie on SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE
Description: SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE was originally filmed as a six-part television series and then edited by Ingmar Bergman into a feature film. In this program, filmed in 2004, renowned Bergman expert Peter Cowie talks about the making of the two versions and the choices made by the director in the editing process.

Title: Le Paris de Zazie
Description: In this short documentary from 2005, Louis Malle’s assistant director, Philippe Collin, gives us a tour of ZAZIE DANS LE MÉTRO’s Paris locations while relating anecdotes about the film’s production.

Title: Michael Barker on Pedro Almodóvar
Description: Sony Pictures Classics cofounders Michael Barker, Tom Bernard, and Marcie Bloom first collaborated with director Pedro Almodóvar at Orion Classics in 1988, on the hit WOMEN ON THE VERGE OF A NERVOUS BREAKDOWN. In this interview, conducted in April 2014, Barker reflects on his many years of working with the director.

Title: Love You More
Description: Directed by Sam Taylor-Johnson • 2008 • United Kingdom /  / Two teenagers are drawn together by the Buzzcocks' single Love You More during the summer of 1978.

Title: Performing THE LAST METRO
Description: In this 2009 video piece, actors Andréa Ferréol, Paulette Dubost, and Sabine Haudepin, along with actor and second assistant director Alain Tasma, recall the joys and challenges of working on THE LAST METRO.

Title: Talking Heads
Description: Directed by Krzysztof Kieślowski • 1980 • Poland /  /  /  / Krzysztof Kieślowski made more than twenty documentaries, including the following short. In TALKING HEADS, Kieślowski poses the questions “What year were you born?” “Who are you?” and “What do you most wish for?” to forty different people, ranging from an infant to a one-hundred-year-old woman.

Title: Bengt Forslund on HERE IS YOUR LIFE
Description: Bengt Forslund, who produced and cowrote HERE IS YOUR LIFE, was a major force in Swedish filmmaking in the 1960s. In this interview, conducted in Stockholm in March 2015, Forslund describes the transformation of his nation’s cinema during that decade.

Title: Tidy Up
Description: Directed by Satsuki Okawa • 2011 • Japan, United States /  / Following the death of his hoarder mother, a young man eagerly looks forward to cleaning out her junk-strewn home—but first he’ll have to contend with his sister, who is intent on preserving the house just as it is—in this tender look at grief and letting go.

Title: Peter Cowie on THE MAGICIAN
Description: In this visual essay, Peter Cowie, one of the world’s leading experts on Ingmar Bergman, discusses many of the themes in THE MAGICIAN and places them within the context of the director’s body of work.

Title: Jodie Foster on LA HAINE
Description: In this introduction to LA HAINE from 2006, acclaimed actor and filmmaker Jodie Foster discusses her passion for the film and the reasons she championed and presented it in the United States.

Title: Norman Lloyd on LIMELIGHT
Description: The following interview with LIMELIGHT actor Norman Lloyd was conducted 2012.

Title: The Burden
Description: Directed by Niki Lindroth von Bahr • 2017 • Sweden /  / A dark musical enacted in a modern marketplace, situated next to a large freeway. The employees of the various commercial venues, portrayed as animals, deal with boredom and existential anxiety by performing cheerful musical turns. The apocalypse is a tempting liberator.

Title: Festival Talks: Sarajevo Film Festival
Description: In 2016, director Kirsten Johnson traveled with Cameraperson to two film festival that had unique connections to the content of her documentary. Both screenings were followed by in-depth conversations with Johnson. An edited program from one of those live events is presented here.

Title: D. A. Pennebaker, 2017
Description: In these interviews, recorded in Bologna, Italy; Monterey; and New York City in 2017, director D.A. Pennebaker recalls his experiences making MONTEREY POP fifty years earlier, and reminisces about a few of the people who became friends and some of the performances that became legendary.

Title: Arturo Ripstein on THE EXTERMINATING ANGEL
Description: Growing up in Mexico City as the son of a film producer, Arturo Ripstein met numerous directors, but it wasn’t until he encountered the work of Luis Buñuel that he decided to embark on a career in cinema himself. In this 2006 interview, Ripstein discusses having access to the set of THE EXTERMINATING ANGEL and observing Buñuel at work.

Title: Cameramen at War
Description: Produced by the British Ministry of Information in 1943, this film is a tribute to newsreel and service film unit cameramen and features some of the most dramatic footage shot during the war.

Title: Paul Schrader on PICKPOCKET
Description: This introduction to PICKPOCKET by writer-director Paul Schrader was recorded in 2004. Please note: the introduction contains remarks about the ending of the film.

Title: Feeling Good
Description: Directed by Pierre Etaix • 1966 • France /  / This short was originally one of the sequences of As Long as You're Healthy, in its 1965 version. In 1971, Pierre Étaix re-edited it to a short feature: Feeling good. In 2010, it was presented in the general reissue of his films.

Title: Serge Bromberg
Description: In this 2011 introduction, film preservationist and historian Serge Bromberg, director of HENRI-GEORGES CLOUZOT’S ”INFERNO,” a 2009 documentary about Clouzot’s legendary uncompleted film, talks about how the filmmaker put his unique visual stamp on DIABOLIQUE.

Title: Charlie Rose
Description: Charlie Rose interview with David Gordon Green from 2001

Title: Jean Oser on KAMERADSCHAFT
Description: In 1988, Jean Oser, the editor of KAMERADSCHAFT, recorded these audio responses to questions sent to him by film scholar Hermann Barth. Intercut with Oser’s responses are scenes from the rare French cut of the film.

Title: Hafsia Herzi on THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN
Description: In this 2010 interview, actress Hafsia Herzi, who plays Rym, discusses the making of THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN.

Title: LYDIA and the Power of Flashbacks
Description: Professor David Bordwell illuminates how Julien Duvivier’s haunting, exquisitely bittersweet romantic drama deploys intricate, subjective flashback sequences to enhance its sublime emotional impact.

Title: “Ciné regards”: AN AUTUMN AFTERNOON
Description: In these short excerpts from the November 26, 1978, episode of “Ciné regards,” critic Michel Ciment and writer Georges Perec look at the ways Yasujiro Ozu’s filmmaking style changed over the course of his career. They focus in particular on his AN AUTUMN AFTERNOON (a.k.a. THE TASTE OF SAKE).

Title: The Moonshiners
Description: Directed by Juho Kuosmanen  • 2017 • Finland /  /  /  / The first Finnish film was made in 1907, but sadly lost forever. So to mark the 100th anniversary year of the Finnish independence, film has now been remade by Juho Kuosmanen (THE HAPPIEST DAY IN THE LIFE OF OLLI MÄKI) following several silent film traditions: shot on B&W 16 mm film and performed with live music and a live foley artist. In the film two siblings inherit all the essentials for a good life: moonshine equipment and a pig. As they embark on their journey, business is good until a card shark arrives.

Title: On Piano, René Urtreger
Description: Pianist René Urtreger, the only musician from the soundtrack session for ELEVATOR TO THE GALLOWS still living, was interviewed in 2005 for the film’s French DVD release.

Title: Alexander Korda Presents
Description: The following rare audio recording, provided by the Library of Congress, is a promotional radio spot for the 1941 theatrical release of THAT HAMILTON WOMAN. It features excerpts from the film and commentary from the set.

Title: Bernhard Wicki on THE BRIDGE
Description: In this excerpt from a 1989 episode of the German television show “Das Sonntagsgespräch” (Sunday Talk), director Bernhard Wicki discusses the making of THE BRIDGE.

Title: Some Days in January, 1984
Description: The following silent movie was shot and edited on Super 8 by filmmaker Tom Jarmusch, director Jim Jarmusch’s brother, during the filming of STRANGER THAN PARADISE.

Title: Beatrice Welles on CHIMES AT MIDNIGHT
Description: Beatrice Welles was nine years old when her father, Orson Welles, made CHIMES AT MIDNIGHT. In this January 2016 interview, she recalls the atmosphere on set and her reluctance to play Falstaff’s young page.

Title: Joyce Van Patten and Julian Schlossberg on MIKEY AND NICKY
Description: This program, featuring new interviews with actor Joyce Van Patten and distributor Julian Schlossberg, explores director Elaine May's approach to the making of MIKEY AND NICKY—from working with actors to the look of the film.

Title: Sophia Loren on A SPECIAL DAY
Description: This interview with actor Sophia Loren was conducted in Geneva in June 2015. In it, she recalls working with director Ettore Scola on A SPECIAL DAY, her fears about playing Antonietta, and the challenges of shooting the love scene.

Title: Pierre Rissient on INSIANG
Description: This interview with film enthusiast and historian Pierre Rissient was produced in 2017.

Title: A Long Time on the Little Road
Description: In 1957, director Satyajit Ray wrote an article for the British magazine “Sight & Sound” about the making of PATHER PANCHALI. Shortly thereafter, critic Gideon Bachmann recorded Ray reading his account aloud. That audio recording is presented here.

Title: Corridor Gossip
Description: This 2007 piece features CORRIDORS OF BLOOD director Robert Day and actor Francis Matthews.

Title: The Sea Horse
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1933 • France /  / Jean Painlevé's classic underwater short THE SEA HORSE uses dreamlike imagery to detail the lives of the titular upright-swimming creatures.

Title: Ingmar Bergman
Description: Director Ingmar Bergman talks about SHAME in this fifteen-minute excerpt from an interview recorded for the Swedish television program Forum and originally broadcast on September 19, 1968.

Title: Barbet Schroeder on MAÎTRESSE
Description: The following interview with Barbet Schroeder was recorded at his home in New York City in 2002. Schroeder set up his own production company in 1964 and produced such films as Eric Rohmer’s MY NIGHT AT MAUD’S. Since 1969, he has had a distinguished career as a director of both documentaries and narrative films, including GENERAL IDI AMIN DADA, BARFLY, and REVERSAL OF FORTUNE.

Title: THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK: Cleve Jones Interview
Description: During preproduction on THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK, director Robert Epstein recorded draft interviews with more than forty people before deciding on the eight subjects seen in the film. Presented here is an excerpt from an interview with gay rights activist Cleve Jones, which was not included in the film.

Title: A Gentle Night
Description: Directed by Qiu Yang • 2017 • China /  / In a nameless Chinese city, a mother with her daughter missing, refuses to go gentle into this good night.

Title: Harold Nebenzal
Description: Harold Nebenzal, son of Seymour Nebenzal, sat down with Criterion in 2004 to discuss his father’s pioneering independent company, Nero Films, producer of such titles as PANDORA’S BOX, M, THE THREEPENNY OPERA, and THE TESTAMENT OF DR. MABUSE. Harold worked on his father’s 1951 remake of M and on CABARET, and is the author of the novel “Café Berlin.”

Title: A Conversation with Satyajit Ray, 1958
Description: In 1958, director Satyajit Ray attended the Robert Flaherty Film Seminar, on the occasion of the U.S. release of PATHER PANCHALI. Ray had by then completed APARAJITO and THE PHILOSOPHER’S STONE, and THE MUSIC ROOM would soon premiere. Presented here are audio excerpts of a conversation Ray had with film critic Gideon Bachmann during the seminar.

Title: Rashit Safiullin on STALKER
Description: Set designer Rashit Safiullin discusses working on STALKER in this interview from 2000.

Title: A Golden Age
Description: This interview with HARAKIRI star Tatsuya Nakadai was conducted in Tokyo in 2005. In it, the Japanese screen legend discusses his career and his performance in the film.

Title: THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK: Amber Hollibaugh Interview
Description: During preproduction on THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK, director Robert Epstein recorded draft interviews with more than forty people before deciding on the eight subjects seen in the film. Presented here are excerpts from an interview with writer and activist Amber Hollibaugh, which was not included in the film.

Title: How Some Jellyfish Are Born
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1960 • France /  / Through a combination of underwater, time-lapse, and microscopic photography, Jean Painlevé creates a beautiful study of the reproduction cycle of jellyfish.

Title: Johanna ter Steege on THE VANISHING
Description: Johanna ter Steege made her film debut as Saskia in THE VANISHING, which earned her the European Film Award for best supporting actress. In this interview, conducted in Amsterdam in 2014, she recalls the extensive backstory she created for her character, working with director George Sluizer, and how the experience shaped her approach to acting.

Title: Jean-Claude Carrière on DANTON
Description: Working with a subject as intensely studied as the French Revolution, and with a director who was not French, scriptwriter Jean-Claude Carrière knew he was walking into sensitive territory with DANTON. In this interview recorded in 2009 Carrière describes how he navigated that intellectual mine field.

Title: We're Going to the Zoo
Description: Directed by Josh Safdie • 2006 • United States /  / Two siblings accidentally pick up a hitchhiker on their way to the zoo.

Title: Silvia Pinal on VIRIDIANA
Description: Silvia Pinal acted in dozens of films in Mexico before traveling to Spain to work with Luis Buñuel on VIRIDIANA. One of the leading figures in Mexico’s entertainment industry, she has acted, produced, and raised a family of entertainers—not to mention served a term in the Mexican legislature. The following interview was conducted in January 2006.

Title: Isabelle Huppert on WHITE MATERIAL
Description: This interview with actor Isabelle Huppert was recorded in 2010.

Title: A Test of Violence
Description: Directed by Stuart Cooper • 1969 • United Kingdom /  / In 1969, Stuart Cooper made this short film about the work of Spanish artist Juan Genovés, whose paintings depict the horror of oppression and brutality. It won prizes at the Berlin, Moscow, and Venice film festivals. It also caught the attention of James Quinn of the Imperial War Museum, which ultimately led to Cooper’s directing OVERLORD.

Title: Geoff Brown on GREEN FOR DANGER
Description: Film scholar Geoff Brown has written numerous books on British cinema, including “Launder and Gilliat” and “Michael Balcon: The Pursuit of British Cinema.” The following interview was recorded in 2005.

Title: The Love Life of the Octopus
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1967 • France /  / The mating rituals and reproductive cycle of the octopus are the subject of this short documentary by Jean Painlevé.

Title: LES ENFANTS TERRIBLES: About the Film
Description: In this short 2007 video, producer Carole Weisweiller, actor Jacques Bernard, and assistant director Claude Pinoteau discuss the making of LES ENFANTS TERRIBLES.

Title: A Boring Afternoon
Description: Directed by Ivan Passer • 1968 • Czechoslovakia /  / Patrons of a bar interact on a summer Sunday afternoon.

Title: Kierston Wareing on FISH TANK
Description: This piece features actor Kierston Wareing, who was interviewed in London in the fall of 2010.

Title: Peter Bogdanovich on STAGECOACH
Description: In this 2010 video piece, acclaimed filmmaker and John Ford biographer Peter Bogdanovich offers his thoughts on STAGECOACH.

Title: Norman Eshley on IMMORTAL STORY
Description: Actor Norman Eshley’s appearance in THE IMMORTAL STORY came very early in his long television career. In this new interview, shot in May 2016, he discusses playing the sailor in Orson Welles’s film.

Title: Ettore Scola on IL SORPASSO
Description: Award-winning filmmaker Ettore Scola began his career as a screenwriter, working with Dino Risi on a number of his films, including IL SORPASSO. In this November 2013 interview, Scola talks about Italian comedy filmmaking in the sixties, writing the character of Bruno, and the necessity of the film’s tragic ending.

Title: Grigori Chukhrai and Actors on BALLAD OF A SOLDIER
Description: This interview with director/co-screenwriter Grigori Chukhrai and actors Vladimir Ivashov and Zhanna Prokhorenko was conducted by Gideon Bachmann for “Film Art” on radio station WBAI at the Four Seasons restaurant in New York, after a special preview screening of BALLAD OF A SOLDIER.

Title: Dégustation maison
Description: Directed by Sophie Tatischeff • 1978 • France /  / Directed by Jacques Tati's daughter Sophie Tatischeff, Dégustation maison is a thirteen-minute comic short shot in a café in Sainte-Sévère-sur-Indre, the same town where Tati's Jour de fěte was filmed. It won the Cesar Award for best short fiction film in 1978.

Title: Making INSIGNIFICANCE
Description: This short video piece, shot during the making of INSIGNIFICANCE, features interviews with actors Gary Busey, Tony Curtis, and Theresa Russell, among others.

Title: Walter Salles on LIMITE
Description: This interview with filmmaker Walter Salles, founder of the Mário Peixoto Archives, was produced in 2017.

Title: Seijun Suzuki
Description: The following interview with director Seijun Suzuki was recorded during a retrospective of his work by the Japan Foundation and Los Angeles Filmforum at the Nuart Theatre in Los Angeles in March 1997.

Title: Faye Ginsburg on CHRONICLE OF A SUMMER
Description: In this October 2012 interview, anthropology professor Faye Ginsburg discusses CHRONICLE OF A SUMMER in the context of Jean Rouch’s career.

Title: A Straightforward Boy
Description: Directed by Yasujiro Ozu • 1929 • Japan /  / A kidnapped boy proves to be more than his abductor can handle.

Title: Masahiro Shinoda on UGETSU
Description: The director of such classics as PALE FLOWER (1964), SAMURAI SPY (1965), and DOUBLE SUICIDE (1969), Masahiro Shinoda considers Kenji Mizoguchi’s UGETSU one of cinema’s crowning achievements. This interview with Shinoda took place in Tokyo in May 2005.

Title: Joshua Oppenheimer on THE THIN BLUE LINE
Description: The following interview with filmmaker Joshua Oppenheimer about THE THIN BLUE LINE was conducted in December 2014.

Title: The Struggle for Survival
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1937 • France /  / On assignment for the mathematics department of le Palais de la Découverte, Jean Painlevé shot this film to be presented at the Paris museum's 1937 international exhibition. THE STRUGGLE FOR SURVIVAL explores population rise and decline.

Title: Extended Scene: Shubert Theatre
Description: The following extended scene features a longer version of an interview with actors Sigourney Weaver, Isabella Rossellini, and Liv Ullmann at the Shubert Theatre in New York that appears in INGRID BERGMAN: IN HER OWN WORDS.

Title: The Marathon
Description: Directed by Alfred J. Goulding • 1919 • United States /  / This 1919 one-reeler stars Harold Lloyd as one of Bebe Daniels' many suitors, who, after a series of mishaps, ends up running in a local marathon. It is presented here with a new score composed and performed by Gabriel Thibaudeau.

Title: Miloš Forman on THE FIREMEN’S BALL
Description: This interview with director Miloš Forman was conducted in New York City in the spring of 2001.

Title: Tadao Sato on GODZILLA
Description: In this video interview, conducted in 2011, renowned Japanese-film critic Tadao Sato looks at GODZILLA in terms of Japanese culture.

Title: The Strange Ones
Description: Directed by Christopher Radcliff and Lauren Wolkstein • 2011 • United States /  / Two travelers - a man and a boy - whose car has broken down stumble upon a small roadside motel, where a girl offer to help them. At first, all seems normal, but an unseen tension begins to mount between the three of them, leading to a startling discovery. Christopher Radcliff and Lauren Wolkstein's multi-award winning short THE STRANGE ONES strips away the ordinary to offer a brief glimpse of a complicated, dangerous and secret world lurking underneath.

Title: The Revolutionary Subjectivity of MEMORIES OF UNDERDEVELOPMENT
Description: The first Cuban film to garner international attention in the years following the nation’s 1959 revolution, Tomás Gutiérrez Alea’s MEMORIES OF UNDERDEVELOPMENT remains one of the most important works of the influential Third Cinema movement that emerged in the developing world as a response to neocolonialist modes of filmmaking. In this episode of Observations on Film Art, Professor Jeff Smith explores the film’s complex depiction of its notably unsympathetic central character—a misanthropic bourgeois intellectual whose moral apathy has rendered him a relic of a bygone era—and how Alea uses a variety of innovative stylistic techniques to evoke his subjectivity. In doing so, Smith illuminates how this landmark of Cuban cinema challenged audiences to evaluate their own commitment to the revolution.

Title: Bath House
Description: Directed by Niki Lindroth von Bahr • 2014 • Sweden /  / Six characters meet in a bath house. The pedant bath house manager, a couple with a strange way of communicating and a gang with shady intentions. Something goes wrong.

Title: Ingmar Bergman & Liv Ullmann
Description: When Ingmar Bergman cast Liv Ullmann in PERSONA, he initiated a remarkable creative partnership that would last well beyond the passionate, years-long affair that also blossomed between them.

Title: Print: In Memory of Abbas Kiarostami
Description: In 2018, Salma Monshizadeh, Abbas Kiarostami’s former longtime assistant, assembled this short documentary from footage of the making of 24 Frames.

Title: Games of Vision in STREET OF SHAME
HARLAN COUNTY USA at Sundance
Description: In 2005 the Sundance Film Festival inducted HARLAN COUNTY USA into the Sundance Collection. The following panel discussion features producer-director Barbara Kopple, cinematographer Hart Perry, editor Nancy Baker, musician Hazel Dickens, and film critic Roger Ebert. Kopple also invited striking Utah coal miners to talk about their struggles.

Title: Olivier Assayas on Sacha Guitry
Description: Olivier Assayas sings the praises of an underrated French filmmaker.

Title: Patti Smith on Bob Dylan and DONT LOOK BACK
Description: In this interview, conducted in August 2015, musician Patti Smith discusses the role Bob Dylan and DONT LOOK BACK have played in her life, as well as tour manager Bob Neuwirth, who served as a mentor early in her career.

Title: Lick the Star
Description: Directed by Sofia Coppola • 1998 • United States /  /  /  / Sofia Coppola made the following 16 mm short film in 1998, the same year she began production on THE VIRGIN SUICIDES.

Title: Night Mayor
Description: Directed by Guy Maddin • 2009 • Canada /  / This short Guy Maddin film tells the story of inventor Nihad Ademi, who harnesses the power of the aurora borealis in Winnipeg in 1939. Ademi uses this power to broadcast images of Canada to its own citizens from coast to coast, but in the process angers he the government.

Title: Le chant du styrène
Description: Directed by Alain Resnais • 1959 • France /  / Poetic and aesthetic visit of a large polystyrene factory.

Title: Deborah Jowitt Version Comparison
Description: The original dance “Appalachian Spring,” which premiered at the Library of Congress on October 30, 1944, was part of the Graham company repertoire for many years before Nathan Kroll documented it. Here dance Critic Deborah Jowitt compares excerpts of an earlier filmed performance of the dance, featuring Martha Graham, Eric Hawkins, and Merce Cunninghams, with the 1958 film.

Title: Colin MacCabe on THE LONG DAY CLOSES
Description: In this interview, conducted in New York in 2013, film critic and professor Colin MacCabe describes his former role as the head of the BFI Production Board, which funded director Terence Davies’s early films Death and Transfiguration and Distant Voices, Still Lives. As an executive producer of The Long Day Closes, MacCabe also discusses the financial obstacles encountered by Davies’s films and the unique process of actualizing one of his scripts.

Title: Toni Servillo on GOMORRAH
Description: Actor-director Toni Servillo, who plays the character Franco in GOMORRAH, is from the region in Italy where the film is set. He was interviewed in July 2009 in Rome.

Title: Lambert & Co.
Description: A longtime fan of American jazz vocalist Dave Lambert, D. A. Pennebaker jumped at the chance to film him auditioning a new group of singers at RCA in 1964. The resulting film helped the director understand his artistic mission—as he put it, “Recording people and music as a kind of popular history that might not otherwise exist.”

Title: Martin Scorsese
Description: Filmmaker Martin Scorsese recorded the following introduction to THE LIFE AND DEATH OF COLONEL BLIMP in 2012. The piece was edited by Thelma Schoonmaker Powell.

Title: Francesco Rosi on THE MOMENT OF TRUTH
Description: In this interview, recorded in Italy in 2004, director Francesco Rosi discusses THE MOMENT OF TRUTH.

Title: “Cinépanorama”: Jeanne Moreau, 1962
Description: This 1962 episode of the French television show “Cinépanorama” features an interview with actor Jeanne Moreau on the set of BAY OF ANGELS.

Title: Barbara Loden with Dick Cavett
Description: This episode of “The Dick Cavett Show” features a guest appearance by director Barbara Loden promoting WANDA. It airead March 4, 1971.

Title: Dissolves in THE LONG DAY CLOSES
Description: Professor Kristin Thompson explores the ways in which dissolves allow Terence Davies to mimic the fluidity and emotional texture of memory in his elegiac coming-of-age film.

Title: Cailleach
Description: Directed by Rosie Reed Hillman • 2014 • United Kingdom /  / Morag is 86. She lives alone at the end of a track looking out to sea on her croft on the Isle of Harris, Outer Hebrides, with her three cats and twelve sheep. Morag was born in this house and has lived here her whole life, following five generations of the family who came before her. CAILLEACH is a portrait of Morag and her simple and peaceful life as she contemplates her next chapter, shares her unique sense of independence and the connection she has to her wild island home.

Title: Brad Dourif on WISE BLOOD
Description: Presented here is a 2009 interview with Brad Dourif, who has acted in over one hundred feature films, including LORD OF THE RINGS: THE TWO TOWERS, BLUE VELVET, and MISSISSIPPI BURNING. He was nominated for an Academy Award for his portrayal of Billy Bibbit in ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO’S NEST.

Title: Hsu Feng on A TOUCH OF ZEN
Description: Conducted in 2016, this interview features actor Hsu Feng discussing her iconic role as Yang Hui-zhen in A TOUCH OF ZEN.

Title: Masaki Kobayashi on THE HUMAN CONDITION
Description: In this 1993 video interview, filmed for the Directors Guild of Japan at Tokyo’s Haiyuza Theatre, director Masaki Kobayashi talks to fellow filmmaker and longtime Kobayashi admirer Masahiro Shinoda (DOUBLE SUICIDE) about THE HUMAN CONDITION.

Title: The Horse
Description: Directed by Charles Burnett • 1973 • United States /  /  /  / A young boy keeps a horse company during its last moments of life in Charels Burnett’s spare, lyrical student film, which poignantly contrasts the callousness of adults with the empathy of children. /  /  /  / Limited engagement ends September 30

Title: Happy Anniversary
Description: Directed by Pierre Etaix and Jean-Claude Carrière • 1962 • France /  / A young woman waits and waits for her delayed husband to celebrate their wedding anniversary.

Title: Seide
Description: Directed by Elnura Osmonalieva • 2015 • Kyrgyzstan /  / Young Seide lives in a secluded mountain village in the heart of Kyrgyzstan. She loves her freedom to ride her horse, the closest soul she has, and enjoys playing with the village boys. When she is faced with the prospect of an arranged marriage, her family decides to honour the tradition and kill Seide's horse for the wedding celebration. Upset and feeling voiceless, Seide tries to understand her family's decision but cannot let her horse be killed. Unfortunately, the horse, like herself, has no way of escape. Alone and broken hearted Seide stays in her old but forever changed world.

Title: Scenes from the Making of THE KING OF KINGS
Description: The DeMille Studios produced many reels of behind-the-scenes footage of the cast and crew on the set of THE KING OF KINGS. Shot for publicity use, these clips and stills show the dimension and scale of a DeMille production in full swing.

Title: B. D. Garga’s SATYAJIT RAY
Description: This short 1974 profile by B. D. Garga, one of India’s pioneering documentary filmmakers and a leading Indian film historian, features narration by director Satyajit Ray and on-set footage from the making of THE BIG CITY.

Title: The Editors
Description: In this interview editors Eleanor Hamerow, professor and former chair of the graduate film program at New York University, and Miriam Arsham, a longtime collaborator of Nathan Kroll's, discuss their work on A DANCER'S WORLD, APPALACHIAN SPRING, and NIGHT JOURNEY.

Title: Raoul Coutard on SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER
