Description: Legendary cinematographer Raoul Coutard began his career collaborating with some of the most celebrated directors of the French new wave and went on to shoot more than seventy feature films. In 2003, he was interviewed in Paris and discussed SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER, his first film with director François Truffaut.

Title: “Télécinéma”: MY NIGHT AT MAUD’S Actor and Producer
Description: In this 1974 episode of the French television show “Télécinéma,” directed by Jacques Brialy, host Olivier Lorsac interviews film critic Jean Douchet, actor Jean-Louis Trintignant, and producer Pierre Cottrell.

Title: Luciana Arrighi on MY BRILLIANT CAREER
Description: In this interview, recorded in Los Angeles in 2018, production designer Luciana Arrighi talks about her first collaboration with director Gillian Armstrong, on MY BRILLIANT CAREER.

Title: Donald Richie on AU HASARD BALTHAZAR
Description: Film scholar Donald Richie talks about why he considers himself a “Bressonian” in this interview, recorded in New York in November 2004.

Title: Francesco Rosi on HANDS OVER THE CITY
Description: Director Francesco Rosi talks about his approach to filmmaking and the production of his fourth film, HANDS OVER THE CITY, in this 2006 interview.

Title: Tony Rayns on THE INSECT WOMAN
Description: This interview with film critic Tony Rayns was conducted in December 2008.

Title: Watch Your Left
Description: Directed by René Clément • 1936 • France /  /  /  / This thirteen-minute short, written by Jacques Tati and directed by René Clément, stars Tati as a farmer who dreams of becoming a boxer but is ill-prepped when he gets his wish.

Title: Michael Fassbender on HUNGER
Description: The following interview with actor Michael Fassbender was conducted by film critic Jason Solomons in 2008.

Title: Rossellini at Rice University
Description: In 1970, Roberto Rossellini was invited to Rice University to present his films to students and participate in videotaped discussions with faculty members. The following are excerpts from those rare archival tapes. Leading the discussion is James Blue, then director of Rice Media Center. Also present are professors Colin Young and David MacDougall.

Title: The Extraordinary Life of Rocky
Description: Directed by Kevin Meul • 2010 • Belgium /  / It seems Rocky was born on the wrong side of luck; all the people he loves die from a fatal accident. First his father, then his grandfather and every single time Rocky is at the center of it all. He is like a magnet for misfortune. Rocky's mom is bitter because she loses her husband and dad. She's unable to comfort Rocky because she is not capable of dealing with her own grief. Celine's cold attitude makes Rocky believe he's the cause of all their misery. It's with these delusional ideas that he grows older. Luckily, Rocky meets Angie, the love of his life. But Angie has her own problems...

Title: Ang Lee on A TOUCH OF ZEN
Description: In this 2016 interview, Academy Award–winning filmmaker Ang Lee describes his appreciation for A TOUCH OF ZEN and the influence it had on his own acclaimed martial arts film CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON (2000).

Title: The Darkness of War in WOODEN CROSSES
Description: Professor Kristin Thompson explores how Raymond Bernard evoked the horror and despair of battle in his shatteringly realistic World War I film.

Title: On Suio-ryu
Description: Shot in 2016 for the Criterion Collection, this new interview with Sensei Yoshimitsu Katsuse, fifteenth headmaster of the Suio-ryu martial arts system, documents and demonstrates the reality of samurai swordsmanship in contrast to its fictitious representation of the Lone Wolf and Cub film series.

Title: Candice Bergen on Louis Malle
Description: Actor Candice Bergen and director Louis Malle were married for fifteen years, until his death in 1995. This interview with Bergen was recorded in 2005.

Title: Ask Father
Description: Directed by Hal Roach • 1919 • United States /  / Harold Lloyd plays a young man who attempts to avoid many obstacles in order to marry his boss's daughter.

Title: Jean Cocteau and His Tricks
Description: This interview with ORPHEUS assistant director Claude Pinoteau, about the special effects in Jean Cocteau’s films, was conducted and directed by filmmaker Marc Caro (Delicatessen, City of Lost Children) in 2008.

Title: From Dreyer to von Trier
Description: In this 2005 interview, Henning Bendtsen talks about his early experiences as a young director of photography for Carl Theodor Dreyer and about his final films, made with Lars von Trier.

Title: Benedict Fitzgerald on WISE BLOOD
Description: Presented here is a 2009 interview with Benedict Fitzgerald, whose screenwriting credits include the made-for-television films HEART OF DARKNESS, IN COLD BLOOD, and ZELDA, as well as the most successful independent film of all time, THE PASSION OF THE CHRIST. WISE BLOOD was his first film.

Title: Color Motifs in BLACK NARCISSUS
Description: Professor Kristin Thompson breaks down the lush palette of Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger’s sensuous masterpiece, showing how set designer Alfred Junge and cinematographer Jack Cardiff use splashes of color to trace the film’s emotional arc.

Title: Tony Aboyantz on LE PLAISIR
Description: Tony Aboyantz’s first job in film was as an assistant director on LE PLAISIR. He worked with Ophuls again on LOLA MONTES, then went on to be an assistant director for Jean Girault for many years. This 1989 interview was conducted in Paris by Martina Muller.

Title: Denis Lenoir on CARLOS
Description: This piece, shot in April 2011, features Denis Lenoir, one of CARLOS’s two cinematographers.

Title: Tony Rayns on AN ACTOR’S REVENGE
Description: In this interview, filmmaker, critic, and festival programmer Tony Rayns examines the themes and visual styles of AN ACTOR’S REVENGE and places the film in the context of Kon Ichikawa’s oeuvre.

Title: Hans Hirschmüller on THE MERCHANT OF FOUR SEASONS
Description: The following interview with actor Hans Hirschmüller was conducted in Berlin in February 2015.

Title: Five Deleted Scenes
Description: The following five scenes were deleted from the final version of THE PLAYER. Also presented are some outtakes from the LONELY ROOM scene, featuring actors Lily Tomlin and Scott Glenn.

Title: Tatsuya Nakadai on WHEN A WOMAN ASCENDS THE STAIRS
Description: Tatsuya Nakadai has acted for some of Japan’s greatest directors, including Masaki Kobayashi, Akira Kurosawa, Hiroshi Teshigahara, and Mikio Naruse, and revealed an impressive range, playing everything from samurai to the bar manager Kenichi Komatsu in WHEN A WOMAN ASCENDS THE STAIRS. In this 2005 interview, Nakadai discusses his work with Naruse.

Title: Nadja in Paris
Description: Directed by Eric Rohmer • 1964 • France /  / A university student wanders around Paris in this short film by Eric Rohmer.

Title: The Making of HUNGER
Description: This 2010 program includes interviews with HUNGER director Steve McQueen, actors Michael Fassbender, Liam Cunningham, Stuart Graham, and Brian Milligan, writer Enda Walsh, and producer Robin Gutch.

Title: David Simon on PATHS OF GLORY
Description: In this episode of our ongoing Under the Influence series, “The Wire” creator David Simon draws deep and surprising connections between his groundbreaking television series and Stanley Kubrick’s 1957 antiwar classic PATHS OF GLORY. Recalling his experience viewing the film with a group of Baltimore detectives, the writer and producer discusses how Kubrick’s portrayal of a callous and hypocritical military bureaucracy served as a model of narrative and political complexity for his own sprawling story of institutional dysfunction.

Title: When it Rains
Description: Directed by Charles Burnett • 1995 • United States /  /  /  / Charles Burnett paints a jazz- and poetry-inflected portrait of African American community and resilience via the story of a mother who enlists a musician’s help when she is evicted on New Year’s Day. /  /  /  / Limited engagement ends September 30

Title: Railway Station
Description: Directed by Krzysztof Kieślowski • 1980 • Poland /  /  /  / Krzysztof Kieślowski began his career making documentaries. Presented here is RAILWAY STATION, one of his nonfiction shorts.

Title: The Black Case
Description: Directed by Caroline Monnet and Daniel Watchorn • 2014 • Canada /  / An eight year old girl and her infant cousin experience a series of traumatic events while quarantined in the infirmary of a residential school for Native children in Canada.

Title: Kaiju Bunraku
Description: Directed by Lucas Leyva and Jillian Mayer • 2017 • United States /  /  /  / A day in the life of a Husband and a Wife, living in a world of giant monsters.

Title: Selected-Scene Commentaries: Jérôme Deschamps
Description: The following selected-scene commentary, recorded for Les Films de Mon Oncle in 2013, features theater director Jérôme Deschamps.

Title: Bluebeard
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1938 • France /  / Inspired by the groundbreaking use of film in the analysis of movement by physiologist Étienne-Jules Marey, Jean Painlevé animated the opéra bouffe BLUEBEARD, about the legendary knight, using clay dolls made by sculptor René Bertrand and Bertrand's three young children.

Title: Le cercle de minuit
Description: Days after Marco Ferreri’s death in May 1997, filmmakers Francesco Rosi and Bernardo Bertolucci and film historian Aldo Tassone took part in a roundtable discussion about the director for the French television show “Le cercle de minuit.” Excerpts are presented here, including interview clips with Ferreri from January of the same year.

Title: Saute ma ville
Description: Directed by Chantal Akerman • 1968• Belgium /  /  /  / Directed by and starring Chantal Akerman, this short film was made when she was just eighteen.

Title: Cronenberg: The Early Years
Description: Presented here is CRONENBERG: THE EARLY YEARS, a 2011 interview with David Cronenberg, conducted by “Fangoria” editor in chief Chris Alexander, in which the director discusses his transition from the experimental filmmaking of STEREO (1969) and CRIMES OF THE FUTURE (1970) to working within the commercial Canadian film industry.

Title: Widescreen Composition in SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER
Description: Professor Jeff Smith explores how François Truffaut harnesses the 2.35:1 aspect ratio in his wildly playful gangster-movie pastiche, a giddy high point in the French New Wave’s assault on cinematic convention.

Title: Acera, or The Witches' Dance
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1972 • France /  /  /  / The lives of miniscule mollusks are intimately captured as they wallow in mud, mate and give birth. Director Jean Painlevé sublimely sets their dance like movements to music.

Title: On the Set of EMPIRE OF PASSION
Description: This program, created by Argos Films in 2003, features EMPIRE OF PASSION production consultant Koji Wakamatsu and assistant directors Yusuke Narita and Yoichi Sai.

Title: A WELL SPENT LIFE: No Man Like Mance
Description: This short documentary, produced in 2014, features interviews with Skip Gerson, director Les Blank’s collaborator on A WELL SPENT LIFE; Blank’s sons, Beau and Harrod; and Chris Strachwitz, founder of Arhoolie Records.

Title: Zoom
Description: The following excerpts are from French television interviews that aired when 2 OR 3 THINGS I KNOW ABOUT HER was in production. In this excerpt from the October 25, 1966, episode of “Zoom,” produced by André Harris, Jean-Luc Godard engages in a sociopolitical debate with government official Jean St. Geours.

Title: Yutaka Yamazaki on STILL WALKING
Description: The following interview with STILL WALKING cinematographer Yutaka Yamazaki was shot in August 2010 at the International House of Japan in Tokyo, with Yamazaki acting as cameraman.

Title: David Constantine on 45 YEARS
Description: Author and poet David Constantine was surprised to learn that his short story “In Another Country” had been optioned to be adapted into a film. In this interview, conducted in 2016, Constantine discusses his story, the changes director Andrew Haigh made in adapting it, and how he feels about the final film.

Title: The Octopus
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1927 • France /  / From 1927 to 1928, Jean Painlevé made his first three films aimed at the general public. Shown in 'ciné-clubs' and avant-garde movie theaters of Paris, these films were written and edited to entertain as well as educate. THE OCTOPUS, one of these educational films, is presented here in its original silent version.

Title: Isaach de Bankolé on WHITE MATERIAL
Description: This interview with actor Isaach de Bankolé was recorded in 2010.

Title: Selected-Scene Commentaries: Stéphane Goudet
Description: This selected-scene commentary, recorded for Les Films de Mon Oncle in 2013, features Jacques Tati scholar Stéphane Goudet.

Title: André Wilms on LE HAVRE
Description: In this April 2012 interview, LE HAVRE star André Wilms talks about the film and working with Aki Kaurismäki, who also directed him in LA VIE DE BOHÈME.

Title: The Story of French Cinema By Those Who Made It
Arata Isozaki on Hiroshi Teshigahara
Description: Perhaps best known in America for the design of the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art building, architect Arata Isozaki once collaborated with Hiroshi Teshigahara as art director on his film THE FACE OF ANOTHER. The following interview with Isozaki was recorded in 2006.

Title: The Restless Cinematography of BREAKING THE WAVES
Description: Jeff Smith unpacks Robby Müller’s handheld camera work in Lars von Trier’s wrenching fable, showing how it alternates choppy realism with calculated stylization.

Title: Billy Blazes, Esq.
Description: Directed by Hal Roach • 1919 • United States /  / Harold Lloyd plays Billy Blazes, a man who attempts to save Peaceful Vale from the violent Crooked Charley.

Title: Walking Like the Dead
Description: Made in 2017 by Jim Cirronella, this program features ten cast and crew members discussing what it was like to portray cinema’s original flesh-eating ghouls, in interviews shot for the 2009 documentary AUTOPSY OF THE DEAD.

Title: Playing by Different Rules
Description: THE RULES OF THE GAME originally ran 94 minutes. After a negative response, Renoir cut it to 81. During World War II, the film was destroyed by bombs. In 1959, it was reconstructed, with Renoir’s approval, from surviving elements, becoming the 106-minute version we know. Chris Faulkner compares the endings of the longest and shortest versions.

Title: Jeff Wall on OSSOS
Description: In this video essay, celebrated contemporary artist Jeff Wall, known for his sumtuous large-scale photographs and his love of cinema, examines the power of Pedro Costa's images. His words are presented alongside visuals from OSSOS.

Title: A Modern Coed
Description: Directed by Eric Rohmer • 1966 • France /  / An examination of the lifestyles of female college students in 1966. Directed by Eric Rohmer.

Title: Susan Cooke Kittredge on ALL AT SEA
Description: The following interview with Susan Cooke, Alistair Cooke’s daugher, was filmed in 2010.

Title: Q&A on PICKPOCKET
Description: In this Q&A footage from a 2000 screening of PICKPOCKET at the Reflet Médicis cinema in Paris, actor Marika Green and filmmakers Paul Vecchiali and Jean-Pierre Améris field questions about the film.

Title: Satyajit Ray on Progress
Description: In the following audio interview, recorded in Berlin on July 2, 1966, director Satyajit Ray and film journalist Gideon Bachmann discuss the recurring theme of progress in Ray’s films.

Title: Continuity Editing in THE DEVIL AND DANIEL WEBSTER
Description: Professor Jeff Smith walks us through the basics of continuity editing and shows how William Dieterle’s faustian fever dream adheres to that code while testing the limits of its expressive potential.

Title: The Making of ANTICHRIST: Sound and Music
Description: Made in 2010 by Zentropa’s DVD production company, Electric Parc.

Title: Out in the Woods
Description: Maureen Gosling, the sound recordist and assistant editor on A POEM IS A NAKED PERSON, spent two years making the film with director Les Blank, living for much of that time in northeastern Oklahoma, where Leon Russell was building a new recording studio. During that period, she shot her own Super 8 footage, a portion of which is presented here.

Title: Monika: Kroger Babb’s Bad Girl
Description: In 1955, producer, showman, and distributor Kroger Babb bought the American rights to SUMMER WITH MONIKA, cut it down, added a dub track and a jazz score, and distributed it as MONIKA, THE STORY OF A BAD GIRL! In this 2012 interview, film historian Eric Schaefer explains how director Ingmar Bergman’s film became grist for the exploitation mill.

Title: Sea Ballerinas
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1956 • France /  / Colorful underwater photography highlights this educational film about starfish.

Title: Rui Nogueira on LE SAMOURAÏ
Description: “Melville on Melville,” Rui Nogueira’s 1971 book of interviews with Jean-Pierre Melville, was for decades the only English-language work devoted to the director’s films. In 2003, cinema historian Ginette Vincendeau added “Jean-Pierre Melville, An American in Paris.” In this 2005 video interview, Nogueira shares his thoughts on LE SAMOURAÏ.

Title: GODZILLA Cast and Crew: Akira Takarada
Description: In this 2011 interview, actor Akira Takarada recalls his experience starring as Ogata in GODZILLA.

Title: Inventing ANDREI RUBLEV
Description: In this 2018 video essay, filmmaker Daniel Raim explores Andrei Tarkovsky’s creative process and the unique aesthetic philosophy he applied in creating ANDREI RUBLEV, using the director’s own words from interviews and essays.

Title: Hans Fromm on PHOENIX
Description: In this interview, filmed in Berlin in January 2016, cinematographer Hans Fromm describes the inspiration for the lush noir look of PHOENIX, and how his relationship with director Christian Petzold has evolved over the course of their two decades of collaboration.

Title: Nicolas Roeg and Jeremy Thomas on INSIGNIFICANCE
Description: INSIGNIFICANCE was the third collaboration between director Nicolas Roeg and producer Jeremy Thomas. This interview with the pair was conducted in London in December 2010.

Title: Genre Play in THE PLAYER
Description: Jeff Smith walks us through Robert Altman’s most intricately allusive film, a satire that enlists genre tropes in order to send up the Hollywood assembly line that spits them out.

Title: “Cinéma cinémas”: Samuel Fuller, 1987
Description: This interview with director Samuel Fuller was excerpted from a 1987 episode of the French television series “Cinéma cinémas.”

Title: Martin Scorsese on THE RIVER
Description: This interview with filmmaker Martin Scorsese was conducted in the fall of 2004. Scorsese, a fan of THE RIVER since childhood, was instrumental in the 2004 restoration of the film through his work with The Film Foundation.

Title: Charlotte et son Jules
Description: Directed by Jean-Luc Godard • 1959 • France /  / A jilted man rants at his mostly silent former lover.

Title: Masterless Samurai
Description: In this 2005 interview, conducted in Tokyo, HARAKIRI screenwriter Shinobu Hashimoto talks about his creative process in writing the script and recalls the reactions to the film.

Title: Michel Piccoli on Marco Ferreri
Description: The prolific French actor Michel Piccoli made six films with Marco Ferreri; DILLINGER IS DEAD was the first. In this interview, recorded in 2009, Piccoli discusses his experience working with Ferreri and what made the director a rarity in cinema.

Title: On Solace
Description: In this 2014 video essay, filmmaker :: kogonada explores director Ingmar Bergman’s CRIES AND WHISPERS, a film in three movements.

Title: Abdellatif Kechiche on THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN
Description: The following interview with director Abdellatif Kechiche was conducted in March 2010.

Title: B. Ruby Rich on Dorothy Arzner
Jacques Witta on RED
Description: In this 2001 interview, Jacques Witta, editor of BLUE and RED, reveals why certain scenes (and parts of shots) in RED were ultimately removed, and shares anecdotes about director Krzysztof Kieślowski’s process in the editing room.

Title: Behind-the-Scenes TV Trailer
Description: The following 12-minute trailer for RICHARD III was produced by Laurence Olivier and includes on-set footage of Olivier, producer Alexander Korda, and other members of the cast and crew.

Title: Neil LaBute on NAKED
Description: The following interview with filmmaker Neil LaBute was recorded in Vancouver in 2005.

Title: BRUTE FORCE: The Actor’s Toolkit
Description: What do actors do when they act? Few aspects of film craft are as widely discussed—and as little understood.

Title: GIRL SHY: Harold Lloyd Meets Classical Hollywood
Description: David Bordwell shows how Harold Lloyd helped silent comedy evolve from gag-based skits to increasingly intricate narrative forms.

Title: Steve Buscemi on SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM
Description: Acclaimed actor and director Steve Buscemi first saw SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM TAKE ONE at the Sundance Film Festival, in 1992, and he was so taken with it and director William Greaves that he pledged his support to the film and any sequels. In this new interview, recorded in New York in 2006, Buscemi talks about his enthusiasm for TAKE ONE and his participation in SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM TAKE 2 1/2.

Title: Defining a Style
Description: In this 2005 featurette, many key WATERSHIP DOWN animators and background artists recall their painstaking work on this landmark adaptation.

Title: Richard Porton on VIRIDIANA
Description: In this interview, conducted in August of 2005, “Cinéaste” editor Richard Porton discusses VIRIDIANA both in terms of Luis Buñuel’s style and in the context of the director’s return to his native Spain.

Title: Adriano Aprà on GERMANY YEAR ZERO
Description: Film historian and teacher Adriano Aprà has devoted much of his career to Roberto Rossellini and his films, directing the 1992 film ROSSELLINI VISTO DA ROSSELLINI, editing the 1992 collection of Rossellini essays and interviews “My Method,” and writing the 2006 book “In viaggio con Rossellini.” This interview with Apra, in which he discusses GERMANY YEAR ZERO, was conducted in 2009.

Title: Jan-Christopher Horak on KAMERADSCHAFT
Description: In this 2016 interview, Jan-Christopher Horak, director of the UCLA Film & Television Archive, discusses the importance of KAMERADSCHAFT to director G. W. Pabst’s career.

Title: BREAKING THE WAVES: Deleted and Extended Scenes
Actor Daniel Gelin on LA RONDE
Description: Daniel Gelin, noted for his work with directors Jean Cocteau, Louis Malle, and Alfred Hitchcock, made two films with Max Ophuls, LA RONDE and LE PLAISIR. In this interview, conducted by Martina Muller in 1989, Gelin discusses his experiences working on LA RONDE.

Title: Nicole Stéphane LES ENFANTS TERRIBLES
Description: In this interview by journalist Patrick Simonin, made in 2003 for the French television channel TV5 Monde, actor Nicole Stéphane reminisces about her friendship with author and filmmaker Jean Cocteau and her experiences shooting LES ENFANTS TERRIBLES.

Title: Manthia Diawara on BOROM SARRET
Description: In this 2016 piece, filmmaker and cultural theorist Manthia Diawara (“African Film: New Forms and Aesthetics and Politics”) addreses the significance of Ousmane Sembène's debut film.

Title: Manthia Diawara on BOROM SARRET
Description: In this 2016 piece, filmmaker and cultural theorist Manthia Diawara (“African Film: New Forms and Aesthetics and Politics”) addreses the significance of Ousmane Sembène's debut film.

Title: Tony Rayns on INTENTIONS OF MURDER
Description: This interview with film critic Tony Rayns was conducted in December 2008.

Title: Rupture
Description: Directed by Pierre Etaix and Jean-Claude Carrière • 1961 • France /  / A man receives a breakup letter from his sweetheart. The pained lover decides to reply, yet his writing utensils conspire to thwart him.

Title: When We Lived in Miami
Description: Directed by Amy Seimetz • 2013 • United States /  / Filmed during Hurricane Isaac, WHEN WE LIVED IN MIAMI is a hypnotic short about the lengths one woman will go to keep her family from falling apart.

Title: Barbet Schroeder on GENERAL IDI AMIN DADA (2002)
Description: The following interview with Barbet Schroeder was recorded at his home in New York City in 2002. Schroeder set up his own production company in 1964 and produced such films as Eric Rohmer’s MY NIGHT AT MAUD’S. Since 1969, he has had a distinguished career as a director of both documentaries and narrative films, including GENERAL IDI AMIN DADA, BARFLY, and REVERSAL OF FORTUNE.

Title: Barbet Schroeder on GENERAL IDI AMIN DADA (2017)
Description: The following interview with director Barbet Schroeder was conducted in 2017.

Title: Bruce Beresford on BREAKER MORANT
Description: In this 2015 interview, BREAKER MORANT director and coscreenwriter Bruce Beresford recalls the production of this landmark Australian film.

Title: Guillermo Navarro on CRONOS
Description: In this interview from 2009, Guillermo Navarro, an Oscar-winning cinematographer (PAN’S LABYRINTH) and longtime collaborator of Guillermo del Toro’s, talks about his work on CRONOS and his relationship with the director.

Title: Écrans Noirs Film Festival, 2010
Description: In the following short film, director Claire Denis documents her return to Cameroon for the 2010 premiere of WHITE MATERIAL at the Écrans Noirs Film Festival.

Title: Toni Servillo on THE GREAT BEAUTY
Description: Primarily a stage actor until he starred in Paolo Sorrentino’s 2001 film ONE MAN UP, Toni Servillo has since collaborated with the director several more times. In this interview, conducted in November 2013, Servillo discusses his work with Sorrentino, especially in THE GREAT BEAUTY.

Title: The World of Kazuo Miyagawa
Description: Renowned cinematographer Kazuo Miyagawa collaborated with a number of great Japanese filmmakers, including Akira Kurosawa, Kenji Mizoguchi, Kon Ichikawa, and Yasujiro Ozu. The following excerpts from the Japanese television documentary THE WORLD OF KAZUO MIYAGAWA explore Miyagawa and Kurosawa’s working relationship on RASHOMON.

Title: Soumendu Roy on PATHER PANCHALI
Description: Soumendu Roy first worked with Satyajit Ray as attendant to the 35 mm Mitchell camera the director had rented to shoot PATHER PANCHALI; in later years, he would become one of Ray’s main camera operators. In this 2013 interview, Roy shares his observations on Ray’s direction and recalls the production of his debut film.

Title: Same Player Shoots Again
Description: The following short film was directed by Wim Wenders in 1967.

Title: You Owe Me One
Description: Directed by Carlos Cuarón • 2002 • Mexico /  / Carlos Cuarón wrote and directed this twelve-minute short in 2002, taking a look at family secrets hidden behind closed doors.

Title: Marin Karmitz on Jean-Luc Godard
Description: In the following interview, conducted in 2014, Marin Karmitz, founder of the film production and distribution company MK2, talks about his career-long association with director Jean-Luc Godard and helping to produce EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF, which Godard referred to as his “second first film.”

Title: M’Bissine Thérèse Diop on BLACK GIRL
Description: Conducted in 2016, this interview with actor M’Bissine Thérèse Diop covers her lead role in BLACK GIRL.

Title: The Maestro
Description: In this interview, conducted in July 2014, Gerald Gaxiola—a.k.a. the Maestro—provides his unique perspective on THE MAESTRO: KING OF THE COWBOY ARTISTS, the film Les Blank made about him and the time they spent together.

Title: Restoring THE APU TRILOGY: The Longer Version
Description: The following program was created by filmmaker :: kogonada in 2015.

Title: Une histoire d'eau
Description: Directed by Jean-Luc Godard and François Truffaut • 1958 • France /  / In this short film, a young woman tries to go to Paris, but her garden and the whole village is flooded with water.

Title: Ira Sachs on FOX AND HIS FRIENDS
Description: This interview with filmmaker Ira Sachs was conducted in New York in October 2016.

Title: Kazuma Nozawa on LONE WOLF AND CUB
Description: Filmed in 2016, this piece features Kenji Misumi biographer Kazuma Nozawa discussing the work of the director of four of the six LONE WOLF AND CUB films.

Title: Staging and Performance in IVAN THE TERRIBLE, PART 2
Description: Professor David Bordwell explores the “expressive movement” that animates one of Sergei Eisenstein’s boldest experiments in film form, demonstrating how the director draws on the language of dance and painting.

Title: Stellan Skarsgård on BREAKING THE WAVES
Description: In this interview, conducted in Stockholm in May 2013, Stellan Skarsgård, who plays Jan in BREAKING THE WAVES, talks about working with director Lars von Trier for the first time on the film, and their subsequent collaborations.

Title: Deleted Scenes
Description: With Nagisa Oshima’s approval, IN THE REALM OF THE SENSES producer Antole Dauman shortened six scenes, to bring the film to his preferred length. The sections of deleted footage are presented here in the context of their original placement in the film. They appear in full color, surrounded by final-cut footage in black and white.

Title: Cinéma cinémas: Wim Wenders Hollywood April ’84
Description: This April 2, 1984, episode of the French television program “Cinéma cinémas,” “Wim Wenders Hollywood April ’84,” features the director and composer Ry Cooder working on the score for PARIS, TEXAS.

Title: Incident by a Bank
Description: Directed by Ruben Östlund • 2009 • Sweden /  / INCIDENT BY A BANK is a detailed and humorous account of a failed bank robbery: A single take where over 96 people perform a meticulous choreography for the camera. This short film recreates an actual event that took place in Stockholm back in June 2006; it's an observation in real-time and a study of how people act and react to the unexpected.

Title: Guillermo del Toro on WATERSHIP DOWN
Description: In this 2014 interview, filmmaker Guillermo del Toro talks about what makes WATERSHIP DOWN a unique work of animation art.

Title: Footprints
Description: Directed by Jaromil Jireš • 1960 • Czechoslovakia /  /  /  / This early short by Jaromil Jireš anticipates the formal and stylistic experimentation that would characterize VALERIE AND HER WEEK OF WONDERS.

Title: The Stripped-Down Style of ALI: FEAR EATS THE SOUL
Description: Professor Jeff Smith illustrates how Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s deliberate blocking and tableau compositions accentuate the social divisions that crisscross his 1974 masterpiece.

Title: “Pour changer étoiles et toiles”: François Truffaut
Description: In this excerpt from a 1982 episode of the program “Pour changer étoiles et toiles,” François Truffaut discusses writer David Goodis and the process of adapting his novel “Down There” for the film SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER.

Title: Julie: Old Time Tales of the Blue Ridge
Description: This twelve-minute film, composed of footage shot during the making of SPROUT WINGS AND FLY, focuses on Julie Lyons, sister of the film’s subject, Tommy Jarrell.

Title: Donald Richie on FIRES ON THE PLAIN
Description: In this interview, recorded in New York in 2006, Japanese-film historian Donald Richie discusses director Kon Ichikawa’s career and his 1959 masterpiece FIRES ON THE PLAIN.

Title: Music and Dolly Shots
Description: In this conversation from 2003, director Agnès Varda and composer Joanna Bruzdowicz discuss the music they created for VAGABOND, along with the dolly shots that it accompanies throughout the film.

Title: Haunted Memoirs
Description: In 2006, director Robert Day, screenwriter Jan Read, and costars Jean Kent and Vera Day remembered the making of THE HAUNTED STRANGLER and their own on- and off-set experiences with actor Boris Karloff.

Title: Steven Soderbergh on GRAY’S ANATOMY
Description: This interview with director Steven Soderbergh was conducted in New York in March 2012.

Title: Festival Ephemera: Photo-Essay with Commentary
Description: Photographer Elaine Mayes was recorded in New York City in the spring of 2002.

Title: The Acquaintances of a Lonely John
Description: Directed by Benny Safdie • 2008 • United States /  / John lives his life alone trying to connect with anything or anyone he can. Sometimes it is hard to tell the difference between hysterical crying and hysterical laughter.

Title: Passionless Moments
Description: Directed by Jane Campion • 1983 • Australia /  / This short film co-directed by Jane Campion and Gerard Lee portrays the awkward trials of everyday living.

Title: Michelangelo Antonion on RED DESERT
Description: This interview with director Michelangelo Antonioni about RED DESERT was conducted as part of the French television series “Les écrans de la ville.” It was directed by Colette Thiriet and first broadcast on November 12, 1964.

Title: Censored
Description: When THE WAGES OF FEAR was first shown in the U.S. in 1955, it was in a much shorter form than the original. It is believed that the distributor cut perceived anti-Americanism and suggestions of homosexuality to appease U.S. sensibilities of the time. This 2004 program analyzes this censorship and presents several of the contested scenes.

Title: Seijun Suzuki and Masami Kuzuu on TOKYO DRIFTER
Description: In this interview, recorded in July 2011, director Seijun Suzuki and assistant director Masami Kuzuu recall the production of TOKYO DRIFTER.

Title: Ron Simon on Nathan Kroll
Description: Musician turned producer Nathan Kroll began his career in television by preserving the work of Martha Graham in A DANCER’S WORLD, APPALACHIAN SPRING, and NIGHT JOURNEY. He then dedicated himself to documenting the arts for television, winning three Peabody Awards, an Emmy, and numerous other honors. In this interview Museum of Television and Radio curator Ron Simon discusses Kroll's work and legacy.

Title: The Restraint of L’AVVENTURA
Description: Professor David Bordwell applies his analysis of film language to Michelangelo Antonioni’s L’AVVENTURA, illustrating how the director uses careful staging and methodical framing to keep us guessing about his characters’ feelings and motivations.

Title: Jean-Pierre Gorin on BOUDU
Description: Filmmaker, writer, and educator Jean-Pierre Gorin began his career as Jean-Luc Godard’s collaborator on the Dziga Vertov Group films, including TOUT VA BIEN. In 2005, he spoke about Jean Renoir and BOUDU SAVED FROM DROWNING.

Title: Maynard Eziashi on MISTER JOHNSON
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2015, actor Maynard Eziashi, who plays the titular character in MISTER JOHNSON, describes the whirlwind experience of his first starring role.

Title: Sylvette Baudrot on PLAYTIME
Description: Sylvette Baudrot has been a script supervisor for more than five decades and worked with director Jacques Tati on three of his films. In this 2006 interview, she recalls collaborating on PLAYTIME.

Title: Seijun Suzuki and Masami Kuzuu on BRANDED TO KILL
Description: In this interview, recorded in July 2011, director Seijun Suzuki and assistant director Masami Kuzuu recall the production and release of BRANDED TO KILL.

Title: “Pour le cinéma”: Louis Malle, 1975
Description: In this excerpt from the September 21, 1975, episode of the French television program “Pour le cinéma,” director Louis Malle offers some insight into BLACK MOON’s characters, its setting in the French countryside, and its unique look and sound.

Title: Chaplin’s Comedy of Murders
Description: From tramp to serial killer: find out how Charlie Chaplin reinvented himself for this pitch-black comedy.

Title: Maria Pia Casilio on UMBERTO D.
Description: Actress Maria Pia Casilio’s first film role was in UMBERTO D., when she was still in her teens. In this interview, conducted in 2003, she describes being discovered by director Vittorio De Sica and discusses her work in the film.

Title: Jacques Champreux on JUDEX
Description: In this interview from 2007, JUDEX cowriter Jacques Champreux recalls collaborating with director Georges Franju on his 1963 film, which was a remake of the 1916 serial of the same name, directed by Champreux’s grandfather Louis Feuillade.

Title: Misterio
Description: Directed by Chema García Ibarra • 2013 • Spain /  / They say that if you put your ear to the back of his neck, you can hear the Virgin talk.

Title: The Langlois Affair
Description: These archival newsreels, narrated by cinema historian Bernard Eisenschitz, offer a poignant glimpse into a turbulent period that deeply affected filmmaker François Truffaut.

Title: Soldiers’ Journals: Sergeant Finlay Campbell
Description: While writing the script for OVERLORD, director Stuart Cooper and cowriter Christopher Hudson read the journals of two D-day soldiers, Sergeant Edward Robert McCosh and Sergeant Finlay Campbell. Moved by these soldiers’ experiences, they incorporated some of their recollections into the protagonist’s story. Here, Brian Stirner, who plays Tom in Overlord, reads excerpts from their journals. Born in Scotland in April 1923, Finlay Campbell was called up in December 1941 and spent the next six months training at the Royal Corps of Signals HQ in Catterick, England. He served in Kent and Scotland before returning to the Home Counties in the winter of 1943, when intensive training for the opening of the Second Front began.

Title: Faces of November
Description: Directed by Robert Drew • 1964 • United States /  / An intimate portrait of President John F. Kennedy's funeral in November of 1963, this short work crafted by documentarian Robert Drew captures one of the most solemn moments in U.S. history.

Title: The Hall of Lost Steps
Description: Directed by Jaromil Jireš • 1960 • Czechoslovakia /  /  /  / This early short by Jaromil Jireš anticipates the formal and stylistic experimentation that would characterize VALERIE AND HER WEEK OF WONDERS.

Title: An Act of Love
Description: Directed by Lucy Knox • 2018 • Australia /  / A close bond between two identical twins is tested when one sister rebels against their shared sense of oneness.

Title: Willy Kurant on MASCULIN FÉMININ
Description: A cinematographer for more than forty years, Willy Kurant has shot film for some of the best directors in cinema. From Jean-Luc Godard, on MASCULIN FÉMININ, to Orson Welles, on IMMORTAL STORY (1968), to Agnes Varda, on LES CRÉATURES (1969). The Criterion Collection interviewed Kurant in Paris, in April of 2005.

Title: Le cercle de minuit
Description: This segment from a 1994 episode of the French television program “Le cercle de minuit” features interviews with director Olivier Assayas and actors Virginie Ledoyen and Cyprien Fouquet.

Title: To Touch a Child
Description: CARNIVAL OF SOULS director Herk Harvey and screenwriter John Clifford were employed for over thirty years by the Lawrence, Kansas–based industrial film giant the Centron Corporation. Between them, Harvey and Clifford made over four hundred films for Centron, from which the following segment has been selected.

Title: Al Ruban on Lighting and Shooting FACES
Description: FACES was shot on 16 mm on a shoestring budget. In this 2013 piece, director of photography Al Ruban details the various film stocks and lighting techniques used to achieve its unique look.

Title: Margarethe von Trotta on BAAL
Description: The following interview with filmmaker Margarethe von Trotta was conducted in Munich in December 2017.

Title: Daniel Gelin on LE PLAISIR
Description: Actor Daniel Gelin, noted for his work with directors Jean Cocteau, Louis Malle, and Alfred Hitchcock, made two films with Max Ophuls, LA RONDE and LE PLAISIR. In this interview, conducted by Martina Muller in 1989, Gelin discusses his experiences on LE PLAISIR.

Title: Limitations into Virtues
Description: In this 2017 video essay, filmmakers Tony Zhou and Taylor Ramos (Every Frame a Painting) examine the style of NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD.

Title: Barney Rosset and Edward de Grazia
Description: Publishing legend Barney Rosset and attorney Edward de Grazia were pioneers in the battle against censorship in this country. Each was also influential in bringing I AM CURIOUS—YELLOW to U.S. audiences. In 2002, Rosset and de Grazia discussed the film, the landmark court case, and their ongoing efforts for freedom of expression.

Title: Learning from Scratch
Description: In this 2017 interview, NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD cowriter John Russo remembers the Latent Image, the commercial and industrial-film production company in which he and cowriter-director-editor George A. Romero were partners, and discusses its importance in preparing the filmmakers for their feature debut.

Title: Donald Richie
Description: In this introduction, recorded in New York in 2004, Japanese-film scholar Donald Richie analyzes important themes and motifs in HARAKIRI and discusses the antiauthoritarian focus of its creators. Please note: the introduction contains remarks about the ending of the film.

Title: Abderrahmane Sissako on TOUKI BOUKI
Description: In this 2013 interview, filmmaker Abderrahmane Sissako (WAITING FOR HAPPINESS) shares his appreciation for Djibril Diop Mambéty’s 1973 film TOUKI BOUKI.

Title: The Emotional Music Script
Description: In this 2005 interview, composer Joachim Holbek discusses the method he and Lars von Trier employed in writing EUROPA’s musical score.

Title: LE HAVRE at Cannes: Interview
Description: LE HAVRE was a sensation at the 2011 Cannes Film Festival, receiving a standing ovation at its premiere and winning the FIPRESCI prize, given by the International Federation of Film Critics. In the following footage from the festival—an interview recorded for French television—the playful spirit of the film’s cast and crew is on display, as they do their best to confound the international press.

Title: “Pour le cinéma”: On the Set of DONKEY SKIN, 1970
Description: Director Jacques Demy and actors Catherine Deneuve, Jean Marais, and Jacques Perrin are interviewed on the set of DONKEY SKIN in this segment from a 1970 episode of the French television program “Pour le cinéma.”

Title: Adriano Aprà on ROME OPEN CITY
Description: Scholar Adriano Aprà has devoted much of his career to Roberto Rossellini, directing the 1992 film ROSSELLINI VISTO DA ROSSELLINI, editing the 1992 collection of Rossellini essays and interviews “My Method,” and writing the 2006 book “In viaggio con Rossellini.” This interview with Aprà, in which he discusses ROME OPEN CITY, was conducted in 2009.

Title: Sharmila Tagore on THE HERO
Description: The following interview with actor Sharmila Tagore was recorded in 2008 by producer Nasreen Munni Kabir.

Title: Edward James Olmos
Description: Edward James Olmos's role in ¡ALAMBRISTA! was one of the earliest screen appearances by this groundbreaking actor, director, and producer. In this interview, recorded in 2010, Olmos discusses the work of his longtime friend director Robert M. Young and the importance of ¡ALAMBRISTA!

Title: I Graduated, But . . .
Description: Directed by Yasujiro Ozu • 1929 • Japan /  / An unemployed college graduate attempts to trick his family into thinking that he has a job.

Title: Introducing Explosive Political Cinema of the 1960s
Catherine Breillat on FAT GIRL, 2001, Berlin
Description: FAT GIRL was first shown to the public on February 10, 2001, when it ran in competition at the Berlin International Film Festival. The following interview with director Catherine Breillat was conducted for German television the day after the screening but never broadcast in its entirety.

Title: Maurice Pialat on Set
Description: In this excerpt from a 1983 episode of the television program “Étoiles et toiles,” director Maurice Pialat is seen interacting with actors and crew on the set of À NOS AMOURS. He also discusses his approach to directing and cinematography.

Title: Jean-Pierre Gorin on À NOS AMOURS
Description: Jean-Pierre Gorin is best known for making seven films with Jean-Luc Godard as the Dziga Vertov Group, including 1972’s TOUT VA BIEN, after which he went on to direct several documentaries and become a professor of film studies at the University of California, San Diego. In 2006, he spoke about À NOS AMOURS.

Title: Neil LaBute on LOVE IN THE AFTERNOON
Narrative Symmetry in CHUNGKING EXPRESS
Description: David Bordwell unpacks Wong Kar-wai’s intricate approach to double-pronged storytelling in one of the defining works of nineties cinema.

Title: N.U.
Description: Directed by Michelangelo Antonioni • 1948 • Italy /  /  /  / This 1948 film by Antonioni documents the lives of street cleaners in Rome. N.U. is short for Nettezza urbana, the Italian municipal cleaning service.

Title: Lou Adler, 2017
Description: In this interview, conducted in Los Angeles in July 2017, Lou Adler, who organized and produced the Monterey International Pop Festival with John Phillips in 1967, reflects on a 2017 anniversary festival that took place in Monterey, an exhibition of Monterey Pop ephemera, and the continued impact of the original festival and the film MONTEREY POP.

Title: THE PASSION OF JOAN OF ARC: About the Frame Rates
Description: The advent of sound cinema standardized film playback at 24 frames per second, but silent films were played at various speeds, sometimes differing from reel to reel within the same film. In this audio essay, recorded in 2017, Danish film scholar Casper Tybjerg explores the debate over the proper frame rate for THE PASSION OF JOAN OF ARC.

Title: Aki and Peter
Description: THE OTHER SIDE OF HOPE is dedicated to filmmaker Aki Kaurismäki’s longtime friend and collaborator, the film critic and festival programmer Peter von Bagh. In this new video essay, filmmaker Daniel Raim explores Kaurismäki’s oeuvre through the world of von Bagh.

Title: Rentaro Mikuni on THE BURMESE HARP
Description: Here, actor Rentaro Mikuni, who plays Captain Inouye in THE BURMESE HARP, recalls his experiences working with Kon Ichikawa. This interview was recorded in Japan in 2006.

Title: Father Virgilio Fantuzzi on THE FLOWERS OF ST. FRANCIS
Description: This interview, with film critic Father Virgilio Fantuzzi, was taped in Rome, in 2004.

Title: Umberto Contarello on THE GREAT BEAUTY
Description: Screenwriter Umberto Contarello has written for numerous directors, including Paolo Sorrentino, Carlo Mazzacurati, and Bernardo Bertolucci. In this interview, conducted in November 2013, he discusses working with Sorrentino and the inspiration for the character of Jep Gambardella in THE GREAT BEAUTY.

Title: The Complexity of Influence
Description: In this video essay, produced in 2014, film critic Kent Jones details how director Alfred Hitchcock influenced François Truffaut’s filmmaking, especially in THE SOFT SKIN.

Title: A Loaf of Bread
Description: Director Jan Němec's graduation film, A Loaf of Bread (Sousto), was filmed in 1960 and based on a story by Arnošt Lustig, also the author of the novel on which DIAMONDS OF THE NIGHT is based.

Title: John Bailey
Description: In this interview, cinematographer John Bailey talks about the unique visual challenges in shooting A Brief History of Time and his experiences working with director Errol Morris.

Title: Split Screen: Christopher Walken Cooks
Description: Christopher Walken cooks with Julian Schnabel and a guy named Cha-Cha. From Season 9, Episode 1.

Title: Hazel Dickens on HARLAN COUNTY USA
Description: Hazel Dickens grew up in a West Virginia coal-mining community and had a successful career as a bluegrass singer and songwriter. Her songs on coal mining caught the attention of producer-director Barbara Kopple, who asked her to provide material for HARLAN COUNTY USA’s soundtrack. In this 2006 interview, Dickens reflects on her career and the film.

Title: Kassagi
Description: A sleight-of-hand artist and pickpocket consultant to director Robert Bresson, Kassagi shows off his skills in this footage from the show “La piste aux étoiles,” originally broadcast on French television in 1962.

Title: David Maysles on SALESMAN
Description: “Newsweek” critic Jack Kroll interviewed Albert and David Maysles upon the theatrical release of SALESMAN. This interview aired in 1969 as part of a WCBS-TV series called “Camera Three.”

Title: Michael Haneke on CODE UNKNOWN’s Boulevard Sequence
Description: In this interview from March 2001, director Michael Haneke discusses the filming of the boulevard sequence in CODE UNKNOWN.

Title: Lelia Goldoni on SHADOWS
Description: Lelia Goldoni was eighteen years old and a student at the Cassavetes-Lane Drama Workshop when she was cast as the female lead in SHADOWS. This 12-minute interview with her was conducted in Los Angeles in 2004.

Title: Cannes Film Festival: John Lurie
Description: This interview with actor-composer John Lurie was shot for French television during the 1986 Cannes Film Festival.

Title: Kazuo Koike on LONE WOLF AND CUB
Description: Filmed in 2015, this piece features “Lone Wolf and Cub” manga writer Kazuo Koike discussing the comics and the film series.

Title: Next Floor
Description: Directed by Denis Villeneuve • 2008 • France /  / During an opulent and luxurious banquet, complete with cavalier servers and valets, eleven pampered guests participate in what appears to be a ritualistic gastronomic carnage. In this absurd and grotesque universe, an unexpected sequence of events undermines the endless symphony of abundance.

Title: Tomás Gutiérrez Alea Audio Interview
Description: The following is a segment from an audio interview with director Tomás Gutiérrez Alea recorded by Silvia Oroz for her 1989 book “Tomás Gutiérrez Alea: Los filmes que no filmé.”

Title: Bertrand Tavernier on LE DEUXIÈME SOUFFLE
Description: Acclaimed director Bertrand Tavernier (COUP DE TORCHON, ROUND MIDNIGHT) began his film career as a critic and publicist. It was in the latter role that he was involved with filmmaker Jean-Pierre Melville’s LE DEUXIÈME SOUFFLE. In this 2008 interview, Tavernier talks about his memories of the film, as well as of Melville the man.

Title: Nixon Responds to the House Judiciary Committee
Description: The following was broadcast live nationwide on April 29, 1974.

Title: Vadim Yusov on IVAN’S CHILDHOOD
Description: In this 2007 interview, cinematographer Vadim Yusov, a longtime collaborator of Andrei Tarkovsky’s (ANDREI RUBLOV, SOLARIS), reminisces about his work with the director on IVAN’S CHILDHOOD.

Title: The Roxy Theater
Description: The latest entry in our original series of art-house profiles explores Missoula’s Roxy Theatre, home of the International Wildlife Film Festival, and gives the theater’s programmers a chance to present Jean Painlevé’s surreal aquatic documentaries.

Title: André Wilms on LA VIE DE BOHÈME
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2012, actor André Wilms talks about meeting director Aki Kaurismäki and the making of LA VIE DE BOHÈME.

Title: The Small Details
Description: In the following interview, conducted in 2013, film writer Ujjal Chakraborty discusses the many symbolic details throughout APARAJITO.

Title: Robeson on Robeson
Description: After Paul Robeson's death, on January 23, 1976, his son, Paul Robeson Jr., turned his own life's work to preserving his father's. In this 2007 program, Robeson Jr., author of “The Undiscovered Paul Robeson” and cofounder of the Paul Robeson Foundation, briefly discusses his father's approach to film, and specifically his role as Emperor Jones.

Title: Hunger
Description: Directed by Peter Foldes • 1973 • Canada /  /  /  / In this animated short, director Peter Foldes depicts one man's descent into greed and gluttony. Rapidly dissolving and ever-evolving images create a contrast between abundance and want. One of the first films to use computer animation, this satire serves as a cautionary tale against self-indulgence in a world still plagued by hunger and poverty.

Title: “Cinépanorama”: Jacques Demy and Michel Legrand
Description: Director Jacques Demy and composer Michel Legrand are interviewed about THE UMBRELLAS OF CHERBOURG in this 1964 episode of the French television program “Cinépanorama.”

Title: Fernando Fernán Gómez on THE SPIRIT OF THE BEEHIVE
Description: This interview with actor Fernando Fernán Gómez was recorded in January 2006, in Madrid.

Title: Peter Bogdanovich on LA BÊTE HUMAINE
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2004, filmmaker Peter Bogdanovich discusses Jean Renoir's achievement with LA BÊTE HUMAINE.

Title: Life and Freaky Times of Uncle Luke
Description: Directed by Lucas Leyva and Jillian Mayer • 2012 • United States /  / Uncle Luke changes the face of hip-hop, is elected mayor of Miami and survives a nuclear meltdown.

Title: Casus Belli
Description: Directed by Yorgos Zois • 2010 • Greece /  / All kinds of people are waiting in seven different queues. The first person of each queue becomes the last of the next one, thus creating an enormous human line. But at the end of the line, it all begins backwards again.

Title: Revoir HIROSHIMA . . .
Description: In 2013, Argos Films, the Technicolor Foundation, the Groupama Gan Foundation, and the Cineteca di Bologna collaborated on a 4K digital restoration of HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR. Davide Pozzi, director of L’Immagine Ritrovata at the Cineteca, discusses the delicate restoration process with cinematographer Renato Berta, a special consultant on the project.

Title: Tones of Terror
Description: This 2017 program featuring producer Jim Cirronella delves into the skillful use of existing library music for the scoring of NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD.

Title: Michael Fitzgerald on MISTER JOHNSON
Description: In the following interview, recorded in 2015, producer Michael Fitzgerald looks back on his journey to making a big-screen adaptation of Joyce Carey’s 1939 novel MISTER JOHNSON.

Title: Isabelle Huppert on THE PIANO TEACHER
Description: This interview with actor Isabelle Huppert was conducted in Paris in June 2017.

Title: The Company on Tour, 1954
Description: In 1954 the Martha Graham Dance Company spent four months on an extensive tour of Europe. Presented here are excerpts of silent 16mm home-movie footage from that tour, featuring performances and behind-the-scenes footage of Graham and her company members. Identifications were provided by Marni Thomas and Ethel Winter.

Title: Martin Scorsese on JOURNEY TO ITALY
Description: This interview with filmmaker Martin Scorsese was conducted by critic Kent Jones in June 2013.

Title: Kent Jones on L’ENFANCE NUE
Description: Kent Jones is the author of "Physical Evidence: Selected Film Criticism" and the executive director of the World Cinema Foundation. Here, he discusses Maurice Pialat's unique visual and narrative approach in L’ENFANCE NUE.

Title: Orson Welles on CHIMES AT MIDNIGHT
Description: This excerpt from “The Merv Griffin Show,” broadcast September 21, 1965, features an interview with director Orson Welles while at the editing table for CHIMES AT MIDNIGHT.

Title: La chambre
Description: Directed by Chantal Akerman • 1972 • Belgium /  /  /  / In Chantal Akerman's early short film LA CHAMBRE, we see the furniture and clutter of one small apartment room become the subject of a moving still life, with Akerman herself staring back at us. This breakthrough formal experiment is the first film the director made in New York.

Title: Nobuko Miyamoto on TAMPOPO
Description: In this interview, actor Nobuko Miyamoto talks about playing the title role in TAMPOPO and working with her husband, director Juzo Itami. It was recorded in 2016.

Title: Exploring the Film
Description: In this discussion, recorded in 2003, Ingmar Bergman biographer peter Cowie offers additional context for the film trilogy of which THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY is a part, as well as for the film specifically—its inception, key players, and themes.

Title: “Cinépanorama”: Anna Karina, 1962
Description: This interview with actor Anna Karina first aired on the French television program “Cinépanorama” on April 7, 1962, a few months before the release of VIVRE SA VIE.

Title: Voyage to the Sky
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1937 • France /  / On assignment for the mathematics department of le Palais de la Découverte, Jean Painlevé shot this film to be presented at the Paris museum's 1937 international exhibition. VOYAGE TO THE SKY muses on extraterrestrial landscapes and earth's role in the universe.

Title: Barry Day on BLITHE SPIRIT
Description: In the following interview, recorded in October 2011, Noël Coward expert Barry Day, author of “Coward on Film: The Cinema of Noël Coward,” discusses BLITHE SPIRIT.

Title: Gente del Po
Description: Directed by Michelangelo Antonioni • 1947 • Italy /  /  /  / This film of a barge trip down the Po River is, along with N.U., one of several early nonfiction shorts by Michelangelo Antonioni to look at the relationship between individuals and their environment, a theme the director would fully explore in such films as RED DESERT. It was made between 1943 and 1947.

Title: DONKEY SKIN Illustrated
Description: This short program from 2008 presents images from several illustrated editions of Charles Perrault’s fairy tale “Peau d’âne,” including those from the first printing in 1695.

Title: About “Voices of Light”
Description: Richard Einhorn composed the oratorio “Voices of Light,” inspired by Carl Th. Dreyer's THE PASSION OF JOAN OF ARC, in 1994. In this 2017 interview, Einhorn discusses his extensive research into the life of Joan of Arc.

Title: BREATHLESS as Criticism
Description: In this 2007 video essay, film historian and author Jonathan Rosenbaum explores a number of the cinematic and literary references in BREATHLESS, elucidating what Jean-Luc Godard meant when he said he approached filmmaking as criticism.

Title: Francine Bergé on JUDEX
Description: The following interview with actor Francine Bergé, who plays Diana in JUDEX, was recorded in 2012 for the Cinémathèque française in Paris.

Title: “Cinéma”: Jacques Demy and Michel Legrand
Description: In this interview from a 1966 episode of the French television program “Cinéma,” director Jacques Demy and composer Michel Legrand talk about their process for creating the music for THE YOUNG GIRLS OF ROCHEFORT.

Title: Bouraouïa Marzouk on THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN
Description: This 2010 interview features actress Bouraouïa Marzouk, who plays Souad in THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN.

Title: That's Him
Description: Presented here are two rarely seen Harold Lloyd shorts: Over the Fence (1917), the first "Glasses Character" film, and That's Him (1918). Lloyd lost many of his early films in a fire, and these have been restored from the best existing elements-a 9.5 mm print and a 28 mm print, respectively-and are accompanied by new scores performmed by Mark Herman on a historic Wurlitzer theater pipe organ owned by film and television composer Nathan Barr. Also included are a discussion about these early film formats by Dino Everett, archivist at the University of Souther California's Hugh M. Hefner Moving Image Archive, and a video tour of the Wurlitzer organ lead by Barr and Herman.

Title: Isabelle Huppert on EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2014, actor Isabelle Huppert recalls working with director Jean-Luc Godard on EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF.

Title: Restoration Demonstration: SHADOWS
Description: The following program details the UCLA Film & Television Archive’s work to preserve SHADOWS. The bulk of the restoration took place from 2000 to 2002, with funding provided by the Film Foundation and the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, among other organizations.

Title: Adriano Aprà on JOURNEY TO ITALY
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2011, critic Adriano Aprà examines the evolution of Roberto Rossellini’s style in JOURNEY TO ITALY, as well as the consistency of the director’s themes across his career.

Title: Jackie Coogan on THE KID
Description: This interview with THE KID costar Jackie Coogan was originally recorded by Kevin Brownlow and David Gill for the 1980 British television series “Hollywood: A Celebration of the American Silent Film.”

Title: Barbet Schroeder on KOKO
Description: In this interview, conducted in New York in 2006, director Barbet Schroeder discusses the film’s origins, documentary filmmaking, and what it was like working with Koko.

Title: Truffaut on THE SOFT SKIN
Description: In this excerpt from a December 1965 episode of the French television program “Cinéastes de notre temps,” director François Truffaut talks about the origins of THE SOFT SKIN, shooting its love scenes, and choreographing its finale.

Title: Back to Castiglioncello
Description: The 2012 film L’ESTATE DI BRUNO CORTONA: CASTIGLIONCELLO NELL’ANNO DEL “SORPASSO” returns to Castiglioncello, the beach town where much of the second half of IL SORPASSO takes place, fifty years after the release of the film. This excerpt features interviews with members of the cast and crew.

Title: Collette Costa on Her Film Selections
Restoring DETOUR
Description: This 2018 program details the challenges that the Academy Film Archive and The Film Foundation, in collaboration with the Cinémathèque royale de Belgique, the Museum of Modern Art, and the Cinémathèque française faced in the restoration of DETOUR.

Title: Nikolai Burlyaev on IVAN’S CHILDHOOD
Description: In this 2007 interview, actor Nikolai Burlyaev offers heartfelt memories of playing the title role in IVAN’S CHILDHOOD and working with director Andrei Tarkovsky.

Title: Peter Bogdanovich on FRENCH CANCAN
Description: The following interview with filmmaker Peter Bogdanovich was recorded in New York in November 2003.

Title: Sea Urchins
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1928 • France /  / Jean Painlevé delivers an intimate (and microscopic) view of sea urchins.

Title: Making History
Description: Filmed in 2016, this program featuring Shih Chun details the actor’s experiences making DRAGON INN.

Title: Paul Schrader on PERSONA
Description: Writer and director Paul Schrader has long been a fan of Ingmar Bergman’s work. In this 2013 interview, Schrader discusses the lasting impact of PERSONA.

Title: Joe Shishido on BRANDED TO KILL
Description: This interview with BRANDED TO KILL star Joe Shishido was recorded by the Criterion Collection in July 2011.

Title: Alain Resnais on HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR
Description: In the first of these two interviews with Alain Resnais, excerpted from a 1961 episode of the French television show “Cinépanorama,” the director talks with François Chalais about his early career. In the second, excerpted from a 1980 broadcast of the French radio program “Le cinéma des cinéastes,” Resnais reflects on the making of HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR.

Title: Preserving Harold
Description: Presented here are two rarely seen Harold Lloyd shorts: Over the Fence (1917), the first "Glasses Character" film, and That's Him (1918). Lloyd lost many of his early films in a fire, and these have been restored from the best existing elements-a 9.5 mm print and a 28 mm print, respectively-and are accompanied by new scores performmed by Mark Herman on a historic Wurlitzer theater pipe organ owned by film and television composer Nathan Barr. Also included are a discussion about these early film formats by Dino Everett, archivist at the University of Souther California's Hugh M. Hefner Moving Image Archive, and a video tour of the Wurlitzer organ lead by Barr and Herman.

Title: Kieślowski’s Cinema Lesson: WHITE
Description: In this piece from 1994, director Krzysztof Kieślowski reviews the opening scene from WHITE and reveals how it was shaped in the editing room.

Title: Robert Vattier on THE MARSEILLE TRILOGY
Description: The following short profile of Robert Battier, titled UN BRUN DE VATTIER, follows the actor around Provence and aired on French television on April 20, 1976. Vattier, who played M. Brun in the MARSEILLE TRILOGY films, discusses his long friendship with writer-director Marcel Pagnol and the impact Marius, Fanny, and Cesar had on his career.

Title: Outtakes: Philippe Devillers
Description: In 1945, Philippe Devillers was assigned as press attaché to French General Philippe Leclerc and concurrently acted as the Indochina correspondent for “Le monde.” Devillers, who authored several books on Vietnam, was critical of French and American policies in Vietnam and here discusses the misconceptions he believes both countries perpetuated.

Title: Kyoko Kagawa
Description: In this interview, actor Kyoko Kagawa talks about her experiences playing the role of Osan in A STORY FROM CHIKAMATSU. It was recorded in Tokyo in 2018.

Title: Ed Lachman on LIFE DURING WARTIME
Description: This interview with LIFE DURING WARTIME director of photography Ed Lachman was conducted in March 2011.

Title: On Y TU MAMÁ TAMBIÉN: Then
Description: This documentary was created at the time of the production of Y TU MAMÁ TAMBIÉN in 2001 and features interviews with director Alfonso Cuarón, cowriter Carlos Cuarón, director of photography Emmanuel Lubezki, and actors Gael García Bernal, Diego Luna, and Maribel Verdú.

Title: GAP-TOOTHED WOMEN: Mind the Gap
Description: This piece, produced in 2014, features interviews with Susan Kell and Chris Simon, both of whom collaborated with director Les Blank on numerous films, as well as Blank’s son Harrod.

Title: Malle and Moreau at Cannes, 1993
Description: For this conversation, recorded at the 1993 Cannes Film Festival for the French television program “Le cercle de minuit,” director Louis Malle and actor Jeanne Moreau sat down with Michel Field to reflect on their early work together and Malle’s development as a director.

Title: Catherine Breillat on À NOS AMOURS
Description: Catherine Breillat has made such controversial films as 36 FILLETTE, ROMANCE, and FAT GIRL. Also a novelist and screenwriter, she wrote the screenplay for Maurice Pialat’s 1985 film POLICE. Here she is interviewed in January 2006.

Title: Denis Lenoir on COLD WATER
Description: This interview with cinematographer Denis Lenoir was conducted in Los Angeles in May 2018.

Title: Marin Karmitz on RED
Description: In the following interview from 2001, Marin Karmitz, producer of the THREE COLORS trilogy, recalls the making of RED and the insistence in Hollywood that the film be considered for the Academy Awards.

Title: M le maudit
Description: For the television program “Ciné parade” in 1982, Claude Chabrol was asked to inaugurate a series of contemporary homages to classic cinema. Chabrol—himself often a director of tense psychosexual dramas—chose the ur-thriller M. In this short, a sort of M in ten minutes, Maurice Risch plays Peter Lorre playing Hans Beckert.

Title: THE SILENCE: Exploring the Film
Description: In this new video discussion, Ingmar Bergman biographer Peter Cowie sheds light on THE SILENCE—its controversial appeal, austere setting, opposing characters, and Bergman’s personal religious catharsis.

Title: Peter Weir on THE LAST WAVE
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2001, director Peter Weir remembers THE LAST WAVE.

Title: “Les nouveaux rendez-vous”: THE LAST METRO
Description: Director François Truffaut and actors Catherine Deneuve and Gérard Depardieu talk about THE LAST METRO in this excerpted 1980 interview from the French television program “Les nouveaux rendez-vous.”

Title: Judith Ridley on NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD
Description: Produced in 1994 by Elite Entertainment, this interview features actor Judith Ridley discussing her role in NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD.

Title: Joanna Hogg Interview
Description: In this interview filmed in 2019, Joanna Hogg looks back on her directing career so far.

Title: Tord and Tord
Description: Directed by Niki Lindroth von Bahr • 2010 • Sweden /  / One day, Tord accidentally walks in to the apartment next to his own. Another person named Tord lives there, he has just moved in.

Title: THE WAR ROOM: Stanley Greenberg
Description: Polling is the necessary but misunderstood dark art at the center of modern political campaigns. In this interview, shot in November 2011, Stanley Greenberg, pollster for the 1992 Clinton campaign, among many others, discusses the nuances of the job.

Title: French Roundtable
Description: This excerpt from the French television program “L’invité de FR3” features director Satyajit Ray, film critic Michel Ciment, filmmaker Claude Sautet, and host Dominique Reznikoff. Directed by Yves Barbara, the episode was broadcast before the 1981 French theatrical premiere of THE MUSIC ROOM—more than twenty years after the film’s release in India.

Title: Split Screen: The Blair Witch Project
Description: A three-person documentary crew disappears deep in the woods of Maryland. From Season 2, Episode 5.

Title: True West
Description: In this 2010 video interview, Pulitzer Prize–winning author Buzz Bissinger (“Friday Night Lights”) explains the key role that 1920s trading post operator Harry Goulding played in bringing Monument Valley to the attention of the STAGECOACH production, thereby establishing a new cinematic icon of the American West.

Title: Raoul Coutard Shoots Z
Description: In 2009, cinematographer Raoul Coutard discusses his experience working with Costa-Gavras on Z.

Title: The Fourth Dimension
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1936 • France /  / On assignment for the mathematics department of le Palais de la Découverte, Jean Painlevé shot this film to be presented at the Paris museum's 1937 international exhibition. THE FOURTH DIMENSION takes a look at how we interact with dimensional space.

Title: Shrimp Stories
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1964 • France /  / After a quick comic introduction, SHRIMP STORIES takes a detailed look at the lives of shrimp.

Title: The Stations of Filth
Description: This video essay on MULTIPLE MANIACS was created in 2016 by film scholar Gary Needham.

Title: Introducing Paolo and Vittorio Taviani
Description: Film scholar David Forgacs introduces the filmmaking duo who breathed new life into the Italian neorealist tradition.

Title: Take a Chance
Description: Directed by Alfred J. Goulding • 1918 • United States /  / In this one-reel film from 1918, Harold Lloyd stars as a man looking to spend his last 25 cents.

Title: GOMORRAH Actors
Description: This short video piece, produced in 2009, features GOMORRAH actors Toni Servillo, Gianfelice Imparato, and Salvatore Cantalupo.

Title: Jean-Pierre Gorin on HANDS OVER THE CITY
Description: Filmmaker and educator Jean-Pierre Gorin (TOUT VA BIEN, LETTER TO JANE, POTO AND CABENGO) takes a critical look at Francesco Rosi’s acclaimed film HANDS OVER THE CITY, in this 2006 interview.

Title: Mario Monicelli
Description: In the following piece, recorded in 2006, director Mario Monicelli introduces THE ORGANIZER.

Title: Peter Cowie Afterword to THE SEVENTH SEAL
Description: This afterword, made in 2008, features film scholar Peter Cowie discussing THE SEVENTH SEAL in a follow-up to his 1987 Criterion commentary track.

Title: Pennebaker on BREATHLESS
Description: Director Jean-Luc Godard once described BREATHLESS as “a documentary about Jean-Paul Belmondo and Jean Seberg.” In this 2007 interview, documentary filmmaker D. A. Pennebaker explores Godard’s statement.

Title: Kazuo Miyagawa on UGETSU
Description: One of cinematography’s finest talents, Kazuo Miyagawa shot many of Japan’s most celebrated films, including Akira Kurosawa’s RASHOMON; Kenji Mizoguchi’s UGETSU, SANSHO THE BAILIFF, and STREET OF SHAME; and Yasujiro Ozu’s FLOATING WEEDS. This interview was recorded in 1992 for the Criterion laserdisc release of UGETSU. Miyagawa died in 1999.

Title: Similarities Between Length and Speed
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1937 • France /  / On assignment for the mathematics department of le Palais de la Découverte, Jean Painlevé shot this film to be presented at the Paris museum's 1937 international exhibition. SIMILARITIES BETWEEN LENGTH AND SPEED offers a mathematical look at proportions.

Title: Julien Duvivier on PÉPÉ LE MOKO
Description: This interview with director Julien Duvivier, in which he discusses his career and PÉPÉ LE MOKO, was conducted for the French television program “Cinépanorama” in 1962.

Title: For the Love of Garlic
Description: This short piece, produced in 2014, features interviews with Maureen Gosling, the editor of GARLIC IS AS GOOD AS TEN MOTHERS; director Les Blank’s son Harrod; and Alice Waters, chef and founder of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, California.

Title: The Phoenix Rises
Description: Conducted in 2018, this interview features actor Shangkuan Ling-fung recalling her work on DRAGON INN with director King Hu.

Title: THE PASSION OF JOAN OF ARC: Version History
Cloud Phenomena of Maloja
Description: Segments of this short documentary, directed by Arnold Fanck in 1924, appear in CLOUDS OF SILS MARIA. Presented in its entirety here, CLOUD PHENOMENA OF MALOJA shows the cloud formations from which both works take their names. It is accompanied by a score by the Sardinian jazz trumpet player Paolo Fresu, in Cuneo, Italy, in 2010.

Title: Shohei Imamura on VENGEANCE IS MINE
Description: In this excerpt from a 1999 interview for the Directors Guild of Japan, director Shohei Imamura discusses VENGEANCE IS MINE with his frequent collaborators Kunio Takeshige and Ken’ichi Benitani.

Title: GARLIC IS AS GOOD AS TEN MOTHERS: Remembering Les
Description: Producer and programmer Tom Luddy and chef Alice Waters’s long friendship with director Les Blank began in Berkeley, California, in the late 1960s. Luddy fell in love with Blank’s films then, and Waters hosted Blank regularly at her restaurant. In this 2014 conversation, they discuss Blank’s contributions to their community and the world of film.

Title: The Making of AN ANGEL AT MY TABLE
Description: This documentary, created in 2002 by Bridget Ikin and Tiara Lowndes, provides a glimpse into the making of AN ANGEL AT MY TABLE and its extraordinary reception and success.

Title: Juzo Itami & Nobuko Miyamoto
Description: This director-actor duo collaborated on a string of genre-bending films anchored by fiercely independent women.

Title: Sea Urchins
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1954 • France /  / From 1927 to 1928, Jean Painlevé made his first three films aimed at the general public. Shown in 'ciné-clubs' and avant-garde movie theaters of Paris, these films were written and edited to entertain as well as educate. SEA URCHINS, one of these educational films, is presented here in its original silent version.

Title: Stig Bjorkman on BREAKING THE WAVES
Description: In this interview, conducted in New York in May 2013, filmmaker and critic Stig Björkman talks about being on location during the shooting of BREAKING THE WAVES and observing director Lars von Trier at work.

Title: FISTS IN THE POCKET: Bernardo Bertolucci Afterword
Description: In this video interview, shot in Rome in 2005, acclaimed filmmaker Bernardo Bertolucci (a contemporary of Marco Bellocchio) discusses his reaction to FISTS IN THE POCKET and explains the film’s importance to Italian cinema.

Title: Jean-Claude Drouot Returns
Description: In 2006 Agnès Varda followed Jean-Claude Drouot, who plays François in LE BONHEUR, as he returned to the movie’s setting of Fontenay-aux-Roses and retraced his steps. He also reconnects with local residents, some of whom were featured in the film.

Title: Introducing Hong Sang-soo
Description: Author Phillip Lopate explores the work of the prolific South Korean filmmaker.

Title: Jean-Claude Carrière on BELLE DE JOUR
Description: Screenwriter Jean-Claude Carrière worked on several films with director Luis Buñuel, but none of their collaborations was a bigger success or more influential than BELLE DE JOUR. This interview with Carrière was conducted at his home in Paris in 2011.

Title: TAKE A CHANCE Commentary
Description: This commentary features director and Harold Lloyd archivist Richard Correll and film writer John Bengtson.

Title: Alekan ’85
Description: The following excerpted conversations with Henri Alekan—shot by filmmaker André Bonzel in November 1985, when he was a student at the Belgian film school INSAS—are from an unfinished documentary about the legendary cinematographer.

Title: Kyoko Kagawa on SANSHO THE BAILIFF
Description: Legendary actress Kyoko Kagawa’s career spans more than fifty years and features work with some of Japan’s greatest directors, including Akira Kurosawa (HIGH AND LOW), Mikio Naruse (MOTHER), and Yasujiro Ozu (TOKYO STORY). In this interview recorded in 2007, she recalls her experiences making SANSHO THE BAILIFF and working with its master filmmaker, Kenji Mizoguchi.

Title: Mastering a New Medium: Sound in M
Description: Listen closely: Fritz Lang’s claustrophobic thriller has one of the densest, most skillfully layered soundtracks in all of early sound film.

Title: THE SPIRIT OF THE BEEHIVE: A Child’s Point of View
Description: Using the great Spanish film THE SPIRIT OF THE BEEHIVE, by Victor Erice, professor Kristin Thompson shows how restricting us to a child's point of view can make the familiar seem strange and emphasize the horrors of war.

Title: Kazuo Koike on LADY SNOWBLOOD
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2015, prolific author Kazuo Koike talks about his original “Lady Snowblood” manga.

Title: Bryan Brown on BREAKER MORANT
Description: In the following 2015 interview, actor Bryan Brown talks about his international breakthrough performance as Lieutenant Peter Handcock in BREAKER MORANT.

Title: Hyas and Stenorhynchus
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1927 • France /  / An informative and visually stunning study of two small species of crustaceans set to music.

Title: Silvia Pinal on Luis Buñuel
Description: Silvia Pinal made three films with Luis Buñuel—VIRIDIANA, THE EXTERMINATING ANGEL, and SIMON OF THE DESERT—all produced by her husband at the time, Gustavo Alatriste. In this interview, conducted in Mexico City in January 2006, she discusses her work with the director.

Title: Welcome to Bleak House
Description: This tour of Guillermo del Toro’s office (dubbed Bleak House by the director), shot in 2010, offers a unique perspective on the mind of the highly imaginative filmmaker.

Title: Nixon: A Self-Portrait
Description: The following is a biographical film created for Richard Nixon’s 1968 presidential campaign.

Title: ALWAYS FOR PLEASURE: Celebrating a City
Description: This short documentary, produced in 2014, features interviews with Maureen Gosling, who collaborated with director Les Blank on ALWAYS PLEASURE, and David Silberberg, who worked with Blank on numerous other film projects.

Title: Vanessa Redgrave on TOM JONES
Description: Actor Vanessa Redgrave was married to director Tony Richardson from 1962 to 1967. In the following interview, recorded in New York in October 2017, she reminisces about visiting the set of TOM JONES and discusses Richardson’s groundbreaking work.

Title: A Master Percussionist
Description: This piece, produced in 2014, features interviews with SWORN TO THE DRUM’s producer, Tom Luddy, a longtime friend and supporter of director Les Blank’s, and Chris Simon, who collaborated with Blank on numerous films.

Title: Memory and Meaning: The Music of HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR
Description: In the following interview, conducted in March 2015, Tim Page, professor of music and journalism at USC, talks about the contributions of composers Giovanni Fusco and Georges Delerue to HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR.

Title: WINTER LIGHT: Exploring the Film
