Description: In this exclusive recording for WINTER LIGHT, biographer Peter Cowie discusses Ingmar Bergman’s inspiration for the film, his revolutionary direction, and the performance of actor Gunnar Björnstrand.

Title: WEEKEND Audition Tape
Description: This brief audition footage, shot by producer Tristan Goligher, features actors Tom Cullen and Chris New performing two short scenes from WEEKEND. Each scene is followed by the final version from the film.

Title: Hitchcock/Truffaut
Description: In these 1962 audio interview excerpts, illustrated with images and film clips, director Alfred Hitchcock reminisces about THE LADY VANISHES and British cinema with filmmaker François Truffaut. Helen G. Scott serves as translator.

Title: Jean-Paul Rappeneau on ZAZIE DANS LE MÉTRO
L’invité du dimanche
Description: In this segment from the January 6, 1969, episode of the French television series “L’invité du dimanche,” director Claude Chabrol and journalist Bertrand Jérôme return to the town where LE BEAU SERGE was shot, eleven years after the release of the film. The segment was directed by Roger Kahane and Daniel Georgeot.

Title: Marc Godin on THE WAGES OF FEAR
Description: Marc Godin is the coauthor, with Henri-Georges Clouzot’s godson José-Louis Bocquet, of the illustrated biography “Clouzot: Cinéaste.” He was interviewed in Paris in 2005.

Title: Marie Colmant on BAY OF ANGELS
Description: In the following interview, conducted in 2013, journalist Marie Colmant, coauthor of the book “Jacques Demy,” explores the director’s affection for outcasts.

Title: Production History: Jean Gaborit and Jacques Durand
Description: In this 1965 interview from the television program “Les écrans de la ville,” Jean Gaborit and Jacques Durand, who were responsible for the reconstruction of THE RULES OF THE GAME, discuss their role in the film’s history.

Title: George Stevens Jr. on GEORGE STEVENS: D-DAY TO BERLIN
Presentation, or Charlotte and Her Steak
Description: Directed by Eric Rohmer • 1951 • France /  / Walter and Charlotte are a young couple who engage in an awkward conversation before Charlotte is set to take a train out of town.

Title: Young Mr. Jazz
Description: Directed by Hal Roach • 1919 • United States /  / A young couple on the run encounter car trouble - right outside a dancehall teeming with outlaws. The two go through a slapstick struggle to keep the crooks, and the girlfriend's angry father, at bay.

Title: Camera Movement in THREE COLORS: RED
Description: Professor Jeff Smith shows us how Krzysztof Kieślowski’s THREE COLORS: RED uses camera movements to establish elusive connections between two characters who are largely unaware of one another.

Title: An Appreciation by Taylor Hackford
Description: In this interview, conducted in September 2013, filmmaker Taylor Hackford, a lifelong admirer of the work of Les Blank, discusses THE BLUES ACCORDIN’ TO LIGHTNIN’ HOPKINS, the film that galvanized Blank’s career.

Title: Reediting TOM JONES
Description: Tony Richardson’s director’s cut of TOM JONES, released in 1989, is seven minutes shorter than the original theatrical cut. In the following 2017 interview, editor Robert Lambert discusses working with Richardson on this version of the film.

Title: The Amateur and the Craftsperson
Description: This video essay looks at TAMPOPO’s themes of self-improvement and mastery of a craft. It was created by filmmakers Tony Zhou and Taylor Ramos in 2017.

Title: Marie Dubois on SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER
Description: Marie Dubois had appeared in only one film when François Truffaut chose her to star as Léna in SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER. She went on to appear in films by Louis Malle and Luchino Visconti, among others. In August of 2005, she gave this exclusive interview in Paris.

Title: The Shower
Description: Directed by Pepa San Martín • 2011 • Chile /  / A couple separates. Elisa got a job outside the country and Manuela, who lived with her five years, has decided not to accompany her. Unable to say goodbye, they spend the last morning together refugees under the shower water.

Title: The Centron Corporation: History
Description: This essay on the history of the Centron Corporation appears in author Ken Smith’s Book “Mental Hygiene: Classroom Films 1945–1970.” It is read here by writer and comedian Dana Gould.

Title: Paraíso
Description: Directed by Nadav Kurtz  • 2012 • United States /  / Three immigrant window cleaners risk their lives every day rappelling down some of Chicago's tallest sky-scrapers. PARAISO reveals the danger of their job and what they see on the way down.

Title: Robert M. Young on Children of the Fields
Description: Robert M. Young's documentary short CHILDREN OF THE FIELDS, produced for the Xerox Corporation's television series Come Over to My House in 1973, became a key source of research for his first feature film, ¡ALAMBRISTA!. Presented here is a video interview with Young.

Title: An Appreciation by Werner Herzog
Description: In this interview, conducted in September 2013, filmmaker Werner Herzog—whose movie FITZCARRALDO is the subject of Les Blank’s documentary BURDEN OF DREAMS—discusses his admiration for SPEND IT ALL.

Title: Yakima Canutt on STAGECOACH
Description: Yakima Canutt was the talent behind the amazing physical feats in STAGECOACH, and he would go on to revolutionize Hollywood’s stuntman industry. In this 2010 video piece, acclaimed stunt coordinator and stuntman Vic Armstrong (RAIDERS OF THE LOST ARK) offers his thoughts on Canutt and his contribution to filmmaking.

Title: Flashbacks in THE PHANTOM CARRIAGE
Description: Professor Kristin Thompson explores the intricate chronology of Victor Sjöström’s innovative ghost story.

Title: YOUNG MR. JAZZ Commentary
Description: This commentary features director and Harold Lloyd archivist Richard Correll and film writer John Bengtson.

Title: TARIS Commentary
Description: Recorded in 2011, this commentary features Michael Temple, author of "Jean Vigo".

Title: Lita Grey Chaplin on THE KID
Description: In this interview, Lita Grey Chaplin recalls her role as the flirtatious angel in THE KID, the production of THE GOLD RUSH, and her eventual marriage to Charlie Chaplin at the age of sixteen. The interview was conducted by Chaplin biographer Jeffrey Vance in 1993.

Title: Quicker Than the Eye: Editing in SANSHIRO SUGATA
Description: Our home film school continues with David Bordwell’s analysis of Akira Kurosawa’s first film, a showcase for the powerhouse director’s range of talents.

Title: Catherine Breillat on FAT GIRL, 2004
Description: In this 2004 interview, director Catherine Breillat discusses her filmmaking methods and the alternate ending to FAT GIRL.

Title: Taris
Description: Directed by Jean Vigo • 1931 • France /  / Jean Vigo's inventive short portrait of Jean Taris, a swimming champion.

Title: Gloria!
Description: Directed by Hollis Frampton • 1979 • United States /  / Intended as one of the final films in the Magellan Calendar, THE DEATH OF MAGELLAN: GLORIA!, made in 1979, was the first work of Hollis Frampton's to feature a computer. The photographer turned filmmaker was at that time experimenting in the digital arts, an area in which he led courses at the Center for Media Study at the State University of New York at Buffalo.

Title: The Sun's Gonna Shine
Description: Filmed in 1968, while Les Blank was shooting THE BLUES ACCORDIN’ TO LIGHTNIN’ HOPKINS, THE SUN’S GONNA SHINE is the director’s lyrical re-creation of a memory from Hopkins’s youth, when he decided, at age eight, to stop chopping cotton and start singing for a living. This ten-minute film features Hopkins’s performance of “Trouble in Mind.”

Title: Ceramics from Ilza (Ceramika Ilzecka)
Description: Andrzej Wajda was one of the Polish Film School's first students when it opened its doors in Lodz in 1948. During his studies, he made three short films. CERAMICS FROM ILZA (CERAMIKA ILZECKA, 1951), his second film, is presented here courtesy of the school. Wajda collaborated with cinematographer Jerzy Lipman, with whom he went on to make A GENERATION, KANAL, and other films.

Title: THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK: Hank Wilson Interview
Description: During preproduction on THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK, director Robert Epstein recorded draft interviews with more than forty people before deciding on the eight subjects seen in the film. Presented here are excerpts from an interview with gay rights activist Hank Wilson, which was not included in the film.

Title: The Belcourt Theatre
Description: Discover the storied history of the indispensable Nashville movie theater and community hub committed to enriching its city through cinema.

Title: On Musashi Miyamoto, Part 3
Description: The character Musashi Miyamoto was inspired by the historical figure of the same name. In this interview, conducted in 2012, translator and historian William Scott Wilson (“The Lone Samurai”) discusses the real-life events corresponding to the time frame of SAMURAI III: DUEL AT GANRYU ISLAND.

Title: Harry Britt, Harvey Milk’s Successor
Description: Harry Britt was appointed to succeed Harvey Milk as supervisor; a human rights activist like Milk, he was then elected for five more years. The following is an excerpt from a speech Britt delivered at a 2003 event marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of Milk’s assassination.

Title: Volker Schlöndorff on THE BRIDGE
Description: In this February 2015 interview, Volker Schlöndorff discusses THE BRIDGE, focusing on its impact on younger Germans and the affection he and his fellow New German Cinema filmmakers had for director Bernhard Wicki.

Title: Ed Lachman: Selected-Scene Commentary
Description: This selected-scene commentary featuring LIFE DURING WARTIME director of photography Ed Lachman was conducted in March 2011.

Title: Louis Malle on THE LOVERS, 1963
Description: Director Louis Malle had recently completed THE FIRE WITHIN when he was interviewed for “Cinépanorama” about his success with THE LOVERS. That interview, directed by François Chalais and Jean-Pierre Fleury, originally aired on October 19, 1963.

Title: Surface Tension
Description: Directed by Hollis Frampton • 1968 • United States /  / A film in three parts: a man talking while a telephone rings, a walking tour of New York, and a goldfish swimming.

Title: GODZILLA Cast and Crew: Haruo Nakajima
Description: In this 2011 interview, GODZILLA performer Haruo Nakajima reflects on the challenges and highlights of portraying the iconic creature.

Title: Split Screen: The Fiji Stooges
Description: Dueling indies at the world’s most remote movie theater, in Fiji, where the Three Stooges are gods. From Season 10, Episode 3.

Title: BLIND CHANCE: Censored Segments
Description: The following program shows the nine sections of BLIND CHANCE that were altered. The censored segments appear in color.

Title: 2 or 3 Things: A Concordance
Description: This video essay traces the sources of many of the quotations and references that make up the script of 2 OR 3 THINGS I KNOW ABOUT HER.

Title: FISH TANK Audition Footage
Description: These auditions for the pivotal role of Mia reveal the array of talent available to director Andrea Arnold during the casting of FISH TANK.

Title: Just Neighbors
Description: Directed by Harold Lloyd and Frank Terry • 1919 •  /  / Suburban neighbors join together to build a garden shed, but end up demolishing their garden in this short silent comedy.

Title: Nicholson Reads “L’AVVENTURA: A Moral Adventure”
Description: The following essay by Michelangelo Antonioni—part of the original publicity materials for L’AVVENTURA—is read by Jack Nicholson, who worked with the director on THE PASSENGER.

Title: Godfrey Chesire and Jamsheed Akrami
Description: In 2018, the Criterion Collection recorded this conversation between critic Godfrey Cheshire and scholar and filmmaker Jamsheed Akrami on the subject of Abbas Kiarostami’s last film.

Title: Daphnia
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1928 • France /  / From 1927 to 1928, Jean Painlevé made his first three films aimed at the general public. Shown in 'ciné-clubs' and avant-garde movie theaters of Paris, these films were written and edited to entertain as well as educate. DAPHNIA, one of these educational films, is presented here in its original silent version.

Title: Angela Allen’s Script Notes
Description: Reminiscences from John Huston’s regular script supervisor

Title: On the Restoration
Description: In this 2011 interview, Ivo Marák, technical director of Universal Production Partners studios, details the work involved in the extensive digital restoration of Marketa Lazarová.

Title: Gold Town Nickelodeon
Description: Art-house cinema is alive and well in the US’s most remote state capital! Join programmer Collette Costa for a tour of the Gold Town Nickelodeon and a selection of films that resonate with life on the frosty frontier.

Title: Vassilis Vassilikos on Z
Description: In this 1967 French television interview, author Vassilis Vassilikos discusses his book “Z.”

Title: Mo Rothman on THE KID
Description: The following audio excerpt is from an interview with distributor Mo Rothman, who partnered with Charlie Chaplin to rerelease his feature films, starting with THE KID in 1972. The interview was recorded by Chaplin biographer Jeffrey Vance in 1998.

Title: Daisy Granados on MEMORIES OF UNDERDEVELOPMENT
The Texas Theatre
Description: Criterion pays a visit to the Dallas theater where Lee Harvey Oswald was arrested, now catering to a diverse local community with imaginative programming and live events—including an original ballet inspired by LA JETÉE.

Title: Cinéastes de notre temps: François Truffaut ou l’esprit critique
Description: Directed by Jean-Pierre Chartier, “François Truffaut ou l’esprit critique” was an episode of the French television series “Cinéastes de notre temps.” In this excerpt from that episode, originally broadcast in 1965, Truffaut reflects on SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER.

Title: Jean Cocteau & Jean Marais
Description: The multifaceted artist, playwright, poet and filmmaker conjured up lyrical, surreal dream worlds with his dashing partner and muse.

Title: A DAY IN THE COUNTRY Screen Tests
Description: The following screen tests for A DAY IN THE COUNTRY were shot on June 25 and 26, 1936. They are presented here courtesy of the Cinémathèque Française.

Title: The Unluckiest Dragon
Description: This 2011 illustrated audio essay, featuring Greg Pflugfelder of Columbia University, details the tragedy that befell the fishing vessel “Daigo Fukuryu Maru” (Lucky Dragon No. 5), an event that inspired parts of the GODZILLA story.

Title: Christopher Munch on THE HOURS AND TIMES
Antonín Liehm on MARKETA LAZAROVÁ
Description: In the following interview, conducted in Paris in 2013, journalist and film critic Antonín Liehm discusses his friend and compatriot director František Vláčil.

Title: François Truffaut and Richard Roud
Description: This excerpt is from a conversation that aired on the New York arts program “Camera Three” in October 1977, when director François Truffaut was in the U.S. for the New York Film Festival screening of THE MAN WHO LOVED WOMEN. The conversation, with festival director Richard Roud, marked Truffaut’s first appearance on American television.

Title: Chris on Chris
Description: This short piece on director Chris Marker from 2007 was made by the London-based film critic Chris Darke, who has written on all aspects of moving-image culture.

Title: EQUINOX Cast Interview
Description: This interview features actors Frank Bonner (a.k.a. Frank Boers Jr.), Barbara Laughray (formely Hewitt), and James Duron (who played the Green Giant) discussing their roles in the two versions of EQUINOX and their reactions to the film today.

Title: Visualizing THE LAST METRO
Description: This 2009 video piece features camera assistants Florent Bazin and Tessa Racine talking about what it was like to work with legendary cinematographer Nestor Almendros and about the creation of THE LAST METRO’s striking period visuals.

Title: Roger Vadim & Brigitte Bardot
Description: She was a blonde bombshell; he was a charismatic lothario. Enjoy two of their collaborations in this charmer of a double bill.

Title: Raymond Queneau, 1959
Description: In this segment from the French television program “Lectures pour tous,” author Raymond Queneau discusses his book “Zazie dans le métro.” The piece was produced by Pierre Dumayet and originally broadcast on February 4, 1959.

Title: David Thomson
Description: In the following piece, recorded in 2014, film scholar David Thomson introduces PICNIC AT HANGING ROCK.

Title: “Cinéma cinémas”: Wim Wenders, 1987
Description: This excerpt is from “Wim Wenders Berlin Jan. 87,” an episode of the French television program “Cinéma cinémas.” It was directed by Claude Ventura and first broadcast February 17, 1987.

Title: Monica Vitti on RED DESERT
Description: In this interview from the French television series “Cinéma cinémas,” actress Monica Vitti discusses her relationship with Michelangelo Antonioni and her approach to acting. The interview was directed by Guy Girard and first broadcast on March 10, 1990.

Title: “Cinépanorama”: Alain Delon, 1962
Description: This interview with actor Alain Delon, conducted and directed by François Chalais, first aired on the French television program “Cinépanorama” on November 24, 1962. Delon discusses working with director René Clément, with whom he would make four films: PURPLE NOON (1960), THE JOY OF LIVING (1961), JOY HOUSE (1964), and IS PARIS BURNING? (1966).

Title: Stefania Sandrelli on I KNEW HER WELL
Description: In this interview, conducted in September 2015, Stefania Sandrelli talks about playing Adriana in I KNEW HER WELL and working with director Antonio Pietrangeli.

Title: I KNOW WHERE I’M GOING! Location Photo Essay
Description: In 1993, I KNOW WHERE I’M GOING! aficionado Nancy Franklin accompanied Mark Cousins to the Isle of Mull (in Scotland’s Inner Hebrides), to participate in his documentary about the film. In this video piece, she narrates her collection of photos taken on Mull and Colonsay, which includes many shots of the locations used in I KNOW WHERE I’M GOING!

Title: To Nathalie Sarraute
Description: This short excerpt from a January 7, 1986, interview on the France Culture radio show “La nuit sur un plateau,” hosted by Alain Veinstein, features director Agnès Varda and fiction writer Nathalie Sarraute, whose writings inspired VAGABOND and to whom Varda dedicated the film.

Title: Cléo’s Real Path Through Paris
Description: In this short film from 2005, Pierre-William Glenn, shooting from the back of a motorcycle, retraces the steps Cléo takes through Paris in CLÉO FROM 5 TO 7.

Title: Chaplin the Boxer: THE CHAMPION
Description: This excerpt from the short film THE CHAMPION, directed by Charlie Chaplin in 1915 for the Essanay Film Manufacturing Company, shows that some of the Tramp’s fancy footwork in CITY LIGHTS had a clear precedent.

Title: Henri Alekan on BEAUTY AND THE BEAST
Description: The following interview with director of photography Henri Alekan was conducted and shown on television in Luxembourg to coincide with the 1995 restoration of BEAUTY AND THE BEAST.

Title: On VERTIGO
Description: VERTIGO features prominently in director Chris Marker’s 1983 SANS SOLEIL, but Alfred Hitchcock’s film also exerts an influence on LA JETÉE, which Marker made twenty years earlier. This excerpt from the contemporary French television series “Court-circuit (le magazine)” explores Marker’s ongoing fascination with Hitchcock’s 1958 film.

Title: Offscreen Sound in LA CÉRÉMONIE
Description: Professor Jeff Smith demonstrates how Claude Chabrol manages to play his audience like a piano, evoking suspense, isolation, and class conflict through an expertly tuned soundtrack.

Title: The True Story of Maria Larsson
Description: The following 2010 documentary looks at photos by the real Maria Larsson and features narration by her distant relative Agneta Ulfsäter-Troell, who tells the story of Larsson’s life and work as an amateur photographer.

Title: Joao Benard da Costa on OSSOS
Description: Joao Benard da Costa (1935–2009) was the head of the Portuguese Cinematheque in Lisbon from 1991 to 2009 and Pedro Costa's loyal friend and supporter. The following comments about OSSOS were recorded in 2004.

Title: A Subjective Assault: Lodge Kerrigan’s CLEAN, SHAVEN
Description: This video essay, written and narrated by Michael Atkinson, explores Lodge Kerrigan’s use of imagery and sound design to convey the unique subjectivity of CLEAN, SHAVEN.

Title: Stan Lee on Alain Resnais
Description: The Spiderman creator recounts his friendship with the director of HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR.

Title: Existential Zombies: Antonioni’s L’ECLISSE
Description: Editor Chris Innis and filmmaking duo Aaron Moorhead and Justin Benson examine the way Michelangelo Antonioni sets the scene for his 1962 classic.

Title: Making Space
Description: Presented here are 2007 interviews with FIRST MAN INTO SPACE director Robert Day and actor Marla Landi.

Title: Coda
Description: Directed by Alan Holly • 2013 • Ireland /  /  /  / A lost soul stumbles drunkenly through the city at night. In a park, Death finds him and shows him many things. This multi-award-winning animated short film begins as a chilling cautionary tale but ends on a heartwarming note.

Title: Enzo Siciliano on MAMMA ROMA
Description: This interview with Enzo Siciliano, author of “Pasolini” (1982), was conducted in 2004.

Title: For the First Time
Description: In 1967, Cuban documentary filmmaker Octavio Cortazar followed a projectionist whose mission was to show moving pictures to rural communities for the first time. Cortazar’s short film, presented here, documents one audience’s response to its first film: Chaplin’s MODERN TIMES.

Title: The Gold Rush - Trailer
Description: Directed by Charles Chaplin • 1942 • United States /  / Charlie Chaplin's comedic masterwork--which charts a prospector's search for fortune in the Klondike and his discovery of romance (with the beautiful Georgia Hale)--forever cemented the iconic status of Chaplin and his Little Tramp character. Shot partly on location in the Sierra Nevadas and featuring such timeless gags as the dance of the dinner rolls and the meal of boiled shoe leather, The Gold Rush is an indelible work of heartwarming hilarity. This special edition features both Chaplin's definitive 1942 version, for which the director added new music and narration, and a new restoration of the original 1925 silent film.

Title: Irm Hermann on THE MERCHANT OF FOUR SEASONS
Description: This interview with actor Irm Hermann was conducted in Berlin in February 2015.

Title: Masaki Kobayashi on HARAKIRI
Description: Filmed for the Directors Guild of Japan on October 14, 1993, at the Haiyuza Theatre in Tokyo, this rare interview with Masaki Kobayashi features the director reflecting on HARAKIRI and his collaborators. It was conducted by filmmaker Masahiro Shinoda.

Title: Photographic Effects
Description: This featurette, introduced by effects director Koichi Kawakita and effects photographer Motoyoshi Tomioka, reveals the visual tricks behind certain sequences in GODZILLA.

Title: Against the Grain
Description: This excerpt from the 2007 documentary AGAINST THE GRAIN: THE FILM LEGEND OF BERNHARD WICKI, a film about the director by his widow, Elisabeth Wicki-Endriss, covers THE BRIDGE and features behind-the-scenes footage from the shoot.

Title: F for Fake - Trailer
Description: Directed by Orson Welles • 1975 • France, Iran, Germany /  /  /  / Trickery. Deceit. Magic. In F for Fake, a free-form sort-of documentary by Orson Welles, the legendary filmmaker (and self-described charlatan) gleefully reengages with the central preoccupation of his career: the tenuous lines between illusion and truth, art and lies. Beginning with portraits of the world-renowned art forger Elmyr de Hory and his equally devious biographer, Clifford Irving, Welles embarks on a dizzying journey that simultaneously exposes and revels in fakery and fakers of all stripes, not the least of whom is Welles himself. Charming and inventive, F for Fake is an inspired prank and a clever examination of the essential duplicity of cinema.

Title: “Cinéastes de notre temps”: JULES AND JIM
Description: In 1965, the French television series “Cinéastes de notre temps” aired an episode entitled “François Truffaut, ou L’esprit critique.” In the excerpt presented here, Truffaut discusses JULES AND JIM.

Title: DHEEPAN: Deleted Scenes with Commentary
Description: The following deleted scenes from DHEEPAN feature French-language commentary by director Jacques Audiard and coscreenwriter Noé Debré.

Title: The Vampire
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1945 • France /  / Jean Painlevé's short THE VAMPIRE draws the connection between the movie monsters of the same name and the South American vampire bat. The animal's gruesome feeding habits are on full display.

Title: Max Douy on THE RULES OF THE GAME
Description: Max Douy’s career as a production designer spanned fifty years and over 150 films, including collaborations with directors Claude Autant-Lara, Jules Dassin, and Jean Renoir. He served as assistant to Eugène Lourié on THE RULES OF THE GAME. In June 2003, he gave Criterion this interview at the famed Moulin Rouge in Paris.

Title: Margot Kidder on “The Dick Cavett Show,” 1973
Description: The following program features an appearance by actor Margot Kidder on “The Dick Cavett Show” in 1973.

Title: Slavoj Žižek on Y TU MAMÁ TAMBIÉN
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2014, philosopher Slavoj Žižek explores director Alfonso Cuarón’s subtle manipulation of foreground and background in Y TU MAMÁ TAMBIÉN, to comment on the film’s political and social context.

Title: MY WINNIPEG Live in Toronto
Description: This featurette documents a 2008 screening of MY WINNIPEG at the Royal Cinema in Toronto, for which director Guy Maddin provided live narration.

Title: Frazer Pennebaker on THE WAR ROOM
Description: In this interview, shot in 2011, THE WAR ROOM producer Frazer Pennebaker discusses the process of gaining access to, and then filming, a presidential campaign.

Title: Pierce Brosnan on MISTER JOHNSON
Description: Actor Pierce Brosnan recalls the making of MISTER JOHNSON in the following interview, recorded in 2015.

Title: Sea Devil
Description: Directed by Dean C. Marcial and Brett Potter • 2014 • United States /  / An American fisherman attempts to smuggle two Cuban immigrants into Miami, passing them off as day laborers. While the group trawls for shrimp, a fourth person boards the boat, carrying a secret at the bottom of the Ocean.

Title: Tonino Delli Colli on MAMMA ROMA
Description: Tonino Delli Colli worked as director of photography on eleven of Pier Paolo Pasolini’s fourteen films, beginning with ACCATTONE and concluding with the director’s final film, SALO (1975). This interview with him was recorded in 2004.

Title: Réponse de femmes
Description: This 1975 short film by Agnès Varda was commissioned by the French television channel Antenne 2, which asked seven female filmmakers each to make a film in response to the question "What is a woman?"

Title: René Clair on LE MILLION
Description: Jim MacAndrew’s interview with director René Clair was televised live in November 1959. With the cooperation of the New York State Education Department, the program aired on only a small number of stations. A 16 mm kinescope copy was made directly from the broadcast feed.

Title: Lira's Forest
Description: Directed by Connor Jessup • 2017 • Canada /  / As the end of her life approaches, an old woman encounters a strange spirit from a nearby forest.

Title: Interview with the Filmmakers
Description: This 1993 interview features filmmakers Rémy Belvaux, André Bonzel, and Benoit Poelvoorde speaking about their collaborative efforts, the creation of MAN BITES DOG, and the controversy upon its worldwide release.

Title: Walter Reade Theater
Description: The Walter Reade Theater at the Film Society of Lincoln Center is a beloved New York institution. We’ve created a short documentary on its history and programming, presented here with a lineup of films handpicked and introduced by its curators.

Title: Rocky VI
Description: Directed by Aki Kaurismäki • 1986 • Finland /  /  /  / The music video for 'Rocky VI' by the Leningrad Cowboys.

Title: Secrets professionnels: Tête-à-tête
Description: The following excerpts are from the March 12, 1964, episode of the French television show “Secrets professionnels: Tête-à-tête,” which focused on Hagop Arakelian, makeup artist on BEAUTY AND THE BEAST.

Title: “Cinéastes de notre temps”: Agnès Varda, 1964
Description: In this excerpt from “La nouvelle vague par elle-même,” an episode of the French television series “Cinéastes de notre temps,” director Agnès Varda discusses her early career in film. The episode originally aired May 19, 1964.

Title: Helene Falconetti on THE PASSION OF JOAN OF ARC
Description: Richard Einhorn conducted this audio interview with Helene Falconetti, the daughter of star Renee Falconetti, in 1995. She is the author of Falconetti, a biography of her mother.

Title: The Platform
Description: The following scene from THE TIN DRUM, in which Oskar disrupts a Nazi rally with his drumming, is accompanied by an audio recording of author Günter Grass reading the corresponding passage from his novel. Grass reads from the original German text, with musical accompaniment.

Title: The Above
Description: Directed by Kirsten Johnson • 2015 • United States /  / This 2015 short film by Kirsten Johnson was commissioned by Field of Vision, a filmmaker-driven visual journalism unit that pairs directors with developing stories around the globe. In THE ABOVE, a U.S. military surveillance balloon floats on a tether high about Kabul, Afghanistan. Its capacities are highly classified and deeply mysterious.

Title: “Le journal du cinéma”: CLAIRE’S KNEE
Description: The following episode of the French television program “Le journal du cinéma” features interviews with actors Jean-Claude Brialy, Béatrice Romand, and Laurence de Monaghan. It originally aired on December 13, 1970.

Title: The Battle for I AM CURIOUS—YELLOW
Description: Renowned film historian and author Peter Cowie narrates this survey of the history of the U.S. release of I AM CURIOUS—YELLOW, from Grove Press’ Barney Rosset and his initial attempt to import the film from Sweden, to the historic court battles that ensued, forever altering the landscape of American cinema.

Title: Rosario Tronnolone Interview
Description: The deleted scene presented here features an interview with Rosario Tronnolone, a film historian and the owner of the world’s largest private collection of materials on Ingrid Bergman.

Title: An Exercise in Discipline: Peel
Description: Directed by Jane Campion • 1982 • Australia /  / This short, concerning a father disciplining his son whilst on a road trip, went on to win the Short Film Palme d'or at the 1986 Cannes Film Festival and effectively launched director Jane Campion's feature-filmmaking career.

Title: Split Screen: Big Miss Moviola
Description: Female filmmakers send their movies to Miranda July and Big Miss Moviola. From Season 7, Episode 3.

Title: Everything Is Beautiful: Please, Have a Seat
Description: This final semgemtn in a three-part program from 2005, produced by Les Films de Mon Oncle, focuses on the furniture design of MON ONCLE.

Title: Bertrand Tavernier
Description: French filmmaker Bertrand Tavernier has long championed the films of Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger, and he was close to Powell for many years. This introduction to BLACK NARCISSUS was recorded for the Institut Lumière in 2006.

Title: “Cinépanorama”: Simone Signoret, 1963
Description: This interview with CASQUE D’OR star Simone Signoret was conducted in April 1963 for the television series “Cinépanorama.”

Title: Soldiers’ Journals: Sergeant Edward Robert McCosh
Description: While writing the script for OVERLORD, director Stuart Cooper and cowriter Christopher Hudson read the journals of two D-day soldiers, Sergeant Edward Robert McCosh and Sergeant Finlay Campbell. Moved by these soldiers’ experiences, they incorporated some of their recollections into the protagonist’s story. Here, Brian Stirner, who plays Tom in Overlord, reads excerpts from their journals. Edward Robert McCosh was called up in Motherwell, Scotland, in September 1943, four months before his nineteenth birthday, and early in 1944, he was transferred to the 74th Field Company RE. By the time his unit crossed to France, the Normandy beachhead had been secured, and their landing was unopposed, though McCosh noted with distaste, “They had even brought special manufactured crosses with them on the invasion.”

Title: Anatomy of a Gag: Monkeyshoes
Description: The following short program, created in 2018 by critic and filmmaker David Cairns, examines Harold Lloyd's unique approach to gags in silent comedy and THE KID BROTHER respectively.

Title: Morgan Neville on F FOR FAKE
Description: The documentary filmmaker on Orson Welles’s magic trick of an essay film

Title: Monsieur Verdoux - Trailer
Description: Directed by Charles Chaplin • 1947 • United States /  / Charlie Chaplin plays shockingly against type in his most controversial film, a brilliant and bleak black comedy about money, marriage, and murder. Chaplin is a twentieth-century bluebeard, an enigmatic family man who goes to extreme lengths to support his wife and child, attempting to bump off a series of wealthy widows (including one played by the indefatigable Martha Raye, in a hilarious performance). This deeply philosophical and wildly entertaining film is a work of true sophistication, both for the moral questions it dares to ask and for the way it deconstructs its megastar's lovable on-screen persona.

Title: Denis Lenoir Commentary on CARLOS
Description: The following is a selected-scene commentary featuring CARLOS cinematographer Denis Lenoir.

Title: Northwest Film Forum
Description: Art-House America heads to Seattle, where Northwest Film Forum’s executive director Courtney Sheehan introduces us to the theater’s community-focused approach to film culture.

Title: Pussy
Description: Directed by Renata Gąsiorowska • 2016 • Poland /  / A young girl spends the evening alone at home. She decides to have some sweet solo pleasure session, but not everything goes according to plan.

Title: Callisto Cosulich on THE CHILDREN ARE WATCHING US
Description: This interview with Vittorio De Sica scholar Callisto Cosulich was conducted in 2005.

Title: Jean-Louis Trintignant on IL SORPASSO
Description: In 1983, Jean-Louis Trintignant sat down with his fellow actor Marie-Christine Barrault to introduce IL SORPASSO for an airing of the film on the French television program “Ciné passion.” In their conversation, presented here, he talks about being cast in the role of Roberto after shooting had already started and the filming of the final scene.

Title: Kieślowski’s Cinema Lesson: RED
Description: In this piece from 1994, director Krzysztof Kieślowski discusses the final editing of the scene from RED where Rita, the dog, runs away, which he refers to as “the first critical moment in the film.”

Title: Monkey Love Experiments
Description: Directed by Ainslie Henderson and Will Anderson • 2014 • United Kingdom /  / Inspired by love, a misguided monkey believes he is destined for the moon.

Title: Gabriel Axel on BABETTE’S FEAST
Description: Director Gabriel Axel began his career working for Danish television in the early 1950s. He struggled for fifteen years to bring to the screen Isak Dinesen’s short story “Babette’s Feast,” considered unfilmable. This interview was conducted at the Karen Blixen Museum in Rungsted, Denmark, in May 2013.

Title: THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK: Bob Ross Interview
Description: During preproduction on THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK, director Robert Epstein recorded draft interviews with more than forty people before deciding on the eight subjects seen in the film. Presented here are excerpts from an interview with activist and publisher Bob Ross, which was not included in the film.

Title: Les Blank on A POEM IS A NAKED PERSON
Description: In February 2013, shortly before filmmaker Les Blank’s death, a screening of A POEM IS A NAKED PERSON took place at Pixar Animation Studios in Northern California, with Blank in attendance. Presented here are excerpts from his discussion with the audience of family and friends.

Title: Ahmad Kiarostami
Description: In this interview shot in 2018, director Abbas Kiarostami’s son Ahmad talks about his father’s last film, 24 Frames.

Title: Making LIGHTNIN’
Description: This short piece, produced in 2014, features an interview with Skip Gerson, director Les Blank’s collaborator on THE BLUES ACCORDIN’ TO LIGHTNIN’ HOPKINS.

Title: Edith Scob on EYES WITHOUT A FACE
Description: In this 2013 interview, actor Edith Scob discusses the making of EYES WITHOUT A FACE and her iconic character, Christiane Génessier.

Title: On Musashi Miyamoto, Part 1
Description: The character Musashi Miyamoto was inspired by the historical figure of the same name. In this interview, conducted in 2012, translator and historian William Scott Wilson (“The Lone Samurai”) discusses the real-life events corresponding to the time frame of SAMURAI I: MUSASHI MIYAMOTO.

Title: 1939 Short Version Ending
Description: Watch the ending of director Jean Renoir’s 1939 81-minute version of THE RULES OF THE GAME in its entirety.

Title: 30 millions d’amis: Le Hasard de Jacques Tati
Description: In this 1977 episode of the French television show “30 millions d’amis,” director Jacques Tati introduces his dog, Hasard, and talks about the canine stars of MON ONCLE.

Title: Chris New’s WEEKEND Footage
Description: During the filming of WEEKEND, actor Chris New brought a video camera to the set. The following selection of footage was shot by New and others who happened to pick up the camera.

Title: CITY LIGHTS: The Tramp Meets the Flower Girl
Description: The following eight minutes of footage were captured by Charlie Chaplin’s friend Ralph Barton. We see the director orchestrate a scene that reveals the flower girl’s blindness and establishes her belief that the Tramp is a wealthy man. It is presented here with audio commentary by Chaplin historian Hooman Mehran.

Title: Liliana Cavani on THE NIGHT PORTER
Description: In this interview, conducted by the Criterion Collection in Rome in 2014, director Liliana Cavani muses on various aspects of the making of THE NIGHT PORTER.

Title: Q&A Session at an Associated Press Convention
Description: The following was broadcast live on November 17, 1973, from Orlando, Florida.

Title: Albert Maysles on THE BEALES OF GREY GARDENS
Outtakes: The Who, “A Quick One While He’s Away”
Donald McAlpine on BREAKER MORANT
Description: In this 2015 interview with Donald McAlpine, the celebrated cinematographer recalls his pivotal early work in BREAKER MORANT.

Title: Deleted Scene
Description: This scene featuring a town meeting was not included in the final cut of GEORGE WASHINGTON. It is presented here with commentary by director David Gordon Green, cinematographer Tim Orr, and actor Paul Schneider.

Title: Joachim Trier on DON’T LOOK NOW
One Hundred a Day
Description: In this short film set in the 1930s, a young woman faces a long day at work at a factory, after having a secret abortion. Gillian Armstrong directed ONE HUNDRED A DAY in 1973, during her last year as a student at the Australian Film, Television and Radio School.

Title: Little Bob in Concert
Description: This performance footage of the singer Little Bob, who gives the benefit concert in LE HAVRE, features the songs “Libero” and “Sheila ’n’ Willey” and was recorded in Le Havre in May 2010.

Title: Polka Happiness
Description: This 2014 piece features an interview with Chris Simon, who collaborated with director Les Blank on numerous films.

Title: The Olympic Games as They Were Practiced in Ancient Greece
Description: Directed by Jean de Rovera • 1924 • France /  / A short tribute to the origins of the Olympic Games shot in 1924. This film is a brief series of tableaux, with athletes posing against a dark stage background and performing the ritual movements of the traditional sports and events.

Title: Orson Welles: On the Nose
Description: Learn how a master storyteller shaped his characters from their noses down.

Title: Benjamin Christensen on HÄXAN
Description: In 1941, HÄXAN director Benjamin Christensen filmed this short introduction for the rerelease of his film.

Title: Ingmar Bergman on PERSONA
Description: In the following excerpt, taken from an interview recorded for Canadian television in 1970, director Ingmar Bergman recalls a stay in the hospital when the idea for PERSONA came to him.

Title: Production History: Chris Faulkner
Description: Historian Chris Faulkner narrates this 2003 video essay on THE RULES OF THE GAME’s inception, production, original release, and 1959 reconstruction.

Title: Luciano De Ambrosis on THE CHILDREN ARE WATCHING US
Description: This interview with THE CHILDREN ARE WATCHING US star Luciano De Ambrosis was conducted in 2005.

Title: WEEKEND: On Location
Description: In October 1967, while Jean-Luc Godard was filming WEEKEND, director Philippe Garrel filmed him, along with his cast and crew. That footage was edited into this 1967 episode of the documentary television series “Seize millions de jeunes” about Godard and his emulators. It includes comments about Godard by filmmaker Jean-Michel Barjol.

Title: Flaherty and Film
Description: Excerpts from the television documentary FLAHERTY AND FILM, featuring interviews with filmmaker Robert Flaherty’s widow and NANOOK OF THE NORTH coeditor Frances Flaherty

Title: CREATIVE NONFICTION: Introduction
Description: CREATIVE NONFICTION is director Lena Dunham’s first feature, made in 2009, during her junior and senior years at Oberlin College. Presented here is an introduction to the film by Dunham.

Title: The Making of ANTICHRIST: Makeup Effects and Props
Description: Made in 2010 by Zentropa’s DVD production company, Electric Parc.

Title: Ophuls’s Collaborators: Marc Frédérix
Description: This interview with production designer Marc Frédérix, who was assistant decorator on THE EARRINGS OF MADAME DE . . ., was conducted by Martina Müller in Paris in 1989.

Title: Emmanuel Machuel on OSSOS
Description: Prior to photographing Pedro Costa's OSSOS and CASA DE LAVA (1994), acclaimed cinematographer Emmanuel Machuel collaborated with a number of extraordinary directors, shooting L’ARGENT for Robert Bresson and VAN GOGH for Maurice Pialat. This interview was conducted at Machuel's house by Aurelien Gerbault in 2004.

Title: Opening Shot of THE PLAYER with Commentary
Description: The celebrated opening shot of THE PLAYER runs more than eight minutes without a cut, traveling around the film’s Hollywood studio location. The sequence is presented here with commentary by director Robert Altman.

Title: M.I.A.’s Closet Picks
Description: The cosmopolitan pop star raids our closet.

Title: Opening Shot of THE PLAYER with Commentary 2
Description: The celebrated opening shot of THE PLAYER runs more than eight minutes without a cut, traveling around the film’s Hollywood studio location. The sequence is presented here with commentary by writer Michael Tolkin and cinematographer Jean Lépine.

Title: Outtakes: The Paul Butterfield Blues Band 2
George Lucas on Akira Kurosawa
Description: In this 2001 interview, filmmaker George Lucas pays tribute to the visual mastery of director Akira Kurosawa and details the elements of THE HIDDEN FORTRESS that directly inspired STAR WARS.

Title: Neighbours
Description: Directed by Norman McLaren • 1952 • Canada /  / In this Oscar-winning short film, Norman McLaren employs the principles normally used to put drawings or puppets into motion to animate live actors. The story is a parable about two people who come to blows over the possession of a flower.

Title: My Josephine
Description: Directed by Barry Jenkins • 2003 • United States /  / Few people know that Napoleon Bonaparte had two wives. He married Marie Louise for an heir, but he married Josephine, his first wife, for love. Aadid works in the laundromat with Adela. Adela is a woman who is very good. She's simple. She's not complicated. She's not someone who makes up schemes. She's very gracious. Lovely. She is Aidid's Josephine.

Title: The Making of ANTICHRIST: The Three Beggars
Description: Made in 2010 by Zentropa’s DVD production company, Electric Parc.

Title: Willem Dafoe at Cannes
Description: This video interview with Willem Dafoe at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival

Title: Marilyn Nash on MONSIEUR VERDOUX
Description: In 1997, Marilyn Nash, who made her screen debut in the role of the girl in MONSIEUR VERDOUX, was interviewed by Charlie Chaplin biographer Jeffrey Vance about her life and her experiences working with Chaplin. Presented here are audio excerpts from that interview, illustrated with photographs and clips from the film.

Title: Bernardo Britto on YEARBOOK
Description: The director of YEARBOOK introduces his film.

Title: The Soundtrack
Description: In this 2012 interview, critic Tony Rayns looks at the unique musical collage of IN THE MOOD FOR LOVE’s soundtrack.

Title: Ingmar’s Actors: Bibi and Liv
Description: Critic Sheila O’Malley pays tribute to two of Ingmar Bergman’s most magnetic collaborators.

Title: Joe Shishido on YOUTH OF THE BEAST
Description: This video interview with actor Joe Shishido was made by Nikkatsu in Japan in 2001.

Title: Capa Influences Cooper
Description: Legendary photographer Robert Capa shot 106 images on Omaha Beach on D-day, only a handful of which survive. These blurry photos have a surreal quality that succinctly conveys the chaos and confusion of the day. In this 2007 photo essay, which includes most of the famous images, director Stuart Cooper discusses Capa’s work’s influence on him.

Title: Behind-the-Scenes Stills
Description: Compiled from the personal collection of director Michael Powell and narrated by his widow, editor Thelma Schoonmaker Powell, these rare behind-the-scenes production photos show the cast and crew on the Scottish locations for I KNOW WHERE I’M GOING!

Title: Rollie Totheroh on THE KID
Description: This audio excerpt is from a 1964 interview with Charlie Chaplin’s loyal cinematographer Roland “Rollie” Totheroh. In it, he recalls that the editing of THE KID was completed outside of California because of concerns that Chaplin’s then wife, Mildred Harris, would draw it into her divorce case against him.

Title: Begone Dull Care
Description: Directed by Norman McLaren and Evelyn Lambart • 1949 • Canada /  / In this extraordinary short animation, Evelyn Lambart and Norman McLaren painted colours, shapes, and transformations directly on to their filmstrip. The result is a vivid interpretation, in fluid lines and color, of jazz music played by the Oscar Peterson Trio.

Title: “20 heures”: Abdellatif Kechiche
Description: This excerpt from an episode of the television series “20 heures” features interviews with director Abdellatif Kechiche, actress Hafsia Herzi, and residents of Sete, the location for THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN, as they celebrate the film’s awards at the 2008 Cesars. Directed by Vincent Vedel and Daniela Suteu, the episode aired on February 23, 2008.

Title: Scoring TOM JONES
Description: In this illustrated archival audio interview, composer John Addison describes working with director Tony Richardson and creating the Oscar-winning score for TOM JONES.

Title: John Pierson introduces SPLIT SCREEN Season Three
Ingmar Bergman on AUTUMN SONATA
Description: In this excerpt from a summer 2003 interview conducted by Marie Nyreröd for SVT Svensk Television, director Ingmar Bergman talks about AUTUMN SONATA.

Title: Hanif Kureishi on MY BEAUTIFUL LAUNDRETTE
Description: The acclaimed British-Pakistani novelist and playwright discusses the autobiographical, historical and political underpinnings of his first screenplay, MY BEAUTIFUL LAUNDRETTE.

Title: Paolo and Vittorio Taviani on Roberto Rossellini
Description: Italian directors Paolo and Vittorio Taviani (THE NIGHT OF THE SHOOTING STARS) saw PAISAN when they were adolescents and credit the film with inspiring them to become filmmakers. Years later, in 1977, Roberto Rossellini was president of the Cannes jury that awarded their PADRE PADRONE the Palme d'Or. In this interview recorded in 2009, they speak of the profound influence Rossellini's films have had on them.

Title: Ana Torrent on CRÍA CUERVOS . . .
Description: The following interview with actor Ana Torrent was recorded in 2007.

Title: Charlie the Barber
Description: Charlie Chaplin and his half-brother, Sydney, liked to film scenes set in barbershops, as evidenced in Sydney’s 1921 KING, QUEEN, JOKER and in this scene, shot for Charlie’s 1919 SUNNYSIDE but never used.

Title: OVERLORD Commentary Excerpt
Description: The following is an excerpt from the commentary track for OVERLORD, which features director Stuart Cooper and actor Brian Stirner, and was recorded in 2006 in Los Angeles and London.

Title: Catherine Demongeot on ZAZIE DANS LE MÉTRO
Description: This segment from the March 4, 1960, episode of the French television program “Cinq colonnes à la une” features journalists Jean-Noël Roy and Pierre Dumayet interviewing ZAZIE DANS LE MÉTRO’s young star, Catherine Demongeot, and her parents.

Title: HARLAN COUNTY USA Outtakes: Jerry and Bessie
Description: Producer-director Barbara Kopple and her crew shot hundreds of hours of film for HARLAN COUNTY USA. Presented here is one outtake, edited slightly for length, from the HARLAN COUNTY USA archives at the University of Kentucky, Lexington.

Title: Benicio Del Toro on THE NAKED ISLAND
Description: This interview with actor Benicio Del Toro, a longtime advocate of the work of director Kaneto Shindo, was conducted in Los Angeles in February 2016.

Title: Kent Jones Video Essay
Description: This program, written by filmmaker and critic Kent Jones and produced by the Criterion Collection in 2013, explores the conception, production, and preservation of Fred Zinnemann and Emilio Gómez Muriel’s REDES.

Title: The Making of ANTICHRIST: The Evil of Woman
Description: Made in 2010 by Zentropa’s DVD production company, Electric Parc.

Title: Kaneto Shindo
Description: The following is excerpted from a video director Kaneto Shindo recorded as a greeting for “The Urge for Survival,” a 2011 retrospective of his work at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Title: Krzysztof Kieślowski on BLUE
Description: In this piece from 1994, director Krzysztof Kieślowski discusses a scene from BLUE, and specifically his idea behind a close-up shot of a sugar cube.

Title: Paul Schrader on Lena Dunham
Description: The following interview with writer, director, and critic Paul Schrader was conducted in September 2011.

Title: On the Set
Description: This silent footage shot on the set of CASQUE D’OR provides a rare glimpse of director Jacques Becker at work. It was broadcast in 1951 as part of the program “Silence on tourne: CASQUE D’OR.” Film critic Philip Kemp recorded commentary for the footage in 2004.

Title: THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK Castro Premiere
Description: THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK had its San Francisco premiere on November 1, 1984, at the Castro Theatre, where it was introduced by writer Vito Russo. Excerpts from that event are presented here.

Title: The Lamp
Description: Directed by Roman Polanski • 1959 • Poland /  / THE LAMP was made in Roman Polanski's final year at the State Film School in Lodz. Polanski has said there is a connection between all his short films, 'because in them I had certain ideals which I wished to express. It's really a question of a certain style that appeals to me more than a theme. I like the theater of the absurd. I also like surrealism. Often I have used a form close to surrealism in order to express a certain idea or thought.'

Title: Cinéma
Description: The following excerpts are from French television interviews that aired when 2 OR 3 THINGS I KNOW ABOUT HER was in production. This excerpt is from an on-set interview with actress Marina Vlady that was featured on the program “Cinéma,” directed by Max Allemand, on October 26, 1966.

Title: Alan Bean on FOR ALL MANKIND
Description: Apollo 12 astronaut Alan Bean was the fourth man to walk on the moon, and he later commanded the Skylab 3 mission, staying a then record fifty-nine days in space. After retiring from NASA, he turned full-time to his other passion, painting. Presented here is a video introduction with Bean.

Title: Cinéma: Travelling
Description: This 1967 installment of the cine-magazine series “Cinéma”’s “Travelling” segment, directed by Frederic Rossif, features on-set interviews with director Robert Bresson and MOUCHETTE cast members Nadine Nortier and Jean-Claude Guilbert, as well as behind-the-scenes footage of Bresson rehearsing with the actors.

Title: Split Screen: “Selective Service System” Story
Description: An intense look at one man’s way out of the Vietnam War draft. From Season 4, Episode 4.

Title: Outtake
Description: This seven-minute outtake from THE BLUE ACCORDIN’ TO LIGHTNIN’ HOPKINS features the bluesman singing the classic song “Mr. Charlie, Your Rollin’ Mill is Burnin’ Down.

Title: Dennis Muren on EQUINOX
Description: In this interview, director Dennis Muren recalls his childhood fascination with effects photography, his amateur filmmaking experiences, and the collaborations and technical achievements that have led to his status as one of cinema’s foremost visual effects artists.

Title: Marceline Loridan, 1961
Description: In the following interview, conducted by François Chalais and originally broadcast on the May 7, 1961, episode of the television program “Reflets de Cannes,” Marceline Loridan, one of CHRONICLE OF A SUMMER’s main subjects, discusses her deportation to Auschwitz and the role that past played in the film.

Title: François Truffaut on Henri-Pierre Roché
Description: In this excerpt from the October 12, 1966, French program “Bibliothèque de poche,” director François Truffaut offers his reflections on Henri-Pierre Roché, author of the novel “Jules and Jim.”

Title: CITY LIGHTS: Stick Stuck in the Grate
Description: The following seven-minute outtake shows a comic routine originally intended to follow the statue unveiling at the start of CITY LIGHTS.

Title: Ron Perlman on CRONOS
Description: In this 2009 interview, actor Ron Perlman reminisces about CRONOS and his work with director Guillermo del Toro.

Title: Harvey Milk Candlelight Memorial
Description: Every year since Harvey Milk’s and Mayor George Moscone’s assassinations, people have joined together on November 27 to honor them. On the twenty-fifth anniversary, in 2003, former teacher and longtime San Francisco supervisor Tom Ammiano and the late mayor’s daughter Rebecca, both featured here, shared their thoughts with the crowd.

Title: John Bailey on Kazuo Miyagawa
Description: Cinematographer John Bailey explores the art of Japan’s most famous cameraman, director of photography for Kurosawa, Ichikawa, Mizoguchi and more.

Title: Chaos Reigns at the Cannes Film Festival
Description: This supplement focuses on the world premiere of ANTICHRIST at the Cannes Film Festival in May 2009, including its reception by the press, critics, and the festival jury.

Title: From the 1921 Version
Description: THE KID was initially released in 1921, as part of Charlie Chaplin’s eight-picture deal with First National Exhibitors Circuit. When Chaplin revisited the film in 1971, he removed three scenes featuring “the Woman,” played by Edna Purviance. Those scenes are presented here, within the context of the film.

Title: “Cinéma:” BELLE DE JOUR
Description: This segment from the December 23, 1966, episode of “Cinéma” features interviews with screenwriter Jean-Claude Carrière and actor Catherine Deneuve on the set of BELLE DE JOUR.

Title: Woody Allen on Ingmar Bergman
Description: It’s no secret that the work of Ingmar Bergman has had a profound influence on Woody Allen’s career. In this short 1998 piece for Turner Classic Movies, Allen talks about his passion for the director.

Title: FANNY AND ALEXANDER Set Models
Description: Anna Asp won an Academy Award, with set decorator Susanne Lingheim, for the art direction of FANNY AND ALEXANDER. Presented here is footage of some of Asp’s set models.

Title: Night of Anubis: Russell Streiner Introduction
Description: The following introduction by NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD coproducer Russell Streiner to an uncorrected 16 mm work print of the film was recorded in 2017.

Title: Quinnford + Scout on WEEKEND
Description: Director Andrew Haigh hired the Irish team of Quinnford + Scout—a.k.a. Colin Quinn and Oisin Share—as the set photographers for WEEKEND after finding inspiration for the look of his film in the lighting and framing of their photography. In this 2012 video essay, Quinn and Share discuss their work and their experiences on the film’s set.

Title: Closing the Doinel Cycle
Description: In the following interview, excerpted from a 1980 episode of the television show “Cinescope” (directed by Thierry Michel), director François Truffaut tells host René Michelems his misgivings about LOVE ON THE RUN, the finale to the Doinel series, and his feelings about Jean-Pierre Léaud and Antoine Doinel.

Title: A WELL SPENT LIFE: Meeting Mance
Description: Chris Strachwitz, a friend and collaborator of director Les Blank’s, founded Arhoolie Records in 1960, and Mance Lipscomb’s “Texas Sharecropper and Songster” was the label's first release. In this interview, conducted in July 2014, Strachwitz tells the story of meeting the famous blues musician who became one of Blank’s subjects.

Title: Forrest J. Ackerman on EQUINOX
Description: Legendary writer, editor (of “Famous Monsters of Filmland” magazine), and science-fiction historian Forrest J Ackerman discusses the two versions of EQUINOX, their impact on genre filmdom, and their legacy.

Title: Gregory Manchess Studio Visit
Description: Meet the gifted oil painter and award-winning illustrator behind many Criterion Collection covers, including A NIGHT TO REMEMBER, KING OF THE HILL, 3:10 TO YUMA, and JUBAL.

Title: Soumitra Chatterjee on PATHER PANCHALI
Description: Actor Soumitra Chatterjee’s first film role was as the adult Apu in 1959’s APUR SANSAR, and he went on to appear in thirteen more of Satyajit Ray’s films. In this 2013 interview, Chatterjee recalls the impact that PATHER PANCHALI had on him and his fellow Bengalis.

Title: Ermanno Olmi on THE TREE OF WOODEN CLOGS in 2008
Description: In this interview, conducted in 2008 by film critic Lorenzo Codelli, director Ermanno Olmi discusses THE TREE OF WOODEN CLOGS and how it captures a peasant way of life that he was among the last to witness.

Title: Les grands-pères du crime
Description: Pierre Boileau and Thomas Narcejac’s novels provided the basis for such cinema classics as Henri-Georges Clouzot’s DIABOLIQUE and Alfred Hitchcock’s VERTIGO, and the authors cowrote the screenplay for EYES WITHOUT A FACE. In these excerpts from the 1985 documentary LES GRANDS-PÈRES DU CRIME, the two discuss their longtime creative partnership.

Title: John Ford Home Movies
Description: In this 2010 video interview, John Ford’s grandson and biographer Dan Ford (“Pappy: The Life of John Ford”) discusses the director’s personal home movies and what they reveal about the man and his special relationships with Hollywood luminaries like John Wayne and cinematographer Gregg Toland.

Title: On Musashi Miyamoto, Part 2
Description: The character Musashi Miyamoto was inspired by the historical figure of the same name. In this interview, conducted in 2012, translator and historian William Scott Wilson (“The Lone Samurai”) discusses the real-life events corresponding to the time frame of SAMURAI II: DUEL AT ICHIJOJI TEMPLE.

Title: Ingrid Bergman’s Home Movies
Description: Director Stig Björkman drew from these six minutes of 8 mm footage, shot by Ingrid Bergman in the 1930s and given to the filmmaker by Bergman’s daughter Pia Lindström, for INGRID BERGMAN: IN HER OWN WORDS

Title: John Pierson introduces SPLIT SCREEN Season Four
Staging in THE RULES OF THE GAME
Description: Jean Renoir’s THE RULES OF THE GAME is famed for its deep-focus photography and intricate staging. Professor Kristin Thompson analyzes the elaborate construction—and mesmerizing chaos—of Renoir’s symphonic tragicomedy.

Title: Ed Lachman: Five Questions
Description: This interview with LIFE DURING WARTIME director of photography Ed Lachman was conducted in March 2011.

Title: John Pierson introduces SPLIT SCREEN Season Two
Ennio De Concini on DIVORCE ITALIAN STYLE
Description: This interview with screenwriter Ennio De Concini was conducted in 2005.

Title: LISTEN TO BRITAIN (Burgin)
Description: In 2001, the English artist Victor Burgin made a video piece, LISTEN TO BRITAIN, inspired by Humphrey Jennings's classic World War II documentary of the same name and Powell & Pressburger’s A CANTERBURY TALE. The seven-minute work was originally presented as a gallery installation and is designed to run as a continuous loop in a dark room. We are please to presented it here, courtesy of the artist.

Title: Ingmar Bergman on CRIES AND WHISPERS
Description: Reporter Marie Nyreröd interviewed director Ingmar Bergman for SVT Svensk Television in the summer of 2003, on the island of Fårö, where he had lived since 1967. In this excerpt, he talks about CRIES AND WHISPERS. At the time of the recording, Bergman was eighty-five.

Title: Jean-Luc Godard, 1972
Description: Excerpted from the 1972 French documentary LA POLITIQUE ET LE BONHEUR: GEORGES KIEJMAN directed by Patrick Camus, this short interview with director Jean-Luc Godard touches on his ideas about political filmmaking and his then-latest film, TOUT VA BIEN.

Title: Adulte
Description: This short film was directed by Carlos Reygadas in 1998, while he was living in Belgium. He used the format to learn the technical aspects of filmmaking. The material presented here is the best available in terms of picture and sound quality.

Title: Cannes 1968
Description: Presented here is an excerpt from Cannes 1968, Sélim Sasson’s newsreel covering filmmaker François Truffaut’s call to shut down the Cannes Film Festival in May 1968. Roman Polanski, Louis Malle, and Jean-Luc Godard were also present.

Title: François Truffaut on Antoine Doinel
Description: In this excerpt from the 1970 TV program “Cinéastes de notre temps: François Truffaut, dix ans, dix films,” director François Truffaut discusses his vision of the Antoine Doinel cycle, and the complex relationship between Doinel and actor Jean-Pierre Léaud.

Title: Monstrous Origins: Outtakes
Description: The silent outtakes and test footage presented here reveal the youthful energy and creativity behind the original version of EQUINOX, 1967’s THE EQUINOX . . . A JOURNEY INTO THE SUPERNATURAL.

Title: Abbas Kiarostami: The Character of Landscape, the Landscape of Character
Description: In the third installment in our ongoing introduction to film language, Professor Kristin Thompson offers an analysis of the legendary Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami's quiet genius.

Title: Ang Lee
Description: Director Ang Lee (THE ICE STORM, BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN) cites THE VIRGIN SPRING as the first art film he saw and one that had a huge impact on him. The following introduction was recorded in October 2005. (Please note: this interview reveals key plot points.)

Title: Michael Ballhaus, 2014
Description: The following interview with THE BITTER TEARS OF PETRA VON KANT cinematographer Michael Ballhaus was conducted in Berlin in 2014.

Title: Double Exposure: DIABOLIQUE and PSYCHO
Description: Two takes on how DIABOLIQUE’s bathtub murder influenced PSYCHO’s shower scene.

Title: Super 8 Footage
Description: This Super 8 footage from the production of PARIS, TEXAS is presented here set to music.

Title: PARIS, TEXAS Deleted Scenes and Super 8 with Monologue
Mike Leigh on THE TREE OF WOODEN CLOGS
Art for Art’s Sake
Description: This piece, produced in 2014, features an interview with Chris Simon, who collaborated with director Les Blank on THE MAESTRO: KING OF THE COWBOY ARTISTS.

Title: “Cinépanorama”: François Truffaut, 1960
Description: In this excerpt from the February 20, 1960, episode of “Cinépanorama,” director François Truffaut discusses the global reception of THE 400 BLOWS, which had just been named best foreign film by the New York Film Critics Circle, and undertakes some self-critical evaluation of his work.

Title: Chantal Akerman and Delphine Seyrig
Description: This segment from the French television program “Les rendez-vous du dimanche,” hosted by Michel Drucker, features director Chantal Akerman and actor Delphine Seyrig discussing their work together on JEANNE DIELMAN. It originally aired on February 15, 1976.

Title: Outtakes
Description: The outtakes presented here are accompanied by music; the original film audio is not available.

Title: David Lynch and Jack Nance on ERASERHEAD
Description: Director David Lynch and actor Jack Nance take a drive to one of ERASERHEAD’s locations in this excerpt from an episode of the French television program “Cinéma, de notre temps,” recorded in 1988 and broadcast on April 23, 1993.

Title: Michael Powell’s Home Movies
Description: Director Michael Powell had a lifelong passion for walking in the hills of Scotland. These home movies, shot by Powell himself and narrated by his widow, editor Thelma Schoonmaker Powell, document one such expedition.

Title: Ophuls’s Collaborators: Annette Wademant
Description: This interview with THE EARRINGS OF MADAME DE . . . cowriter Annette Wademant was conducted by Martina Müller in Paris in 1989.

Title: Outtakes
Description: This rare archival footage of the Rolling Stones in their prime has been preserved as a work print from the original editing sessions for GIMME SHELTER. The performances and backstage footage were filmed at Madison Square Garden on either November 27 or 28, 1969. The mixing session occurred in London in early 1970.

Title: Carlo Lizzani on BITTER RICE
Description: In this 2003 interview, BITTER RICE screenwriter Carlo Lizzani discusses the process of writing the script and working with director Giuseppe De Santis.

Title: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar on THE TALE OF ZATOICHI
On the Set of SECRET SUNSHINE
Description: This program features on-set interviews with actors Jeon Do-yeon and Song Kang-ho, as well as behind-the-scenes footage.

Title: Marcel Ophuls on Max Ophuls
Description: Marcel Ophuls is the son of director Max Ophuls and an Academy Award–winning documentary filmmaker. In this interview, conducted at the Cannes Film Festival in 2008, he discusses LA RONDE and his father’s legacy.

Title: Lando Buzzanca on SEDUCED AND ABANDONED
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2002, actor Lando Buzzanca talks about working with director Pietro Germi on SEDUCED AND ABANDONED.

Title: Kroll: In His Own Words
Description: Producer Nathan Kroll was responsible for documenting Martha Graham's work in the films A DANCER’S WORLD, APPALACHIAN SPRING, and NIGHT JOURNEY. Recorded in 1995, Kroll here describes the origins of the films and the experience of working with Graham. His comments are illustrated with film clips and stills.

Title: Restoring MILDRED PIERCE
Description: Discover the painstaking process behind restoring this cherished classic.

Title: The Making of a Scene
Description: In this on-set footage, director Mathieu Kassovitz orchestrates one of the more technically challenging scenes in LA HAINE, the one in which Vinz fantasizes about shooting a cop.

Title: Alf Sjöberg, 1966
Description: In this interview excerpt, produced for Swedish television in 1966, director Alf Sjöberg discusses his early film career with host Nils Petter Sundgren.

Title: Musical Motifs in FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT
Description: If you’ve always wanted to study film, here’s your chance! In this series, the authors of “Film Art: An Introduction” bring film school home in plain language. This month, Jeff Smith breaks down a classical Hollywood score with a Hitchcockian twist.

Title: Ping Zhu Studio Visit
Description: Meet the artist behind our TAMPOPO cover.

Title: “Cinépanorama”: Pierre Fresnay
Description: On September 25, 1956, actor Pierre Fresnay appeared on television for the first time (on the French program “Cinépanorama”) to commemorate the tenth anniversary of his MARSEILLE TRILOGY costar Raimu’s death and to discuss their collaboration.

Title: Max Douy on FRENCH CANCAN
Description: The following interview with FRENCH CANCAN set designer Max Douy was recorded exclusively at the famed Moulin Rouge in June 2003.

Title: “What’s My Line?”: Harold Lloyd, 1953
Description: On April 26, 1953, Harold Lloyd appeared as a “mystery guest” on the CBS television show “What’s My Line?” to publicize a theatrical rerelease of THE FRESHMAN. His segment from the show is presented here.

Title: The Spanish Actresses: Sophie
Description: Since MR. ARKADIN was originally financed as a French-Spanish coproduction, Orson Welles reshot two scenes with different actresses for the Spanish version of the film. Amparo Rivelles played the Baroness Nagel and Irene López Heredia played Sophie. Those two scenes, one of which is presented here, appear only in the Spanish version of the film.

Title: MR. ARKADIN Rushes: Close-Ups
Description: Found in the archives of the Cinémathèque municipale de Luxembourg, the footage shown here represents rushes Orson Welles used to construct MR. ARKADIN, at least as far as he was able.

Title: Plaisir d’amour en Iran
Description: In this 1976 short film by Agnès Varda, Pauline and Darius explore the city of Isfahan, Iran.

Title: Silvia Pinal on SIMON OF THE DESERT
Description: This interview with Silvia Pinal was recorded in Mexico City in January 2006.

Title: Liquid Crystals
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1978 • France /  / A semi-psychedelic collection of different liquids crystalizing under a microscope.

Title: The Professor
Description: The following uncompleted 1919 short by Charlie Chaplin reveals his early interest in performing fleas.

Title: Concert for Dogs
Description: On January 4, 2016, Laurie Anderson performed her “Concert for Dogs” in New York City’s Times Square, in honor of 9/11 first responders’ dogs. The music was transmitted to audience members through headphones and to the dogs via low-decibel speakers, while footage from HEART OF A DOG played on video billboard screens on the surrounding buildings.

Title: Carrots & Peas
Description: Directed by Hollis Frampton • 1969 • United States /  / I thought of the film as a set of ironies upon the form of the art history through its little vocabulary of images; the language is there as a kind of empty sign of the distraction of the lecturing voice, which, if you're actually looking at the images, goes in one ear and out the other. Of Course, the first time anybody ever looked at the film out of my control, they immediately ran the track backwards.' - Hollis Frampton

Title: Hairat
Description: Directed by Jessica Beshir • 2017 • Ethiopia /  / Yussuf Mume Saleh journeys nightly into the outskirts of the walled city of Harar to bond with his beloved hyenas, a ritual he has practiced for over thirty-five years. Shot in black and white, HAIRAT is a meditation on this uniquely symbiotic relationship between man and wild beast.

Title: “Cinépanorama”: PICKPOCKET
Description: In this 1960 episode of the French television program “Cinépanorama,” director Robert Bresson answers questions about PICKPOCKET from interviewers France Roche and François Chalais.

Title: John Pierson introduces SPLIT SCREEN Season Seven
Fiction and Other Truths: A Film About Jane Rule—1
Description: Canadian author Jane Rule published the novel “Desert of the Heart” in 1964; it has come to be considered a landmark of lesbian fiction. The following excerpts from the 1994 documentary FICTION AND OTHER TRUTHS: A FILM ABOUT JANE RULE, by Lynne Fernie and Aerlyn Weissman, feature Rule discussing the writing of her groundbreaking book.

Title: The Making of ANTICHRIST: Behind the Test Film
Description: Made in 2010 by Zentropa’s DVD production company, Electric Parc.

Title: Stefania Sandrelli on SEDUCED AND ABANDONED
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2002, actress Stefania Sandrelli talks about working with director Pietro Germi on SEDUCED AND ABANDONED.

Title: Beyond PLAYTIME
Description: This short documentary from 2002, written by Jacques Tati scholar Stéphane Goudet and featuring rare archival footage, explores the genesis of the director’s hugely ambitious production.

Title: Peter Bogdanovich
Description: This introduction by filmmaker and writer Peter Bogdanovich was recorded in 2005.

Title: “Passez donc me voir”: THE LAST METRO
Description: In this excerpt from a 1980 episode of the French television program “Passez donc me voir,” director François Truffaut and actor Jean Poiret discuss their work on THE LAST METRO and their memories of the occupation.

Title: THE 400 BLOWS Auditions
Description: This 16 mm screen test footage from 1958 features an interview with actor Jean-Pierre Léaud, some improvised dialogue between Léaud and Patrick Auffay (René in THE 400 BLOWS), and an audition by Richard Kanayan (who plays one of the children and went on to appear in François Truffaut’s SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER in 1960).

Title: Bernardo Bertolucci on MAMMA ROMA
Description: Filmmaker Bernardo Bertolucci began as a production assistant to Pier Paolo Pasolini on Pasolini’s first film, ACCATTONE (1961). This interview with Bertolucci was conducted in 2004.

Title: John Pierson introduces SPLIT SCREEN Season Six
Arlette Langmann and Patrick Grandperret on L’ENFANCE NUE
Description: Arlette Langmann is the cowriter of L’ENFANCE NUE and a longtime collaborator of Maurice Pialat's. Patrick Grandperret is a filmmaker who also served as Pialat's assistant director. This interview was conducted by Serge Toubiana on April 18, 2003, shortly after Pialat's death.

Title: Unreleased Performances: Clarence Ashley, 1963
Description: The outtake presented here, originally recorded by director Murray Lerner and his crew for FESTIVAL, features an unreleased performance by Clarence Ashley.

Title: John Sayles on HARLAN COUNTY USA
Description: Director John Sayles’s films include RETURN OF THE SECAUCUS 7, LONE STAR, and MATEWAN, which chronicles the struggles of West Virginia coal miners in the 1920s as they try to unionize. The following interview was recorded in November 2005.

Title: John Pierson introduces SPLIT SCREEN Season One
Nick Doob on THE WAR ROOM
Description: In this interview, shot in 2011, THE WAR ROOM camera operator Nick Doob discusses the process of gaining access to, and then filming, a presidential campaign.

Title: The Sex Scenes of WEEKEND
Description: In this short piece, created in 2012, director Andrew Haigh comments on the most intimate moments between the characters Glen and Russell in WEEKEND.

Title: Outtakes: Big Brother and the Holding Company
Mishima on Mishima
Description: In this interview, journalist and historian Jean Prasteau talks to author Yukio Mishima for an episode of the series “À la vitrine du libraire.” It originally aired on January 15, 1966.

Title: Jeanne Moreau on THE LOVERS, 1972
Description: In this interview, which was directed by Jacques Nahum and Raoul Sangla for “Tête d’affiche” and originally aired on January 30, 1972, actor Jeanne Moreau discusses her “scandalous” roles, beginning with Jeanne in THE LOVERS.

Title: English Prologue
Description: When THE FLOWERS OF ST. FRANCIS premiered, at the 1950 Venice Film Festival, it contained a specially prepared prologue on paintings and frescoes from Francis's time (mainly Giotto's frescoes on the life of the saint), to help situate and contextualize the story historically. Removed prior to the film's general Italian release, later that year, it disappeared from view until the American edition, first showin in New York in October 1952. That version of the film included what is believed to be a shortened form of the prologue, which is presented here.

Title: Serge Reggiani on CASQUE D’OR
Description: This interview with CASQUE D’OR star Serge Reggiani was conducted by critic Claude-Jean Philippe in 1995 for the program “La France en films.”

Title: Charlotte Gainsbourg at Cannes
Description: This video interview with Charlotte Gainsbourg at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival

Title: THE UMBRELLAS OF CHERBOURG: Restoration Demo
Terry Jones
Description: This introduction to PLAYTIME by actor and comedian Terry Jones was recorded in 2001.

Title: Junkopia
Director: Chris Marker, Frank Simeone, and John Chapman
Description: Directed by Chris Marker, Frank Simeone, and John Chapman • 1981 • United States /  / The filming of the Vertigo sequences in Sans Soleil brought director Chris Marker to the Bay Area on a number of occasions in the early eighties. During those visits, Marker's friend Tom Luddy often drove him from Berkeley to Francis Ford Coppola's Zoetrope film offices in San Francisco. That journey passed by the Emeryville Mudflats, an ever-changing art gallery of driftwood sculptures and structures that intrigued Marker. Created by anonymous artists, the works would regularly wash away with the tides, only to be replaced by new ones. One day, with the help of some of the Zoetrope crew, Marker went out to immortalize the scene, which no longer exists.

Title: American Version Excerpts: Ending Sequence
Description: A CANTERBURY TALE was considered a failure after its initial U.K. release, and Michael Powell agreed to reedit it for the American market. In addition to cutting the film by over twenty minutes and reordering scenes, he shot a new prologue and a scene near the end of the film that cast the main story as a flashback  - Sgt. Johnson's account of his adventures in Kent is told to his new wife, played by Kim Hunter, who was soon to appear in the Archers' A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH. The ending sequence with Hunter is presented here.

Title: American Version Excerpts: Prologue
Description: A CANTERBURY TALE was considered a failure after its initial U.K. release, and Michael Powell agreed to reedit it for the American market. In addition to cutting the film by over twenty minutes and reordering scenes, he shot a new prologue and a scene near the end of the film that cast the main story as a flashback  - Sgt. Johnson's account of his adventures in Kent is told to his new wife, played by Kim Hunter, who was soon to appear in the Archers' A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH. The proloque with Hunter is presented here.

Title: From the 1921 Version
Description: THE KID was initially released in 1921, as part of Charlie Chaplin’s eight-picture deal with First National Exhibitors Circuit. When Chaplin revisited the film in 1971, he made significant changes. Included here are the original First National opening titles, various intertitles, and the closing card reading “The End,” all of which were redesigned for the film’s later version.

Title: Cahuenga Blvd.
Description: Directed by Andrew Haigh • 2003 • United Kingdom /  / This short film, created in 2003 by Andrew Haigh, provides some insight into the director’s evolving vision.

Title: Uncle
